**Simplified Text:**

**Garbage in, garbage out**

Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away seems like a good idea for the environment and for money. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have similar ways of dealing with rubbish. One common way is that local governments collect rubbish at regular times. Rubbish bags or bins are taken away by special trucks to a dump. 

To economists, this system is strange because in many places, it is free. Families pay for this service through local taxes, but a family that throws away four bags of rubbish each week pays the same as an elderly couple that throws away one bag. However, the cost of getting rid of rubbish is not zero. The more rubbish people throw away, the more trucks and workers are needed, and the more local governments have to pay to dump the rubbish. 

If rubbish disposal is free, people will throw away too much rubbish. A simple solution is to make families pay for the cost of throwing away their waste. This would encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, if local governments provide places to recycle. 

But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this simple idea can have complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns that started charging families for their rubbish. The most common way was to sell stickers or tags that families had to put on their rubbish bags. Only bags with these tags were picked up each week. 

In a study published last year, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at a program started in July 1992 in Charlottesville, Virginia, a town with about 40,000 people. Residents had to pay 80 cents for each tagged bag of rubbish. This seems like a good use of market forces. However, the authors found that the benefits of the program did not cover the costs of printing tags, paying sellers, and paying workers. 

True, the number of bags thrown away fell by 37%. But this was mostly because people crammed more rubbish into each bag, a behavior called the "Seattle stomp." Instead of buying more tags, people jumped on their bags to fit more rubbish inside. This is not as effective as machines at dumps. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14% in Charlottesville. In 25 other Virginia cities without a pricing program, the weight fell by 3.5% anyway. 

Worse, some people started to dump their rubbish illegally instead of paying for collection. The authors guess that illegal dumping may account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. 

One positive result was a 15% increase in recycling, which suggests that people chose to recycle (which is free) instead of paying to throw away their rubbish. But many people were already recycling in Charlottesville before the program started. 

In a more recent study, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at rubbish in more detail. They found that charging for rubbish does reduce the amount thrown away, but not by much. On average, a 10% increase in sticker prices only cuts rubbish by 0.3%. This is less than in other studies. To throw away a lot less rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. 

If this is true, we should think about whether other things, like income and education, are just as important as price. In richer towns, for example, people throw away more rubbish than in poorer towns and have less time to recycle. 

Should we say that charging families for rubbish is a bad idea? Not really; free disposal is probably too cheap. But the effects of simple policies can be complicated. We often need complex economic models to understand them. Sometimes, the results are not very good. 

**Questions:**

1. What is the main idea of the text?
2. Why do economists think the system of free rubbish disposal is strange?
3. What did Fullerton and Kinnaman study?
4. What happened to the number of rubbish bags in Charlottesville after the program started?
5. What is the "Seattle stomp"?
6. Did recycling increase or decrease in Charlottesville after the program started? 
7. What do the authors suggest about the relationship between income and rubbish disposal?

**Simplified Text:**

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life could change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at your job? Success in a career is not enough anymore. Many people feel that their work is not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy despite their success. Loving your job used to be enough to make you special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is an important question. If your skills make you boring and you cannot talk to others outside your job, then no amount of money or status will make you happy.

I want to find out how work can help us feel fulfilled and not just be a way to make money. Work should help us live better lives, discover new talents, and meet different people. However, this does not mean that unemployment will disappear. As more people get educated, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful.

Even jobs that used to be respected, like doctors and architects, can be stressful and unfulfilling. Many workers feel unhappy in their jobs. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel that their values match those of their companies. I am studying different jobs to see how they affect people. I want to understand happiness, love, friendship, and respect in our work lives.

Many people feel like they are not truly alive at work. They may have the choice to leave their jobs, but they feel stuck because of their qualifications and careers. For example, many hotel workers are smart and capable but work long hours for low pay and little respect. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep; they could be cultural centers where people from different countries meet and connect.

Hotel staff often have little chance to use their skills and knowledge. If hotels listened to their workers' dreams, they could offer more services. But many hotels focus only on making money. It is time to think about work in a new way, focusing on people, not just profits. 

For me, work is about relationships. Many people want to have more control over their jobs and choose their colleagues. This means they need to learn to communicate well with others. Good communication is important, but it is different from real conversation. Real conversation creates a bond of respect and can change how we see each other. Every time we have a meaningful conversation, we make the world a little better. 

**Questions:**

1. What does Theodore Zeldin think about success in a career?
2. Why is it important to think about how work affects us as people?
3. What do many hotel workers feel about their jobs?
4. How can hotels become more than just places to sleep?
5. What does Zeldin believe is important for work relationships?

**Text: 'BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology'**

'Broadcasting' originally meant to spread seeds widely by hand. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents hope for growth and success. The idea suggests that there are resources available to help spread information and ideas. 

We need to understand why a new technology that sends words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fits this farming idea. Television is connected to other forms of communication, like the telegraph and the telephone. However, from the beginning, it was seen as a centralised 'mass' medium. This means that it sent information from one central place to many homes. This way of broadcasting matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.

There were some attempts to create different ways of using television. In the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain tried to make two-way television, which could replace regular telephones. Many science magazines, like Radio News, published articles on how to build television equipment. However, in 1938, big companies agreed on standards for television that pushed these amateur efforts aside. This was a missed opportunity for a different kind of television that could have been more equal and community-based.

In the early 1930s, television was mostly used for public shows in the USA and was seen as a competitor to the film industry. Many people watched television in public places, especially in Britain and Germany. The idea of amateur two-way television was not successful, but public viewing was common in several countries during the 1930s. 

Manufacturers wanted to sell more home television sets, so they focused on broadcasting to many homes. As working-class people improved their living standards from the 1920s, the dream of having entertainment at home became real for many people in Western countries. This is now happening worldwide.

There is a clear link between social changes and how broadcasting is organized. As societies modernized, they became more centralized, and traditional communities broke apart. People became more mobile, which made them feel more isolated compared to earlier communities. Centralized broadcasting helped governments share important information with all citizens and created a sense of community in the nation-state.

Broadcasting became the main way to share information through radio and television. However, there is also a positive view of broadcasting as a way to support democracy. Between the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way to ensure everyone had access to important information for participating in society.

Television is changing, and the term broadcasting may not fit well anymore. In the future, this idea may only refer to a specific way of using audio-visual technology during a certain time of social change.

**Text: Clutter**

Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes we want too many things. Modern advertising is made to play on our fears. The message is often, "If you don’t have this, you are not good enough." 

To see how much advertising affects you, try not to look at any billboards the next time you walk down the street. We see many ads on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet. All of these tell us to buy more things.

**Caves**

Many researchers and universities around the world study caves. They look at where caves come from, how water moves in them, and what lives in them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and have been studied for a long time, especially in places where caves affect our lives. 

However, visiting many caves requires physical strength, so cave research is often done by both scientists and people who visit caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**

Many people have watched the weather for a long time without any tools. This helped create the science of meteorology, which has become very advanced since the 17th century. Now, satellites and electronic tools give us a lot of weather information quickly. Computers can solve complex math problems much faster than people can.

Meteorology uses many difficult words that are hard to understand. But human experience is still very important for making weather forecasts. What people observe can help scientists understand the weather better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Not long ago, I thought that opera was mainly theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. This is how it should be. I come from the world of theatre, where the words and the actors are very important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once it starts, and the performers and the audience usually speak the same language.

At any music performance, whether in a concert hall or an opera house, there are many people who, like me, do not know much about music. Some of them may feel embarrassed about what they don’t know. Most people are amazed by the skill of the performers. A great singer or a good musician shows us the results of many years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports match. We know athletes are doing something similar to what we do when we run for a bus, but we see how much better they are.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand how skilled an actor is and may not be very impressed when an actor finishes a long speech. They often ask, “How do you learn all those lines?” This does not mean that theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences; many of them are the same people. It may mean that audiences and performers are more equal in theatre than in music.

Does music need to learn from theatre? I think yes. I have seen how a different approach can make the experience of concert-goers better. Live music is very theatrical, full of feelings, and can be surprising. The rules that still exist in music, like strict dress codes and showing too much respect to conductors and soloists, make a big difference between players and listeners. This can feel uncomfortable.

On the other hand, when music audiences clap between songs or after a great performance, it can be a nice way to show appreciation, but it can also interrupt the flow of the music. 

Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done. Many people are working to bring new audiences to concert halls and opera houses and to make them feel that “serious” music is for everyone. I remember a special event called In Search of Angels, which took place in a cathedral and then moved into the town. It was a wonderful musical experience, and many audience members were not just there to watch and listen but also to take part.

I wish music could be more like the exciting and bold theatre. Sometimes this can happen in unusual places, where expectations are changed. This can create surprising effects for both performers and audiences. People may have to give up some comforts, like a good sound or warmth, but theatre audiences have learned to be brave and follow artists into unexpected spaces.

I know that most plays are performed in a usual way, not very different from concerts. However, I believe that we can and should change how we experience music. I am just a fan: I love theatre and spend a lot of time and money enjoying music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy being part of the audience.

**Text:**

**Sand**  
I admire how sand can be changed into useful things like glass and concrete, but I do not like it when it is just sand. To me, sand is a problem. It is a barrier between a parking lot and the sea. It blows in your face, gets into your food, and can hide important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove, even with a strong hose. But, when you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, the sand falls off you. For days, you find sand on the floor when you take off your shoes, and more sand comes out when you take off your socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. I do not want sand around me.

**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home. The old way to lock a door was with a rope, but now we have electronic locks that use plastic cards. However, people still like to use a real key to lock their doors. Even when companies make new electronic locks, they still include a metal key because people want to feel safe at home.

**Modern Art**  
I was nervous to visit the new Tate Modern gallery because I do not understand modern art. I like some of it, especially furry things, neon lights, and big photos. I think if I knew more about art, I would have more opinions. The important thing is not to understand art perfectly, but to let it speak to you. This gallery tries to help visitors understand the art better. The first thing I noticed was the labels that explain what the art is about. These labels helped me understand the art instead of just looking at it without knowing.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

**Adapting Novels for Film**

When a book is made into a movie, many parts of the story are often cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see things in a new way. While writing a script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the dialogue and descriptions from the book and still tell the same story. This does not mean that the original words were not important. It is about how each type of story (books and movies) asks the audience to pay attention in different ways. 

In a book, some details about characters are repeated to help readers remember them. For example, we might see the same character trait mentioned more than once. In a movie, we can often tell who is speaking by looking at the scene, but using names like "he said" can make it easier to follow. 

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the story. It is a special experience that takes us away from our everyday lives, at least for the time the movie lasts. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we are back in the real world. Some people think that watching movies is just for fun and not real art. Many of our parents and teachers felt this way. They enjoyed movies but did not see them as something important.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were made up of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because the layout was confusing. There were a few important places, like the Script Department, but most of the rooms looked the same. There were three main entrances, but none of them helped you find your way easily. Most people who worked there knew how to get around, but it was difficult for visitors. 

Because of the hard work of the people at the studio, stories of love and adventure could be shared with audiences. Couples like Jane and George, or Sally and Dick, could escape their everyday problems for a few hours while watching a movie.

**Film-Makers**

Many people want to make movies. Bookstores have many books about how to write scripts and make films. Universities offer classes on this topic. There are even contests where you can win a camera to make your own movie. Robert Rodriguez made a famous film called El Mariachi for only $7,000, and it helped him become a well-known director. He wrote about how he felt he needed to make his big movie soon, just like famous directors did when they were young.

In the past, it took longer for film-makers to start making movies. They often worked in other jobs first, like editing or writing. For example, John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, and Fred Zinnemann was in his forties. But now, many new film-makers have to find their own way without the help of big studios or television.

**Simplified Text:**

In the past, the council houses were all over the western side of the city. They were rows of small, old houses made of orange brick or white plaster. In summer, the smell from a factory nearby filled the air, and a paperboy often looked disgusted as he walked to deliver papers. I have forgotten most of my early life, but I remember sitting by an upstairs window and looking at the houses in the distance. I also remember my mother, who was small, precise, and often angry. I never understood why she was angry, so I could not make her feel better.

Even as a child, I noticed that my mother was very lonely. She felt alone even in a room full of people. She had strict rules about how to behave, which I did not understand. For example, we were not allowed to walk into our neighbors' gardens or disturb their flowers. We had to sit quietly at the dining table, listening to the radio shows my mother liked. There were many rules like this.

My mother had a few friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. I later realized that they were not very good company. They often talked about their problems, like bad legs and cold weather, and I sometimes felt like I was one of the problems.

Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight was on my shoulders, and I needed to grow up quickly to escape it. Growing up in West Earlham was very structured. Until you were five, you stayed at home. I remember long days playing on a rug while my mother sat in a chair, looking cold. After turning five, you went to Avenue Road infants school, which was half a mile away. Some lucky kids had mothers with bikes, but my mother usually let other kids take care of me on the way.

If I remember anything from those early years, it is the summer holidays. I saw a little of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door who told stories about his time at sea. Once, there was a charity event where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to get me to join a group for helping others. But my mother dismissed it, saying they just wanted money. She often talked about how people were only after money, and she did not like politicians at all.

My mother was not completely unaware of her role in my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum on the bus. We would look at paintings together. My mother did not mind this, and she even started to have opinions about the art. I remember one time she saw a painting of a Roman soldier and joked, "Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!" This was a rare moment of humor from her. 

**Questions:**

1. What type of houses were common in the western side of the city?
2. How did the paperboy feel when he delivered papers?
3. Describe the mother in the text. What was she like?
4. Who were the three friends of the mother mentioned in the text?
5. What did the mother think about charity events and politicians? 
6. Where did the mother take the child on Sundays? 
7. What did the mother say about the painting of the Roman soldier?

**Text: Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. It was getting dark, and the air felt thick and damp. I knew this side of the street very well. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. The Krings and the Pottses lived nearby, and they were my first friends, all girls. 

The houses on this street were different, even if I didn’t know everyone’s name. I remembered the small channels in the cement that carried rain from the roofs to the street. I used to skate and ride my scooter over them. As the street went down, the houses seemed to get simpler. The porches were lower, and the front yards were smaller. 

Over the years, things changed. Wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces and how they dealt with the smells of the old stores.

**Bachelor Fads Furniture Designer Rick Gilbert**

Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has big doors and exposed brick walls. But Rick did not want his flat to be completely open. He said it was hard to work when everything was in view. So, he used a big piece of plastic to create a hallway and hide his office. 

He wanted the kitchen to be a place where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. To make the flat feel warmer, he put light wood on the floors. He has modern chairs and sofas, but he also has some old furniture from his parents or from markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. He wrote a famous book called *In Patagonia* in 1977. This book changed travel writing. It was exciting and imaginative. Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories better. He believed that traveling could help people discover new histories and adventures.

**Swimming**

One summer day, it rained heavily. I ran across the lawn behind my house and jumped into the pool. I swam back and forth, watching the raindrops splash like little fountains. The best moments were when the rain got stronger, and the sound of birds disappeared. 

During this summer in 1996, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the feeling of going in circles, like a tiger in a cage. Many places today are marked and labeled, which makes them feel less real. Walking, cycling, and swimming help us feel the wildness of nature. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious parts of our world.

**Text: 'CRYING**

Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose in human evolution. He was likely wrong. Recently, scientists have shown that crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby explained that crying helps create a bond between a mother and her child. Many people believe that tears, especially in children, show feelings of helplessness. 

However, it is harder to understand why adults cry. The sound of crying is not as important as what we see when someone cries. In early human groups, crying may have helped people trust each other and feel connected. 

People cry for many reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for someone who is suffering. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, like when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We may also cry when watching a sad movie, and this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social reasons for crying are clear, but research is still ongoing.'

**Text: The Heat is On**

We have all heard about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Most people know a little about global warming, but many are not sure what will happen because of it. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere in the world. Since the atmosphere affects everything on our planet, any changes in the climate will also affect plants, animals, water, and soil.

Humans have learned to use natural resources to help us grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are very important. The problem is that we do not know exactly how the world will change or what is causing these changes. Over the last 100 years, human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are connected to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate, but we do not fully understand how.

We know that the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has changed with global temperatures over the last 40,000 years. This shows that they are related. Evidence suggests that our planet has warmed by about 6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not just natural and is partly caused by human pollution.

Many scientists are trying to predict what will happen because of higher global temperatures. They use special computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs). These programs help scientists understand how temperature, pressure, sunlight, and other factors interact to predict climate conditions. However, these models are not perfect and can be slow and expensive to use. We do not fully understand all the processes in the climate system, but we know it is complex.

Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than we have seen before. The predictions from GCMs help us understand what the world will be like in the future. They suggest that by the year 2100, the average global temperature could rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, and sea levels could rise by 15 to 95 cm. We may also see more extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts.

These changes will affect the environment and humans. Climate change can change where forests and grasslands are located, the types of species in these areas, and their ability to provide resources we need, like food and water. Some effects may be harmful, but not all changes will be bad. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have helped increase wheat production.

However, many predicted effects of climate change are concerning. Small changes in climate can affect water availability, especially in dry areas. The Mediterranean region is already seeing less rainfall in some places. In southern Portugal, for example, rain is now falling more in autumn and winter, with less in spring.

Another problem is that glaciers are changing. This will affect ice in the Arctic and other areas, which will impact plants, animals, and human structures. The most visible effect of global warming will be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds to this. Since many people live in coastal areas, rising sea levels could lead to serious problems, like flooding in cities such as London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people could lose their homes and jobs, creating millions of environmental refugees.

The worst effects will likely be felt by small island nations, which could disappear if sea levels rise too much. This would be devastating for the people and cultures of these islands, as well as for the countries that would have to help those who are displaced.

Text: 'Mission to Mars

Wanted: a married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars. Applicants must be strong and healthy. This will be the first astronauts on Mars if Dennis Tito's plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 succeed. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars' gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel. Saving fuel is very important because the next time Mars and Earth are close together is in 2031. 

It is a big task, but there is a race to create new technologies. If these technologies are ready in time, the spacecraft might go to Mars. Even if it does not leave Earth, the work on this project will help future missions.'

**AESTHETICS**

Art is important, but sometimes it is hard to understand. This is because we often think of art only as things we can see, like buildings, books, paintings, or statues. However, the real meaning of art comes from how we experience it. When we only focus on the art itself, we can miss its true significance.

Some artworks are very famous and admired. Because of this, people may forget the human experiences that created them. When art is seen as separate from life, it becomes difficult to understand its meaning. Art should not be isolated; it should connect with our everyday experiences.

To understand art better, we need to look at it in a different way. We should think about the normal things in life that help us appreciate art. For example, we can enjoy flowers without knowing much about plants. But if we want to understand how flowers grow, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight.

Many people enjoy things like movies, music, and comics, but they do not always think of these as art. When art is only seen in museums, people may forget to enjoy the art in their daily lives. It is important to remember that art is connected to our everyday experiences. When art is linked to the things we do every day, we can appreciate it more.

**Text: Observing Lions**

Lions are often seen as amazing hunters. In the evening, a group of lions quietly comes out of the shadows to catch their food. They seem to work well together to hunt and take care of their young. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have learned that their behavior is not always as perfect as it seems. 

When we started our research in 1978, we wanted to understand why lions hunt together, raise their cubs, and scare away other animals with their loud roars. We thought that working together would help them survive better. But if one lion helps too much, it might not get enough food for itself. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in a few years, but lions are very good at resting. 

It has taken us a long time to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand their actions.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was an important moment for the band. The album, called *New Life*, changed rock music in this country for many years. It moved away from the serious and heavy music of the past and introduced a lighter and more fun style. 

The songs mixed social comments with strong feelings and included sounds from fairground organs and brass bands. The band used humor and showed their true voices. They wrote songs about everyday things like sunbathing and relaxing on Sundays. But the best songs had deep feelings, like "So Low," which was a beautiful song about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. 

*New Life* is special because it has 16 great songs with no bad ones, which is rare for long albums.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was always interested in stories about 'The Sibyl,' wise women from ancient times. I first heard about one from my mother. An old woman from Cumae offered King Tarquin of Rome nine books for 300 gold pieces. He said no, so she burned three books and offered him six for the same price. He still said no, so she burned three more. Finally, he bought the last three for 300 gold pieces. I learned a valuable lesson from this story about selling and life.

I was often lonely as an only child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they would not let me. My mother told me to do something interesting so they would want to join me. It worked, and I have never forgotten that lesson.

When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something that mattered to me. I don’t like to travel much, so I sent my editor a long list of places I did not want to go. I prefer to explore ruins because I enjoy traveling through time in my mind.

**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**

When you send your manuscript, it will likely go into a pile of other manuscripts waiting to be read. This pile is called the slush pile. Usually, a junior editor or an experienced editor will look at it. They want to find something new and interesting. If they like your novel, they will show it to a senior editor. 

The senior editor will need to explain why your novel is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about whether you, as an author, can be successful in the future. Publishers often want to meet authors before making an offer.

**Text: Advertising Challenges**

If you work in advertising, the early 1990s were very hard years. There was a big recession, which means that many businesses were not doing well. This recession lasted a long time and was worse than expected. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were very high, and many people lost their jobs. More than half a million people were unemployed, and many homes were taken back by banks because people could not pay their mortgages. All businesses were affected, especially the car and building industries, which saw a drop of 30%.

People in advertising were not the only ones losing their jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help their companies make money, but they had to do this with smaller budgets. They were told to do more with less money. At the same time, companies started to realize that they needed to make products that customers wanted, not just what was easy for them to make. This idea became more important in the last ten to fifteen years.

Because of this, marketing became more important in companies. More people in management learned about marketing, and some brands started to market themselves better. This made marketing professionals more respected, but it also made their jobs harder. Many people thought that marketing could solve all problems, but this was not true. About half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising, so advertising people felt a lot of responsibility.

In the 1980s, advertising was very successful, but in the early 1990s, it faced many challenges. The bad economy made companies cut their advertising budgets and think more carefully about how much they were spending. Many companies were not sure if advertising was worth the money. They wanted to know what they were getting for their investment.

Client companies wanted better advertising strategies, better targeting, better creativity, and better media placement. They wanted the best people from advertising agencies to work for them and to be motivated to create great work. While this situation is tough for advertising professionals, it also means they have to find ways to do more with less.

There are many reasons why creating effective advertising is difficult. Some of these reasons are because of the recession, like high production costs and the fear of taking risks. Other reasons are changes in society, like the power of retailers, changing consumer needs, and new laws about advertising. Some companies also face the challenge of advertising in other countries.

Because of the economic situation and these changes, advertising professionals need to find out what works in advertising. They remember the saying, "Only half of my advertising works. The trouble is I don't know which half." Now, there is more pressure to make sure that advertising is effective.

Unfortunately, help for those who want to improve their advertising is not easy to find. Companies and advertising agencies are too busy dealing with these problems to share their experiences. Those who have succeeded often keep their success a secret. This means that while some events may provide useful information, many books about advertising do not help much. They often make it seem like all advertising work is of high quality, which is not true. This does not help the employees who are responsible for advertising in their companies.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was in university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Most people wanted different jobs. Cooking seemed like a hard job. Chefs work long hours, feel a lot of pressure, do simple tasks, and do not earn much money. But I did not let this stop me. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life was not good. Being a chef seemed like a good escape from my student life. It promised a serious and honest way of living that I did not find in college.

My wish to cook was not just because I was unhappy. I also loved the beauty of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I remember my first dish very well. After that meal, I wanted to learn all the secrets of cooking. I changed my student life to prepare for becoming a chef. My history degree felt unimportant, and I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making special meals.

**Extract from a Novel**

The swimming instructor at my school was a small, strong man with tattoos. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this until the hour was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. He was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with dislike and said, "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight." "Point your toes!" 

The next week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high, and I felt scared. I tried to gather my courage. Slowly, I could not hear anything and felt like I was in a quiet bubble. I waved my arms like I had been taught, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment, but I still felt very happy. I thought, "This is what they mean by 'free as a bird.'"

**The Traveller**

For people who care about having a comfortable bed, running water, and living safely, the traveller seems strange and interesting. These are people who choose to take risks. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone on rough seas, eat insects if they have to, and can live for months in unknown places. It is easy to think of them as odd or different. They seem to live in a world far from ours, and we can ignore them, happy to return to our lives with microwaves and phones. We feel safe knowing the risks we face are predictable, like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not say he is a world-class sailor, but he is good enough. He sails because he is a writer and wants to write about sailing. Sailing gives him stories to tell. Raban's small boat has a device that tells sailors their exact location anywhere in the world. He likes this tool, but he also believes that using a compass was a mistake. He thinks it changed how people connect with the sea. Now, sailors look at the compass instead of studying the waves and feeling the ocean. The sea, which used to be full of life, is now just a space to cross. Because of this, a sailor can use an autopilot for long times. This is why Raban has time to watch the waves carefully.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books can help us feel at home in the world. We can relate our own experiences to those in great books from the past or from faraway places. In other people's books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can express what we feel but in a clearer way. What we feel shy about is clearly written in their words. We feel thankful to these authors for reminding us of who we are.

When we read and travel, we escape our daily routines. Our eyes are wide open when we first arrive in a new place. This is also true when we read a great book, which shows us things we might have missed before. Our minds become more aware of the world around us. We notice the colors of the sky, the expressions on people's faces, and feelings we didn’t know we had.

**Author's Note**

These thoughts about travel were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes to fit the articles better, but not much else. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were small details. If I rewrote the articles to predict future events, they would not be true to the moment I wrote them. Like any traveler, I was there, not knowing what would happen next, just trying to understand what had already happened. This is the story of modern travel: the world opening up to people who can afford a ticket. But I believe my fellow travelers were not completely unaware. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been misused, "ecotourism" would win first prize. This term started in the early 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that many travelers wanted to make sure their trips did not harm the places they visited. The term quickly became popular. Now, "ecotourism" can mean anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour that includes cultural experiences, beautiful nature, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is likely called ecotourism. The original idea was good, but without clear rules, many travelers became confused about what ecotourism really means.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook about my trip to Transylvania for 50 years, but I found it again a few years ago. It helped me remember that time, but it was not perfect. In Transylvania, I had a much easier time than I expected, staying in friendly country houses for weeks. When I stayed in one place for a long time, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only wrote short notes instead of full stories. I worried that some details might be out of order when I began writing this book, so I added many warnings. But then I realized that these pages were not a guidebook, so I let the story flow without too many worries.

**Text: Fashion and Writing**

**Fashion**  
Fashion is often thought of as something new, but it has a long history. Many experts say that fashion started to grow in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries when trade became more important. As societies grew and changed, more types of clothing were made, and the meanings of what we wear became more complex. Today, it is hard to know what a piece of clothing really means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people.

**Writing**  
Stories in newspapers about famous authors can give a wrong idea about what life is like for most writers. Many writers, like me, do not have best-selling books. We often have to work other jobs to pay the bills. Some writers work in the evenings and have full-time jobs. Others, like me, do different small jobs, such as teaching and writing articles. I have heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I have never found one. Still, by balancing part-time jobs and using credit cards, and with help from friends, I manage to write my novel.

**Sudden Fame**  
When we started performing at small places, they began to fill up with fans. We had to use secret doors to avoid being overwhelmed by excited girls. On our days off, it was hard to go outside without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of us. Even though I was still shy, I felt a strange new confidence that many shy people understand. In short, I felt very out of my comfort zone.

**Text: Music - The Future of Music**

Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were many new ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, there were fewer live music performances and fewer jobs for professional musicians.

More people can access music now, and this is likely to continue because music meets many human needs. Music is important for national events and for personal activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments.

I believe that people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big part of the economy in Britain, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help young people develop important skills. Research in the USA shows that making music can improve thinking skills. Studies in Europe suggest that group music lessons can help children with social skills and concentration.

Current research is looking at how playing an instrument can help people learn other skills. For example, practicing regularly can help with good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of this, there will likely be a continued need for music lessons in the near future.

What about the future? There are two likely changes. First, people will listen to more types of music, and new styles will mix together. Second, technology will be used more to create and perform music. This will make it easier for people to compose music, but it may also mean fewer live performances.

More people of all ages will want to make music together in their communities, reflecting their local musical traditions. To prepare for this future, music education needs to change. We need to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This means music lessons will need to adapt to be relevant for more people.

Musicians will need to be trained to inspire and teach learners of all ages. They will also need skills to work with different groups and to communicate well. This is a big change from traditional music teaching, and it will require accountability to the public. 

Finally, we need to raise awareness of the importance of music in our lives. Music is essential, but it is often taken for granted. Everyone in the music profession should work together to make sure this changes.

**The Actor's Craft**

Sometimes, people do not respect actors. This is often because actors talk about their work in interviews. Instead of sharing deep thoughts, they often use boring phrases or gossip. The actor Paul Scofield once wrote to a friend that acting is best when it is performed, not when it is talked about. He said that acting has no strict rules, except that the audience should hear the actor. Each time an actor performs, they start fresh and learn about their character and the story. After a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next performance. This emptiness shows when people talk about acting.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester plays Hamlet in a way that shows he is between being a boy and a man. His performance is simple but strong. He controls his body and emotions well, showing both anger and humor. This makes his character both scary and lovable. You can see how he waits to act, and his friend Horatio also seems to be moved by something inside him. 

**What is Acting?**

What does it mean to act? Is it copying real behavior or creating something new? This is a big question in theater.

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

One director has a special way to start rehearsals called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. The actors listen quietly to understand the words. When it is their turn to speak, they look at the screen, think about the words, and wait for the right moment to talk. For example, if the line is about waiting in the rain, they might remember a time they waited in line. They should not plan too much but trust that something will happen when they act.

**The Perfect Theatre**

A perfect theater makes you feel important. Going to a live performance should feel special. The staff should care about the audience. The audience should feel close to the actors and be able to hear and see them well. The size of the theater is important too. If the theater is too big, it can feel wrong because acting is about people. Many theaters built in the late 1800s were good because they made the audience feel connected to the stage. 

When you go to the theater, you want to see something surprising and new. If not, you might as well stay home.

Rock and roll in the 1950s was mainly for young people, but it was also very important for older people and the middle class. It helped create new rock stars who were inspired by this exciting music. **Snow**  
I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me over as I walked on the slippery ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole that was about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, and I fell through the thin layer of snow. I climbed out, feeling scared and shaken, and I wondered what would have happened if the hole had been much deeper. I sat against a pine tree that was sticking out of the snow to think about what to do next. In one hour, I had only walked half a mile. It was clear that I had to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**  
There are many books that help researchers understand qualitative research. While there is a lot of information about collecting data, many books do not explain how to analyze that data. This can be confusing for researchers. To help, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about how they analyze their data. The goal was to share their experiences and make the process clearer, not to create a guidebook. This task is not easy, so we let our contributors share their work in different ways, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Simplified Text: Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old son eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and pretending to be a dinosaur. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, but he didn’t remember much. 

Many people think that learning on a screen is good, but is it really? One writer talked about using an interactive program with his son. The father read the words while the son played with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes reading a book, he might have learned something. Research shows that learning happens best when there is talking with teachers or parents. We can use new technology to teach our children, but traditional education is still very important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world’s movie-making was in Hollywood. People living there did not like this change. They thought their quiet area was being taken over by new people. But in the end, they accepted it because success is important in America. Success is measured by how much money a film makes. 

Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one. In less than a hundred years, Hollywood has changed from a small village to a famous town, like New York or Paris. It has changed a lot; a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange trees to get to the store. But in some ways, it is still a small village, with people mostly talking about films: how much money they made, who is dating whom, and who is working on what project. Many successful people try to live somewhere else but still work in Hollywood. It is the place where many people in show business want to be.

**Photography**

Photography was created by artists in the 1800s. They wanted to make a lasting record of what they saw. The new tools they used made pictures that were clearer and more detailed than paintings. This surprised other artists. Some art critics said photography could not be art because it depended on machines. 

But photographers believed they had found a new way to express themselves. They used photography like other artists use paint and pencils to show their view of the world.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, every children's book had illustrations. This also included novels for older children, but fewer were published over time. There was a lot of activity in children's publishing, but it was often low-budget, which led to some average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. 

The collection of black-and-white illustrations is a mix of good and not-so-good work. It is a great place for research and finding interesting things. The best illustrations will be shown to the public again, either through new books or exhibitions. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and soon, a publisher will likely create a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time.

**Text: Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website talked about the risks of telling everyone where you are online. The website said that when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also telling many people about your location. Some of these people might not be the ones you want to meet. This shows that sharing a lot online can have problems.

The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a big audience. We can share our stories, photos, and feelings. But sometimes, we realize that sharing too much can be dangerous, and we can feel lost. This can be sad, but we should not give up. There are lessons from people who used the internet before us.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started sharing his life online. At that time, the internet was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall wanted to share his experiences. He created a blog where he wrote about everything in his life. In January 1996, he began posting every day, and many people started to read his blog. Hall was open about his life, and he wrote about any topic.

One day, visitors to Hall's blog found that his homepage was gone. Instead, there was a video called Dark Night. In this video, Hall explained that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, he was told to choose between his blog and his relationship. He felt that sharing his life online made people not trust him. The blog ended, but the problem of sharing online still exists.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young woman in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a colleague sent her blog link to the bosses at her company, including some she had made fun of. Because of this, she lost her job. 

Experts say this is called the "online distribution effect." This means that people often say things online that they would never say in person. But our online lives are connected to our real lives. If we forget this, we can make big mistakes.

Armstrong's story had a happy ending. After being upset and stopping her blog for a while, she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is popular among "mommy bloggers," and her writing helps her family. She learned an important lesson: the internet lets us say anything, but that doesn’t mean we should.

**Text: Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired. In rich and busy countries, not getting enough sleep and feeling anxious are common problems. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have trouble sleeping. Some popular books in Britain have characters who cannot sleep or are about sleep research. 

A sleep expert says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic. One researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they started to sleep about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep.

In Europe, a sleep research lab at a university studies how tiredness affects people. They have looked at how tired sailors are, how noise at airports affects sleep, and how tired drivers can be dangerous. They find volunteers by advertising in student newspapers. Volunteers are paid £5 an hour and follow sleep instructions.

Dr. Louise Reyner helps the volunteers feel comfortable. Some are worried because they wear electrodes on their heads. They think the researchers can see their dreams. But the researchers are more interested in how the body works. 

In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. Volunteers come at 2 PM, a time when people often feel sleepy, especially if they did not sleep well. They drive while answering questions. The road ahead looks endless, and the sun is bright. The young men say they will not fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one man trying hard to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight, but then he starts to blink more and more. Soon, he nods off, and the car goes off the road. 

Dr. Reyner says that drinking coffee can help. Two cups can make someone a safe driver for half an hour. She suggests energy drinks and chewing gum with caffeine for people who work at night. 

Scientists know that humans sleep in cycles. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. We usually dream during light sleep. Our brains stop our bodies from moving to keep us safe. 

Scientists are sure that women sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they do not know why. Some researchers say sleep helps us travel through time safely. 

In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A history professor studied British life from 1500 to 1850. He found that people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for a while, and then went back to sleep. This time was good for thinking and remembering dreams. Poor people enjoyed this quiet time away from their busy days. 

By the 17th century, with more artificial light, rich people started to sleep in a more efficient way. The industrial revolution made people work longer hours in lighted buildings. 

In some non-western cultures, people still do not have strict bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, then wake up again. The idea of sleeping all night is not the same for everyone. In some tribal societies, noises and the need to watch for danger make it hard to sleep continuously. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

**Simplified Text:**

I am talking about big cowboy boots. Really big boots. I stood in my expensive cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. I wore a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and realized I did not belong there. I flew in from Denver early in the morning. I thought I looked like a cowboy, but that feeling went away when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a dirty shirt and carrying a bag. He looked at my new cowboy boots and then walked away.

I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. I was addicted to racing cars. But now, I do not race anymore. I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have other jobs ready for when he stops racing. I thought I had some ideas, but they did not work out. I thought about being a commentator for races, but there were many other drivers who wanted that job. I also tried to sell classic cars, but that did not work either because nobody was buying them.

Being an "ex" anything is hard. Nobody wants to hear about how I almost became the World Champion. Even if I had won, people would only listen for a short time. Last year’s champion is not important anymore. I do not want sympathy, but I miss racing. I miss the feeling of driving a fast car. I could go from zero to one hundred and fifty miles per hour in just a few seconds. I also miss the excitement and the people who cared about what I said. 

Now that I do not race, I have a lot of free time. Last week, my phone rang twice, but I have so much empty time. I looked up at the blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above me. I saw some small brown birds in a cactus nearby. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that a fake cowboy in fancy boots still has a lot to learn.

2. Where did the narrator fly in from?
3. What did the narrator think about being a cowboy?

**Text: Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, residents walk around the city, and if you join them, you will probably hear different languages. People come to Vancouver for its nice weather, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, clean and safe places, and good schools and jobs. Some people may complain about how fast new buildings are being built, but the new people and tourism have helped the city grow. 

People used to call Vancouver 'Terminal City' because it was a place where many journeys began. Now, Vancouver is more of a gateway than ever.

Journalists like me are not good at writing letters. Some say this is because we do not like to write for free, but I think it is more about how we work. In our jobs, we try to make our writing very good, so we find it hard to write a simple letter. A true artist, who writes without thinking too much about the effect, does not have this problem. I believe that understanding the power of words is what makes a real artist. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he did not think about what made them great.

Opening a new supermarket used to be a big event in Britain. A famous person, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open every day, and famous people are not needed anymore. **Text: Citizen Kane**

The film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. There was a lot of excitement about it, but it was not a big success at first. People were worried about how William Randolph Hearst, who the film was about, would react. It was later shown on television that made more people notice it. Many people say this film inspired them to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film did well because he did not know what he could or could not do. He just made the film the way he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to tell the story of a newspaper owner who was like Hearst, Welles knew he had a great chance to show his skills as a director and actor.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He had told her twice that he might be late and that he might stop at the golf club on his way home. He wanted to talk to someone, and that was a good place to do it. Carmel nodded her head but seemed like she did not really hear him. "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "Funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I will walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it is almost wrong to waste the day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You should enjoy yourself. If I am late, I won’t want anything to eat, so don’t worry about it." "No, that’s fine," she replied.

"Tea boy? Do you mind? I am a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator." 

A recent study shows that job titles can cause problems at work. A survey found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees think job titles create divisions among workers. Most surprisingly, 70% of office workers said they would give up a pay rise for a better job title. This shows that people care a lot about how they are called at work. **The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually why I traveled. Taking pictures was not just my job; it was my passion. I loved how light fell on different surfaces. A single photograph could show the beauty of a place, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture. As long as I had film in my camera, I could keep trying. I had a simple rule: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for great shots.

Once, I took a picture of smoke from a burning oil well. It became very popular, and many newspapers wanted to use it. It was a lucky moment, but they say you create your own luck. After that, I decided to work freelance. I thought it was a smart choice, but life had other plans. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped. That’s why I was in Vienna instead of a more exciting place. But I was still taking photographs, and I was getting paid for it. That felt good.

My assignment in Vienna happened by chance. I had taken pictures in London for a book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*. I had a good time capturing the beauty of London in different seasons. After I finished my London photos, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna. Instead of hiring someone new, they asked me to take his place. The publishers liked my work, and I was available. I was happy to go because things were not good at home.

I stayed at the Europa hotel in the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy trip, and I didn’t take many photos. This time, I was alone in January, and I knew it would be different. When I arrived, I was excited to see the beautiful city covered in snow. I was ready to take great pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t take any photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, enjoying the city’s atmosphere. The weather was cold, but it added to the beauty of the old buildings. I wanted to create my own version of Vienna, not copy what Rudi had done. I needed to wait for the right moment to take my photos.

The next morning, I woke up early. The snow from the night before made Stephansplatz look beautiful and quiet. I wanted to capture the cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one shot. The tall spire reached into the sky, while the base was very large. I knew I would have to focus on part of it. The weather was magical, and photography has always felt magical to me. 

In the past, people were amazed by how photographs were made. You could watch a blank piece of paper turn into a picture in a dark room. Even when you understand how it works, it still feels mysterious. Maybe that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

In recent years, I have seen many contemporary art exhibitions. Some are great, and some are not so good. I often feel frustrated when exhibitions seem to push a certain idea or message. Sometimes this works, and we learn about new trends in art. But often, it feels forced or not genuine.

As a curator, I wanted to create a different kind of show. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. The exhibition was called "Window-shopping." It was a collection of individual artworks that were connected only because they were all art. 

For example, Sam Cole made knitted cats that chased each other on a toy train track. In contrast, Matthew Crawley filmed a video of him opening a camera and breaking it. These artworks do not fit into a specific theme, but they can still be shown together. They do not get in each other’s way and can actually help each other stand out.

**Art History**

Many people who enjoy paintings are afraid to think too much about them. They worry that analyzing art will ruin their enjoyment. Some art historians focus more on theory than on the experience of looking at art. This can take away the pleasure of seeing and creating art.

Understanding art does not mean we cannot enjoy it. In fact, knowing more about what we are looking at can make it more enjoyable. Our feelings about art are also influenced by the society we live in. What we like in art is not just about our personal taste but also about the values of our culture. 

While it is important to enjoy art, the idea that thinking about art takes away from enjoyment is an old belief. Art can be both enjoyable and something we think about deeply.

**Text: Metals**

Long ago, people in the Stone Age became interested in metals. While sitting by a river, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow stone. This stone was not like other stones; it was beautiful. This is how gold may have come into the lives of early humans. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it quickly became very popular. 

Copper may have also been found by chance. When people saw how useful copper tools were, they began to look for copper and ways to get it from the ground. This is how metalworking started and helped our ancestors live better lives.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is difficult because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and times of trouble are no longer here. We cannot know exactly why they moved or how they lived. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas on people from the past. 

However, we can use computer modelling to recreate old landscapes and environments. We can create virtual communities that act like real people. We can set rules and make social groups. Then, we can change things, like the amount of rain or the number of people, and see how these digital people react.

**Text: Photography**

For the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture many parts of human life. In this short time, photography has improved a lot. It helps us see moments that pass quickly and shows us both big and small things. Photography gives us images from faraway places, different parts of space, and the problems of modern life. It is an important way to express what it means to be human.

However, people have been making pictures for much longer. The first pictures were made about 35,000 years ago in caves. We are not sure why these early paintings were made. They might show real hunting events, help with hunting, be religious symbols, or just be for decoration. But pictures have always been a part of human culture.

Throughout history, people have asked how accurate pictures are and what they mean in society. Many believe that "seeing is believing," which gives pictures special importance. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a true visual record of life. The camera works like the human eye and can create fixed images that look very real.

The ability to capture images was seen as a great achievement. It was thought that everyone could understand photographs easily. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even a very isolated person could understand a photo of the sky. But as global communication grew in the late 20th century, we began to question if everyone really understands photographs the same way.

Photography is often seen as a clear way to show reality. People often show photos to say, "This is my grandson." Since photography was invented in 1839, the way people use and think about it has changed a lot. At first, photography was a way to keep records, but now it is more than that. Photos can tell us about the people and society that made them.

I want to show that the camera is not just a tool that records events. Photography can also inspire social and political change. For example, the changes in art during the Italian Renaissance were connected to new ways of seeing. Similarly, photography has played a big role in creating the media culture we have today, while also showing the difficult realities of the world.

Some people need to feel safe before they can write a poem, while others write to feel better when they are sad. **The Short Story**

In a short story, it is important not to have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used when they help the story. A memory from the main character can help move the story forward, but it should not slow it down. Dialogue, or conversations between characters, is very helpful. It can show different sides of a story quickly and keep the reader interested. A short story should have conflict and action, just like a novel, but every word must count.

**Screenplays**

The more you play, the better you understand the game. In screenplay writing, the same is true. The more you write, the more you see how to create a good story.

**Looking at Writing**

Writing is something that needs to be taught, while speaking comes naturally. We need to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it.

**POETRY RECITALS**

At any time in history, people may find the world of literature confusing. However, later on, it is easier to see the important writers and styles. Right now, there are many different types of poetry and many ways to write and share it. There are also different opinions about what a poet should do in society.

Today, there is a debate between two groups of poets. One group is made up of serious writers who want their poems to be read on the page. The other group is made up of popular poets who like to perform their poems for an audience. These two groups do not always agree. 

In the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in village halls or homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to read to students. Arts festivals also have poetry readings by famous poets. 

For popular poets, performing their work is very important. Their poems are often simple and easy to understand, so people can enjoy them right away. However, serious poets, who work hard to create deep and meaningful poetry, may not be appreciated by audiences who are hearing their work for the first time. 

The problem is that serious poets might only read their easiest poems to connect with the audience. But listening to poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry on the page. It can be fun and helpful to hear poets read their work, even if they are not great speakers. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems beforehand.

One good reason for popular poetry readings, sometimes mixed with music, is that they help people enjoy poetry. This way, audiences can see poetry as something for everyone, not just for a few special people.

**Oral History**  
Historians often use oral evidence, which means they listen to people's stories about the past. However, this can be difficult. When someone shares their memories, their feelings and the person asking questions can change the story. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to ask about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers things. The memories shared can also be influenced by other things, like what people see in the media or how they feel about their past. Sometimes, people remember things with a sense of nostalgia, thinking that the past was better than it really was. 

**Animal Science**  
There are two main ways to study animal science: the physiological approach and the whole animal approach. Physiologists study how the body works, like how nerves and muscles help animals behave. The whole animal approach looks at how animals behave in their natural environment. There are two types of researchers in this area: psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists often study a few types of animals, like rats and pigeons, in labs. Ethologists study animals in the wild and how they behave naturally. Both types of research are important, and they are starting to work together more. Understanding behavior is important, and we cannot just look at how nerve cells work; we also need to study the behavior itself.

**The Social Sciences**  
When students start studying social sciences, they have to learn two things at once. They need to understand the subject and also learn how to study it. This means they must know the facts and research, as well as the methods used to gather this information. Social sciences are about people and society, but they go beyond what we think is common sense. Each social science looks at different parts of social life and uses its own methods and ideas. These ideas help researchers understand society better and make each discipline unique.

**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. The Roman architect Vitruvius said that architecture includes order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He did not mention utility or function at first, but he later talked about how to design buildings for different purposes. The beginnings of classical architecture are complex. Before classical times, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. However, these simple structures were important and influenced later architectural designs. In essence, a classical temple is like a simple hut.
