**THE WELL**

I read somewhere that if you dig a deep enough hole, you can see the stars when it is clear. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket off the wall. I fell into the well. I hit my head. At first, I saw strange lights. Later, I remembered how cartoon characters see stars when they get hit on the head. At that moment, I felt confused, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. 

You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran away to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge. I landed on the courtyard stones. I heard loud voices from the castle door. I ran away to hide in the shadows by the moat bridge. 

Mother and Father came with you and old Arthur. Mother was screaming and waving her hands. Father shouted for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows, feeling excited. Then I saw the drops of water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. At my feet, the water had made a small pool. I looked back into the courtyard, where Father was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. Mother was screaming loudly now, a sound I had never heard before. It scared me. 

What should I do? I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. It went from a fun idea to something that could get me in big trouble. I was angry with myself for not thinking this through. I needed a plan. I gathered my courage and came out of hiding, staggering and blinking. I called out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit and then fell on the stones. 

Sitting up, I felt comforted in my mother’s arms. I said, “Phew” and “Oh dear,” and smiled bravely. I told them I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat, and I crawled and swam until I got out. I thought I was almost getting away with it until Father came to me. He asked me to repeat my story. I did, but I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. I said the secret passage had fallen in after me, and it was too dangerous to look for it. I said I had barely escaped with my life. 

When I looked into my father’s eyes, it felt like looking into a dark tunnel. It was as if he was seeing me for the first time. My words got stuck in my throat. “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” he said, sounding very disappointed. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked at me with a sad expression, shaking his head. He could see through my lie and worried about me. His pity hurt me more than my father’s words. It made me realize how serious my actions were.

The piano is in the best room of the house. They will move it last. Sitting on the stairs, Susan remembers the day they moved in. The piano was the first thing they brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers worked hard for two hours to get it inside. Robert watched with excitement, while Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" 

Peter, Susan's late husband, helped solve the problem. They left the piano outside while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder took out a window, and they used a crane to lift the piano inside. The children were so happy to see it. It cost a lot of money, and they could not afford to tune it for months.

Now, the children are busy and do not come home often. Susan finds it hard to move around the house. She thinks about the stairs and remembers that the banister was not fixed perfectly. She should have told the movers about it, but it is too late now. 

Fred asks if she is okay. He tells her that the piano is the last thing to move. Susan feels nervous. Robert and Francesca come to watch. Fred talks to her, and she feels like crying. Moving her things makes her feel sad. 

Just then, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is in front, and another mover is behind. They carefully bring it outside. Robert laughs first, and soon they are all laughing together, happy that it is over. As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan only sheds tears of laughter.

**Text: Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

**Do-it-yourself literary criticism: Is it just fun?**

From the beginning, one important idea of the Internet was that everyone could share their thoughts. In theory, anyone could publish their ideas or create a music channel online. But in the early years, you needed some technical skills to do this. 

One area that opened up to many people was book reviews. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could write a book review. Amazon allowed anyone to share their opinion about a book and give it a rating of up to five stars. This was a great idea because it let readers see what others thought about a book, not just what the publisher said or what professional critics wrote.

Amazon had many customers and received a lot of reviews. However, this also led to some problems. Many reviews were submitted every day, and it was hard for Amazon to check them all. A team of editors looked at the reviews to make sure they followed the rules. For example, one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors were not allowed. Reviews that gave away the ending or used bad language were also not accepted. But since reviewers could remain anonymous, some people wrote fake reviews. 

For instance, a writer named Lev Grossman was upset by the bad reviews of his first book. To fix this, he wrote some good reviews under a fake name. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed the fake reviews. 

Authors could also comment on their own books by clicking a link. Most authors wrote friendly messages asking readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for readers to contact them. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments were really from the authors, except for famous writers.

The real excitement came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it received good reviews from the press. But some people mentioned in the book were angry and wrote many negative reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days. Despite this, Amazon thought it was good that so many people were writing reviews.

Amazon wanted to keep the reviews focused on the books, so they paid special attention to popular books. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to be found on pages for less-known books. For example, a classic children's book called The Story about Ping inspired funny reviews because "ping" is also a computer term. One long review compared the book's story to how the Internet works.

Most reviews on Amazon were serious, and they helped other readers decide if a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books was hard because you had to pretend to feel something about books you didn’t care about. This is why making it easy for everyone to write reviews is a good thing.

**Family Business**

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car on the way back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the nice girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received a Latin prize and a prize for doing well in my exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, but I already knew what he was thinking because he was quiet. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I replied, trying to act brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also heard," he continued, and I knew he was going to confront me, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law. "I just said that," I explained. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can understand a lot of information quickly, you are good at talking, and you like performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."

"Be that as it may," he said, trying to stay calm, "I feel like your heart is not in the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."

The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by what my family expected. I saw many jobs I could do, and I wanted to explore them. But I also didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was his favorite - but I still found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about these things. "It's a pity because you have the skills - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.

"Anyway," I added, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I took care of him because he didn't have a mother. I loved Maurice, and because the business was successful, we lived well - in a big house in London, went to nice schools, wore good clothes, and enjoyed parties and shows. My father knew many interesting people, and our house was always lively.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me."

"OK," I said, happy to avoid making choices right now, especially since my father would be upset if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us.

So, it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, but only a couple of times a year and always with easier tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris for my final exams.

In my last term, my father came to see me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor said I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew if I focused, he might be right. I felt ready and confident. But then my father told me that he needed me to do one last important job for the family business, and it would be worth my time.

"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell my father didn't understand how much pressure I was under, and he would see my refusal as a betrayal. As he explained the job, I saw how determined he was, how clear and resourceful he was in his work. He was a kind of genius, and I respected that in him. It made my own plans seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

**Simplified Text:**

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be alone. I believed that people here would not care if the houses looked old and broken. I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you, even if you don’t know them. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens used to be loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about summer, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have cut back some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. It is a small garden in London, where plants have to grow tall to survive.

“Been doing some cleaning, I see,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz. She leans out of her window. Jaz is a writer, and I sometimes help her with her work because I am an English teacher. I have her latest story with me now. “How’s the work going, Jaz?” I ask. “Oh, in no other job do people ask you about your work so many times a day,” she replies. Then she says, “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I see that it looks messy. Jaz knocks on my door. “So, you’re on holiday now, lucky you.” She sits in the chair while I put a cushion on the ground where there used to be grass. “Cheers,” she says, thinking she is young. “I should have become a teacher – writers don’t have holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do, and those who can’t, teach.” 

“What are your plans for the holidays?” she asks. I feel worried about the empty days ahead. “Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” I ask. My heart races as I speak. “Of course I will,” Jaz says, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A nice bed and breakfast?” she asks. “No, I’ll stay with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were eight.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with stories. 

“Going back to your roots. What do you think of my story?” Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I have not read much of. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses. I decide to be honest. “Let me give you a little tip,” I say. “What?” she asks, surprised. “Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good.” “Teachers!” Jaz says, acting like a schoolgirl who doesn’t want to listen. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,” I say. My words sound a bit silly. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. 

When we go inside, my calm kitchen makes me feel better. Then I suddenly remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now. She used to wink at us and say, “I’ve had my moments.” We almost laughed.

**Heritage**

Heritage means the connection people have with their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage because we know about our grandparents and have heard stories about their lives. It is important to learn about our past to understand our future. Heritage helps us feel secure about where we come from and gives us a place in history. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. There may be parts of our national heritage that we do not like, but it is still a part of us, and it feels good to belong to something. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our well-being. It influences our customs and culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. However, in modern society, many of these stories have been lost. Now, we can learn about our past through places and buildings. It is very important to protect these links to honor our ancestors.

**The Fens**

Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*. I did not know then that the Fens, a part of England, would be very important in my story. People often ask me why I, a person from London, chose to write about a place I do not know well. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, a good setting for my book. But I learned that the Fens are not flat or empty. They are very English but also strange and different. It is surprising that there is a place in the middle of England that many people find unusual, especially since many other areas of Britain have become part of the country's culture. The Fens are both empty and full, both farmed and wild, and they seem open but are also mysterious. I have not visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow, but as a writer, I enjoy creating imagined worlds. I prefer to guess about the Fens rather than find proof. This way of imagining the Fens is special because, as shown in Edward Storey's book, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a way of thinking.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to read. Now, museums should do more than this. They can create interesting displays that catch visitors' attention and make them feel something. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide boxes of objects for teachers to use in classrooms, and some museums now offer similar materials for elderly people who are losing their memory. Museums focus on real items from history, not copies. They help people connect with authentic objects that had meaning in the past. This is what makes museums special and different from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CDs. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will find that their competition in "virtual history" can actually help them by making people want to see real history.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to keep things safe is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly and affect many people. This can make some people want to preserve everything and encourage others to think more about our towns and their future. People who have lived through big events, like world wars, may want to preserve things more than others because stability is important to them. If there is a need to preserve, planners should consider it. Change is not bad if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in society, such as our population, welfare, and needs.

**Text: Einstein**

If you stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used to sell many products, like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some famous theories called 'relativity'. These theories are known for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that do not match our everyday experiences.

Einstein was part of a big change in science. Scientists were trying to understand the universe better by studying how matter and natural forces work together. Einstein made important contributions by looking at basic ideas: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people followed Isaac Newton's ideas, which said that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but can change.

**Young Readers**

When we were children, Lydia and I did not trust any book that won a prize because we thought it would be boring. Our mother did not like this and often showed her disapproval. But our father would give us small coins for each chapter we read to encourage us to read better books. He would also give us some special books as gifts, marked with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. We thought many of his books were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and even a famous book of poems.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851, "The origin of human language is a secret and wonderful thing." This secret has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller said that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans who lived in dangerous places made desperate sounds, and some words today still remind us of their fears, like "malaria," which means "fever," and the Latin word "mors," which means "death."

Many people avoided talking about how language started because they thought it was silly. But now, studying the origin and evolution of language is very important. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech for friendly communication, and it was also important in struggles for power. Sharing information was probably not the main reason for language at first, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said, who thought language was mainly for sharing knowledge.

**Text: Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have deadlines and strict rules about how long they can be. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a short time – maybe a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Some believe that people only write reviews because they need money. Others think it is because they cannot spend all their time on a book or a serious project.

However, writing reviews is a skilled job. It is different to write a short review of 600 to 800 words for a newspaper than to write a longer review of 6,000 to 8,000 words for a journal. A review in a weekly magazine is usually about 1,500 words and has challenges from both short and long reviews. 

A reviewer must think about who will read their work. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want a detailed review. Reviewers also need to know a lot about different topics and write in a way that is easy for smart people to understand and enjoy. Most reviewers also write other things besides reviews.

The American writer John Updike does not think much of criticism, but he still writes reviews between writing his novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with humble titles. Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long, but they also want their work to be remembered, especially if they think some of their best writing is in those reviews.

I feel this way about my own writing. I mostly write academic books, which are the kind of work professors are expected to do. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write both reviews and academic studies. The time when other academics criticized professors for writing reviews is over. Now, there are many reviews, and almost everyone can write one. This is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them stay connected to the public. 

Professors need to remember to write in a way that non-professors can understand. When they talk to each other, they might use complicated language, but they should communicate clearly with others. In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a secondary job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Text: 

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment. When he entered the dark hall, he felt a quick feeling of ownership. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes came back when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened while he was away. The flat felt like a welcome place for him, a space where he could be himself. 

He thought he should worry about intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to wait for him, looking either clean or messy, depending on how he had left it. Over time, he began to see it as a part of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings overflowed. He became frustrated that it could not change. 

There were always some letters by the door and the answering machine would sometimes blink when he got home. He was thankful that his windows were not broken and that nothing had been stolen. He often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home after a long day at his office. 

On the bus ride home, he felt more like himself again and did not want to be alone anymore. At his desk, he wanted to be alone with his things, but when he got home, he felt empty. He suspected that his job, which he did not like, was changing him and taking him away from who he really was. 

He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. His thoughts became unclear, and he felt lost. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and believed he could change his life. But he had been so eager to find something that he followed the first opportunity that came his way. 

After university, he tried to make a plan for a better life, but he only wanted to survive. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, following them as they moved forward. He went to one job interview and did not think much about the job itself. He was happy to have a nice conversation with Neil, his boss, and did not think about the long meetings that would follow. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who had applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

Even though everyone was going to the racecourse, I pushed my way through the crowds to find a good spot. An area was blocked off to make a course for the goats. It was not like a big racecourse, but people were standing on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few special goats in order. This was not easy because goats are known to eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I started to think about the night, and I felt scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, there was nowhere to stop, and we had not seen any villages or huts since early morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our flashlight to see the cliffs. The flashlight batteries were low, so we changed them, but the new ones did not work. We could not find a place to camp. A little later, Lesley said she saw a distant light, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we could not see what was happening. Time seemed to stop, and we kept moving.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**

I am not good at making presentations, but as the managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and to important shareholders. How can I get better at presenting and feel more confident? You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many leaders need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask your colleagues what tough questions the audience might ask. You also need to create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and then move towards your main point.

**Simplified Text:**

Some activities cannot be rushed. They take the time they need. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will not turn out right. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some things can be done faster, like solving puzzles or doing math. But other things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they may not work, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.

Sometimes, we need to think quickly, but this can be a bad idea. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. There are three main speeds of thinking. The first is faster than normal thought. Some situations need a quick reaction. For example, if my motorbike skids on a wet road, my body knows what to do right away. This quick thinking is called our "wits."

The second speed is normal thinking. This is when we figure things out, weigh options, and solve problems. A mechanic fixing a car or a student working on homework uses this kind of thinking. We often call this "intellect." People who are good at this are called "clever."

The third speed is slower and more relaxed. This is when we think about things in a more dreamy or playful way. For example, when we sit by the sea and listen to the waves, we are in a different mental state than when we are planning something. This slow thinking is just as important as fast thinking. We need time to think slowly, especially when life gets busy.

Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Recent studies show that slow thinking helps us understand complicated situations. Fast thinking works well for simple problems. But when we are unsure about what to do, we need to take our time. For example, if we are trying to manage a difficult group at work, it may be better to think carefully rather than rush for answers.

This slow thinking is connected to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have always understood that slow thinking has its own value. Scientists are now studying these slower ways of thinking. They find that the unconscious mind can do many important tasks if given enough time. It can learn patterns that our normal thinking cannot see and solve complex problems better than quick thinking.

2. What are the three speeds of thinking mentioned in the text?
3. Why is slow thinking important?
4. How can slow thinking help with difficult problems?
5. What do poets and philosophers understand about slow thinking?

**Text: Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been welcomed warmly. It is a friendly place in a very isolated area. There are about forty people here - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers. We all work together as a close community. My school French is just enough to communicate, but not enough to have fun conversations. I miss the small details in the language, and my phrasebook does not help me at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt unsure of myself. I was a little scared of mealtimes. I would wait and worry about which table to choose. I felt nervous when I spoke, and I felt anxious like I did in the first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or feel scared when people talk to me. I think this feeling is not about missing people or communication, but because I have lost the confidence I used to have when I could talk easily.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was a young author, and he did not notice me. He remembered faces, and when I saw him, he would shake my hand politely, but he did not want to be friends. If I saw him at the opera with an important person, he would not see me. But then I became a successful playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to be friendlier. One day, he sent me a note asking me to lunch. I thought he was testing me. After that, I had many new friends, and I began to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock said he did not care about the story of his films or the acting. He cared about the pictures and the music. For Hitchcock, it was not the message or the acting that moved the audience. He believed that people react to the film itself, no matter where they come from. So, if a film is made well, the audience in Japan should scream at the same time as the audience in India. Hitchcock was very clear and logical about his work. He was a genius who liked to hear the audience scream. He did not think about deep ideas or complex meanings. He focused on the film and how it could affect the audience.

**Text: Amateur Astronomy**

Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. Until about 30 years ago, there were not many charts and catalogues. Telescopes were not very good, and there were few books about practical astronomy. Today, there are many types of telescopes and equipment available. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. 

However, some things have also been lost. Now, you may have to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, which was easier to find in cities 50 years ago. During the day, the sky is often filled with airplane trails that can last for hours and make it hard to see the sun and stars at night.

New products come out all the time, and it can be overwhelming. More choices can lead to more stress and less time. Because of this, many people are looking for "simplexity" - simple things that make life meaningful in a complicated world. But it is not easy to simplify life when there are so many options. There are more brands of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and many software updates and plans to choose from.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it is very important to us. Nothing can change this tradition. The guests at McAndrews are old-fashioned and maybe a little snobbish. I do not like the bad manners of shop assistants today. I do not enjoy the friendly behavior of waiters who seem to want to be too familiar. 

I know the names of many guests because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. When I see them in the hotel, we only say a polite hello. This respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels today.

I said that Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello, and I was wrong about his acting. I still believe that Othello and Desdemona should have a bigger age difference, but I take back my words about Mr. Fearon's amazing performance. The whole cast is wonderful.

**Lake Vostok**

In Antarctica, there is very little life. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But in the middle, on the big white plateau, there is no life. However, there is a large hidden lake called Lake Vostok under almost 4 kilometers of ice. This lake is under the coldest place on earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore this lake and find out what strange life might be there. 

For two years, researchers from around the world have been trying to learn the secrets of the lake. If they succeed, we will see many discoveries about Lake Vostok in the next few years.

**Scientists**

Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. We all know that they want to learn about everything, from tiny atoms to big black holes. But these scientists want to understand why we want to know these things and why science cannot explain this desire. 

I believe it is more important to know if what scientists do is right, rather than argue about why we want to know. The key point is that science is a tool, and we should decide how, when, and why to use it.

The problem is that computers do not help people read everything from start to finish.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office and saw everything was neat. The carpet was clean, and the desk was dark wood, just like he remembered. Files were in their right places, and twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves. Kathleen was trying to close a filing cabinet and then looked at him. "You have to use computers, Charles. This is too much," she said. 

"Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he replied, admiring the room. He did not want to think about computers. They had talked about this many times. She did not understand why he did not want to use technology, even though he was good with computers and had written an important paper about them. She could use any software and make it do new things.

Text: "You don’t take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She was not really asking; she was stating a fact because she had been making coffee for Lancelot for many months. She forgot sometimes because he was not usually supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that if he stayed away, things would get very busy. 

He thought about how he had changed from a valued helper, meeting authors and playwrights for lunch, to someone who was always rushing to fix problems and had nowhere to park when he got to work. 

"This came," she yelled, waving a folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Under that, it said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one, even if it was changed. 

Ian Cuthbert had received a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was one of Lancelot's old friends, and he was a good example of how some people do not change their behavior, even when they should. Lancelot skipped the introduction he had read many times and looked at the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. It was clear that Ian's manuscript would not be ready soon. 

The synopsis was not as brilliant as people said Ian was. It had a cheerful tone, but it felt empty. Lancelot remembered a famous author who had published an incomplete book after he died. That author had been paid little by little for each chapter. But Ian had received a lot of money upfront, which was not how things usually worked. 

Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising talent in Cambridge. Ian's friends wanted to take over British theater, and they did. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he had met them. For some reason, Ian's creative talent stayed hidden. While others became successful, Ian stayed away from the spotlight. 

At the height of his influence, Ian was hard to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine about the arts, but it never got published. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but he still did not produce much. At meetings, he was sarcastic and critical of others' ideas. Ten years later, he could hardly be counted on to show up for anything. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" had been a mistake from the beginning.

**Text: England's Breakfast Revolution**

A good breakfast is very important, according to health experts. However, breakfast is a new idea in England. In medieval times, people did not often write about breakfast. Some travelers ate a meal at dawn before long journeys, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.

In the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. Some writers say this happened because food was easier to get. But there were also big changes in society. For example, more people had jobs with set hours. Many of these jobs started very early in the morning. So, eating breakfast became necessary for everyone, not just for rich people.

**Text: Photography and Sport**

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences. They also think about social and cultural ideas. In this book, we will see how these things affect the style and meaning of a photograph. We will also look at how people see and react to these images. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they usually understand the photos without thinking too much. But we can ask if the photo really shows what happened at that time. Does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment important, or does the photo represent something bigger in the world?

**Sport**  
For me, sport is more than just a game. The best athletes believe in themselves completely. To be the best, you need to focus and put everything else aside. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. You either succeed or fail. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but it also shows the importance of teamwork. My sport lets me shine as an individual, but it is also a team game, and I must balance both. It is like life – you can do well alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened doors for me and shown me things in the world that many people will never see. But you also have to give up a lot to get these rewards.

**A Special Memory**  
Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I was not awake because of insomnia; I was awake because the bird's beautiful song kept me up. As I listened to its melodies, I felt like I was in a special musical world. To understand the bird's song, I thought about my experiences with jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an amazing live performance. I cheered and groaned as the bird sang different tunes through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

**Simplified Text:**

People have always had strong feelings about birds. Some love them, some fear them, and some even worship them. But what does this say about us? 

In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Is it trying to tell us something, or is it just lost? Depending on how you see it, both ideas could be true. 

Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, we still see images of wrens in homes across Britain. Even if old beliefs about them are not as strong now, people still care about wrens. A place without wrens feels sad. 

This connection to birds comes from a time when people relied on nature for survival. They learned to understand the importance of different animals. Over time, ideas about birds have changed. 

For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a helpful bird in London, taking food from children. But later, people thought of them as pests, and they almost disappeared. Now, red kites are protected again and are important for conservation efforts in Britain. 

Our interest in birds goes back to early humans. They watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about who we are. Birds can fly, sing, and seem free, which makes us admire them. 

Some people think our feelings for birds are old and not important now. But these feelings are still part of us, and losing them would be hard. That is why birds are now seen as signs of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger, which is sad because it means losing not just birds but also part of our culture. 

Certain birds, like the skylark and turtle dove, represent love and magic in stories and poems. Losing these birds makes us feel sad, but we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not in stories. 

Folklore, which includes stories and legends about birds, is very important. These stories connect us to birds in a way that scientific facts do not. They help us feel emotions that are often hidden in our busy lives. 

Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel cannot be fully explained by science. Birds are fascinating in ways we do not always understand. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a long history, and its song makes us think about the future.

**Text: Maps**

A map shows the locations of places and features on the earth. It helps us understand how far things are from each other and in which direction to go. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like saying "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring was more about how easy it was to travel than the actual distance.

Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for trains, do not always show true directions.

In the past, important landmarks were shown on maps with signs that varied in size to show how important they were. Different maps used different styles based on their purpose and location. To understand old maps, it is important to know the style used.

The history of making maps, called cartography, shows how we have become better at measuring distance and direction. Over time, people used science to help make maps. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, they started using a compass. They also learned that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve maps.

As time went on, more people started using maps, not just travelers and merchants. Soldiers needed accurate maps for battles, especially after new weapons were invented. This led to the creation of contour maps, which show the shape of the land. Other people, like archaeologists and historians, also needed maps for their work.

Today, mapmakers create maps for many different uses, like showing land use or climate. The importance of maps in many fields has led to a new interest in cartography. 

It is important to remember that the development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of quick change. Sometimes, old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Mapmakers often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Because it is easy to copy old maps, some map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas. 

Therefore, we should not always trust maps as the best evidence of what we know today. The many maps we have now are the result of a lot of hard work and thought. They are valuable records for studying human history, which makes learning about old maps very interesting.

**Simplified Text:**

I met a young man named Andrew Lloyd Webber in his nice room. It was much better than the messy rooms where his family lived. Andrew had a lot of records, the first stereo record player I had ever seen, and even expensive wine glasses. He was a student at Magdalen College, Oxford, studying history. He wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams; I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like money and fame. 

When Andrew asked me to try to be a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I agreed. He played me some of his music, and I could tell he was very talented. He needed someone to write lyrics for his songs. I didn’t have much to show him, except for a song I had written that a small band recorded. We promised to meet again and write something together. 

I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I knew Andrew was special. I thought it would be exciting to work with him. The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, I felt less sure about my future in music. I thought I would probably become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five, as my father expected. This worried me because I wanted to enjoy pop music for longer. 

I decided to see Andrew again. He was interesting and talked about food and architecture. He had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man who helped orphans. I thought the story was good but not very exciting. However, Andrew believed in his music, and I wanted to help him. 

I started to write funny songs for the musical. Andrew told me the story and played the music. I even skipped work one day to write lyrics. I didn’t know it then, but I was starting a new career.

**Text:**

**Language**  
You and I are part of a special group of living things. We can share our thoughts and feelings with each other using language. Language is very important in our lives, and it is hard to think of life without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably be talking. When people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as a natural skill. This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders do not learn to make webs from someone else; they just know how to do it.

**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather are made by the air around us, and they greatly affect animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which have many different kinds of plants and animals. In cold and windy places, there are only a few living things. The daily weather changes that create the climate happen because of big air movements. The air is always moving because the Earth spins. The sun also causes a lot of this air movement.

**Coffee**  
As a barista, my job was to serve drinks, but I also had to make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had several days of training to learn how to make coffee and clean the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino. By the end of the week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might have to do simpler tasks again. Luckily, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Text: Art on TV**

Why does television often have problems with programs about art? Painting and sculpture are good subjects for TV because the camera can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 

A good example of this is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on famous artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as a dealer in metals and became known as a speculator. The metals market has fewer rules than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market economy. 

However, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found that the opposite is true. More minerals are being taken from the ground, and the prices of raw materials are going down. If we consider inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to explore on your own. 

Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm waters are also great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

**Text: Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**

You can build your own bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by two engineers, James Marr and Ian McMillan. You will get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and have a fun weekend building your bike.

It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can build a bamboo bike. I went to see what was happening. There is a lot of energy and fun in the workshop. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Companies like Calfee Design and Bamboo Bikes have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. But many cyclists find bamboo bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost about $2,995 or £1,868.

James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes that everyone could afford. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a business. They wanted to share the joy of making something special and sustainable. Now, the Bamboo Bike Club is more about community than business. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price.

On the first day of the course, James and Ian teach how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. They help you glue the bamboo tubes together to make the bike frame. They also use metal tubes for parts that need to be strong, like the handlebars and wheel forks. This can be hard for someone who is not good at DIY. But James and Ian are there to help. They check every cut and joint to make sure everything is right. If you make a mistake, it’s okay. You can just try again with a new piece of bamboo.

On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are as strong as metal bikes. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months.

The bamboo bikes may not look as perfect as metal bikes, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that these bikes are meant for a relaxed ride, not for racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride. When I tried James's bike, it felt light and smooth, even on bumpy roads. James says the best part is riding the bike. The bamboo bikes are fun to ride and cost less than £500.

**Simplified Text:**

**Self-help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I knew it would be a bestseller," she says, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Diane has her own company. Dr. Gray's small book helps men and women communicate better. This book is very popular and is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry tries to help people improve their lives, but it also creates many new problems. In Britain, people see that many self-help books are not very good, but many are published anyway. For every self-help book that is published, many others are not accepted because they are too similar or too specific. Editors are looking for the next big hit, and they care more about how well a book can sell than how well it is written. Diane says, "If someone has a catchy title, that is a big part of the success."

**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth will be told. However, this agreement is often not kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important. Sometimes, writers think that telling a story in a different way can show the truth better than just telling the facts. They may call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This can happen without any bad intentions.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
People who study detective stories say that this type of story shows the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In a detective story, a crime represents a human desire, like greed. Solving the crime helps society return to normal. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other and are connected in a strange way. The detective is part of both the law and the crime world. Sometimes, he feels guilty about this connection, and sometimes it makes him more determined to catch the criminal.

**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. He said that writing in a fancy place like this is hard. He believes that only scientists can write well about science because they understand it best. He says, "Never write down to the reader." You can make the language easier, but you must keep the main ideas clear. If readers feel that you are talking down to them, they will not enjoy your writing.

**Text: Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers, it is very cold inside. To handle the hot summer, the gym uses a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, when it is quiet, the gym feels like it is in the Arctic. This shows how people often use air-conditioning too much. It is now a common part of work and fun, showing how we can control the temperature. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use sunlight and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas are simple but can really help and would reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, more people are interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches became better, sundials were seen as just garden decorations. Now, people are looking at them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show. There, serious-looking older women showed how to paint flowers on a teacup with careful brushstrokes. It was amazing to watch because each stroke made a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for many years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? But when I went to the class, it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

**Text: The Wrong Country**

Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, in a hotel called Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that other people in the group were students from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there must have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks on the flight.

When they landed, a woman with glasses told them to stay together. The brochure did not say anything about an overnight stop, but when they arrived, Keith realized that was what it was. It was close to midnight, and they were tired, so they did not question the beds they were given. But the next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay in the hotel for their whole holiday, and they became worried.

"We have the lake and the water birds," the receptionist said with a smile. "You can take a boat to Interlaken." 

Keith told the man, "There has been a mistake. We were meant to be in Venice, in the Pensione Concordia." 

"I do not know that hotel. This is Switzerland," the receptionist replied. 

"A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane," Keith insisted. 

"Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you have changed your minds..." 

"We haven't changed our minds. There has been a mistake," Keith said firmly. 

The receptionist shook his head. He did not know about any mistake. Dawne then said, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. 

"Is there a problem?" a woman said, smiling at Keith. She was the same woman he had seen at Gatwick. 

"My name is Franks," she said. "I am married to the man with the bad leg." 

"Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks?" Dawne asked. "We are in the wrong hotel." 

Mrs. Franks smiled and gave the name of the travel agency again. Keith interrupted, "We got into the wrong group. We told the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it to her." 

"We should have known when they weren't from Dover," Dawne added. "We heard them talking about Darlington." 

Keith was annoyed and wanted Dawne to stop talking. "We noticed you at Gatwick," he said. "We knew you were in charge." 

"I counted you, but you did not see me," Mrs. Franks said. "Let me explain. Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends clients to many places. There are different holidays at different prices." 

"All tickets and labels look the same, yellow with two red bands," she continued. "If you followed other people with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up anywhere!" 

"But we are not meant to be in Switzerland," Keith insisted. 

"Let’s see," Mrs. Franks said and then walked away, leaving them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. 

"She seems nice," Dawne whispered. Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and then getting on the plane. 

"Nice to have some young people along," an old man said. He and his wife looked very old. They said they had the best sleep because of the lakeside air. 

"That’s nice," Dawne said. Keith walked out of the hotel, and Dawne followed him. They did not say anything about the funny situation they were in. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they had ended up on a tour with older people when they wanted to escape from them. Uncle had said this when they tried to get him to come with them.

**Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**

American business leaders are looking to the explorer Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.

Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, people are just starting to learn about him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," but this is not completely true. Now, Americans are very interested in him. Many books and stories about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being made. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is also in the works.

Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They tell stories about his actions and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even use the phrase "speaking Shackleton" to describe their conversations. Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a model for modern management.

Jim MacGregor, a partner at a New York firm, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His firm focuses on communication during business changes and crises. For example, they help when a factory has an accident or when many workers must be let go. MacGregor believes that even if a company handles a crisis well, it can still hurt itself by communicating poorly. He says, "Shackleton is a model for management because he was a great leader and communicator. He knew what was important, especially when lives were at stake."

One important decision Shackleton made was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his commitment to his men’s safety. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge. His 1914 expedition became famous. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." 

From the diaries of that time, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. MacGregor says, "Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and willing to change plans if needed." 

Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, strength, and patience. MacGregor adds, "One of the hardest things to do in tough times is to wait, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. If you invest money and make a mistake, it is better to wait and get your money back than to sell and lose a lot. Also, don’t be afraid to change your plans if they are not working."

Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley did not wear them. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing something similar with a biscuit when they were very hungry on an earlier expedition. He said he would leave the biscuit in the snow because it was so valuable.

As Caroline Alexander, the author of *Endurance*, says: "People want to hear stories of heroism. Shackleton shows that there is not much heroism today. He stands out as a true example of the ideals we long for."

**Simplified Text: 'Finding Food in Madagascar'**

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is a primate, and it has a way of finding food that is similar to a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.

Scientists have studied how aye-ayes find insects. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might be.

Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with holes. Some holes had food inside, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food. They did not need to see the holes to find the mealworms. They might have used their sense of smell or sound, but tests showed they did not need these either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked or when the mealworms were quiet.

Dr. Erickson found that the aye-ayes could feel the empty spaces in the wood. When they look for food, they tap the wood with their long finger and listen carefully. They might be using a method called echo-location, which means they listen for sounds that bounce back to them. They can also hear insects moving inside the wood.

Some people think that the aye-aye acts like a woodpecker in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the aye-aye is not the only one doing this job.

The aye-aye is interesting because it has features of both woodpeckers and bats. It also acts like a squirrel. Its teeth keep growing like a squirrel's teeth, and it has been seen in the wild opening nuts and eating the inside with its long finger.

**Text: 'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'**

Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? We might have some old diaries or family stories, but they often do not tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We want to write things down, but we often forget to do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but videos are not the same as real life.

Hannah Renier has a solution. She writes life stories for other people. She makes a book that has at least 20,000 words and can have pictures too. She focuses on ordinary people, not famous ones. The idea started when she talked to her family and saw that many stories from the past were being lost. 

"When I began, I did not take it very seriously," she says. "But after meeting people who have interesting lives, I changed my mind. Many people say they do it for their children or for future generations, but they also enjoy it themselves."

People feel safe to share their stories with her. A 62-year-old man said, "I was honest. I talked about my divorce, and it still hurts." He wrote his story for his family, but he has not let his children read it yet. He thinks some details might hurt them. He wants them to read it only after he is gone.

Hannah has noticed that many people are affected by their childhood. "Many people repeat the same mistakes they made when they were young," she says. "They often marry people their parents liked or choose partners to rebel against their parents." 

Many people still feel sad about things that happened with their parents many years ago. They try to impress parents who were never happy with them. Some people even want to say, "I can't stand my mother."

Hannah listens to people without judging them. "I am not here to be nosy," she says. "Sometimes people tell me things and then wonder if I should write them down. I usually do, and they can change it later if they want." Most people want to be honest about their lives.

Hannah's work is not about showing off. She believes that life is moving quickly, and we are forgetting our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their family history. 

Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these talks to write the life story, changing the order of events if needed. She can create everything for the book except the binding, which has gold lettering. People can choose the color and title of their book. 

The final product is well-organized and looks good. Each book costs nearly £3,000, and extra copies cost £25 each. Hannah gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from buying. "I thought more people would want this service," she says. "But the people I have worked with are often wealthy and like to read certain magazines."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces in total. It is important to know that none of the sculptures are real. All the sculptures are copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The Museum is in a special building with good natural light. The plaster copies have many benefits: sculptures that were once together but are now in different museums can be seen together again. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We often have courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels. Our popular Beginner's Course is for new photographers, and we also have shorter courses and Master Classes with special photographers. Members can use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (ages 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members scheme, led by our photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and have many photography materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection has nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original cabinets from the early 1700s. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and helped to grow the collection. The collection is organized by geological age, showing how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems. There are labels to explain what they are and how they are used today.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
There are over 400,000 air photographs in this collection, taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. The photographs are interesting because they show the landscape and how it has changed from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can buy copies. These copies are made to order and usually take about a month.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest and most unique tourist attractions in the world. Visitors can have fun making wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes resin copies, called facsimiles, to protect the originals and make brass rubbing easy for everyone. The brass plates were used as memorials and spread from Germany to other parts of medieval Europe. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**Text: From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have been lucky to have 35 years with small children, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This brings us close, especially now that they are older and I am more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have slapped my children when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the best father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am here if they need me, but I do not want to make them feel guilty if they do not call me. My parents did that to me, and I would never do that to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, only about 25 years old. I found the responsibilities hard at first, but they also kept me young. As they became teenagers, they showed me new things like music and fashion. This helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. But now, I can take them on holidays to nice places like the south of France. They get along well with my friends and come to parties and events with me, which is nice.

**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I started my political career. My wife and I promised to spend time with our children, but as I became more involved in politics, it became harder to find time. I only accept weekend meetings if my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their kids to work. Maybe we all want to include our children in our lives more.

**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about being a father. I tried hard to stay close to my children. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think that confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate said we were too relaxed as parents. I think I should have had more rules. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as my youngest.

**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but when I see her smile, all my irritation goes away. A baby's smile is the best way to make you feel better.
