**Text: 'Flying in Weightlessness'**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked like a normal aircraft from the outside. The pilot told the students that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135, which is based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and lights on the padded walls. Most of the seats were taken out, except for a few at the back where the 13 students from Europe and America sat. They had worked hard for 12 months to win a place on this special flight. 

The European Space Agency gave them a challenge to create interesting experiments to do in weightlessness. The students with the best ideas got to go on this amazing flight, which felt like a big roller-coaster ride. For the next two hours, the plane would go up and down, creating moments of weightlessness. 

When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the plane went higher for a moment before falling back down. During the few seconds of weightlessness, the students felt like they were floating. The plane took off smoothly, but everything changed when the pilot made the plane climb steeply. The engines roared, and the students felt the pressure in their heads. Then, the engines stopped, and they experienced weightlessness. 

For 20 seconds, they floated in the air, feeling like they were on a trampoline. They could not tell which way was up or down. After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane back up. Gravity returned, and some students landed hard on the floor. 

They had 30 curves to complete, giving them 10 minutes of weightlessness for their experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released their device, and one student managed to turn it over. 

A German team studied how metal joins are affected by weightlessness, which is important for building future space stations. Another team from Utah State University worked on making solar sails from thin films in microgravity. They believe these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind. 

After two hours of flying, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**Simplified Text:**

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you plant trees on it, you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is good for planting trees.

I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so I was excited about planting trees. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, my brother, sister, and I had planted the whole 70 acres. In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot during that winter. It is funny to think of it as a happy time because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet and cold for so long.

Every morning was a challenge. I had to get ready for planting. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but the rain would be falling. My clothes were still wet from the day before, and my boots were soaked. I had to tie my shoelaces, which were slippery. “My mind started to think about many strange things and ideas about life.”

In that first year, I had a helper who was good at planting trees. This was helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with trees. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but when it gets lighter, it is easier to work. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you line up three poles to help you. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down the line, then turn around and come back.

I enjoy hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the least number of movements to dig a hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You learn to take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. 

Mentally, it is interesting. My mind starts to think about many things, including nature and our place in it. A lot of my thoughts about the natural world began during those days. I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow. It is satisfying to see them grow because I planted them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me feel anxious. However, everything worked out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months. I went alone and wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*. There is a small cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

**Text: 'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset. We take care of orphaned animals. But the noise from the box was strange, so I looked inside. There were three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born between January and March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. 

These three cubs were found by builders. While they were working, their machines accidentally broke into the badger's home. The mother was found dead, and her babies were still trying to drink from her. I could see the cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove to keep warm. There were two girls named Primrose and Bluebell, and a boy named Willow. At first, I used a syringe to feed them, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth first to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around, even if it was a bit shaky. They were happy together with a warm pad as a substitute for their mother.

Three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, but he was still eating. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When feeding animals with a bottle, it is important not to let them drink too fast, or they can get liquid in their lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with medicine.

Feeling sad about Willow, I continued to care for the other two cubs. Then, six days later, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, alone and cold. He knew the mother would not come back. This new cub, named Willow II, joined us. He was about two weeks younger than the girls. I soon found out that he was very hard to feed. I had to move the bottle around and squeeze it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day.

By the end of April, the girls were eating creamed rice and anything else I gave them. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but had trouble eating without making a mess. I finally gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more food. At almost five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and plants. My badgers were doing well, especially since it was a hot summer and finding food was hard.

By August, the cubs started to be active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they would chase each other and play. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek sometimes got caught and had colorful reactions. During these late-night walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because their homes were disturbed. Badgers are very protective of their territory and can be dangerous to others. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate to keep them safe.

The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them on our farm. With advice from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels and a special gate. It had three rooms, one bigger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside. As we built it, the badgers explored the new home before going on their walks. They became excited about climbing through the tunnels and making their beds. The building cost more than we expected, but a local bus company helped pay for it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home.

One evening, the badgers finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I checked on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy here.

**Text: In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was to study the "variations of the compass." These variations are now called "declination," which is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed to know this to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.

Halley was one of only two men in England paid to do scientific research at that time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip ended early because of problems with the crew, but he tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a chart showing the variations of the compass in the Western and Southern Oceans. This chart helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.

Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing his route. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.

Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was at Halley Station in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life and said, "Halley led a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics." Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.

Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's journey will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. He will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.

Dr. Clark explains, "It is common to measure the size of the magnetic field but not the direction. You need to know true north to measure the direction. On our expedition, we can use satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his work will help fill in any gaps in the data.

Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea. He was the first civilian to be appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. 

Does Dr. Clark have the right experience for this journey? He spent two years in Antarctica and worked at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's passion? He says, "I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this. Some people might think I'm obsessed, but I want to have a good reason to sail across the Atlantic again. Halley and his amazing life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, peacocks walk freely in Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire. They show their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior makes people think about a question that Charles Darwin wondered about: how can birds have such fancy feathers in a world where survival is tough? 

Darwin believed that animals change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He said that the strongest animals survive and have babies. But he thought that the peacock's tail was not useful for survival. So, he suggested another idea called "sexual selection." This means that female birds choose males based on their beauty.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if peahens liked the males with the most beautiful tails, there must be another reason for this choice. The tail might show that the male is healthy and strong, even if humans cannot see it.

Now, 100 years later, scientists are still studying this question. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Marion Petrie and her team want to find out two things: Do peahens really choose the males with the most beautiful tails? And do these males have other good qualities, or is it just about looks?

The male peacocks show off their tails in groups, and the hens compare them. Observations show that the hens prefer the males with the most eye spots on their tails. These males attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that male birds with beautiful feathers might be healthier and have fewer parasites. There is some evidence for this in other bird species. But Dr. Petrie and her team have not yet been able to check the health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.

This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the babies of attractive and unattractive male peacocks. She wants to see if the babies of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose males for good reasons.

There is also an interesting idea from the mathematician R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will have long tails, and her daughters will like long tails. This could lead to more males with long tails over time. This idea shows that females might choose beauty for its own sake, just as Darwin thought.

1. Where do the peacocks live?
2. What do the peacocks show to the hens?
3. What did Darwin believe about how animals change over time?
4. What is "sexual selection"?
5. What do the hens prefer in male peacocks?
6. What is William Hamilton's idea about male birds?
7. What is Dr. Petrie studying this year?

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe says that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. You might think that I am a romantic person, but I am not sure about that. 

My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but modern technology has also helped a lot. However, it is important to say that new technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real life at sea. This is often what they wanted to find when they went sailing. I do not think sailors should go back to facing all the difficulties of the past. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if every sail works by itself? Sometimes, dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.

Why should we change our steering positions from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? This change makes the cabin feel like a big ship, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said it had all the comforts but no luxury. I learned that he was right. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest boat I have ever sailed.

However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing her. I looked for a younger boat but could not find one, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. The designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are good with computer design, but Irens first drew this boat on a paper napkin. Later, he used a computer to make the design better. We worked together to improve the design until it was perfect.

The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside. This is because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about furniture. This is the best way to design a boat. In her calmness, she shows that you do not need to follow trends to be happy, and that sometimes it is good to learn from the past. Made from wood treated with special glue, she does not take in water. So, she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular now. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers are very well trained. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment lasts an hour and makes you feel great. The staff in the treatment rooms were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy. Henlow is planning to make big changes this year, including a swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a quiet walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy. I want to visit again. This is a perfect place for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The calm and relaxing feeling of this big house was clear as soon as I walked into the reception area. The Hall has a beautiful library, a nice conservatory, and lots of space, so you can be alone if you want. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, which includes checking your weight and blood pressure. They called us patients, which felt strange because I am healthy. However, I was happy that they found a shoulder problem and helped me with it in group workshops and private sessions. Each person gets a special diet to follow. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry and got a headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm, but it is a nice old manor with cozy log fires and a big lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool, so I could exercise after eating. There is a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture and exercises. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, but also relaxed. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens around the 376-acre estate. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with amazing food. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent some time in the gym to burn off some calories. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty treatments if you want them, before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is the most delicious I have ever tasted. It is the worst because it has 360 calories, which is a lot if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep during the massage. I had the best sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with great facilities and comfortable rooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book treatments. They offer many services, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters. I would love to take a break here every month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the last seven million years, humans have not changed much from chimpanzees. We are still more than 98% similar to them. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very new. Our ability to create art and other things we think are special to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 

Studies of animal behavior show that many traits we thought were only human are also found in animals. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that there are not many clear differences between humans and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from special genes, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost seven million years. The first forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we cannot find them because they do not last long. The first clear evidence of human art comes from the Cro-Magnons, around 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways: human art is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive. Let's look at these points.

First, Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. Some human art does communicate ideas, but this is not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, on the other hand, helps birds defend their territory or attract a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. So, by this idea, human art does seem different.

The second point is that human art is made for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during the breeding season, so they might not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art seem unique.

The third point is that human art is learned. Each human group has its own art styles that people learn. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. But these styles are not in our genes. People from different countries can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.

Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell that a painting from the 20th century is different from the Mona Lisa. Even experts can often tell who painted a work and when it was made. However, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy also created paintings that some people might mistake for human art. Congo made many paintings in one day and was upset when his pencil was taken away. They even had an art show in London in 1957, and many of their paintings sold.

These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for practical reasons; they were created for the enjoyment of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is often made to communicate with others, while the chimpanzees did not care about sharing their art. However, some famous human art was also made just for the artist's own pleasure.

**Text: An Amazing Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. Children's stories used to have brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Today, you do not find such people in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while at home with his family. The team he led had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous for everyone.

This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to find something new in his life. "I thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."

Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he said the desert was "kind." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing some of their water. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were very tired and the camels had not had water for seven days, we found some. We did not have the famous sandstorms of the Taklamakan. And we did not feel the freezing cold that could have stopped us. We were always fighting against problems. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which sometimes fell over onto us."

"What pushed me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No planes flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was hard at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much; you have so much behind you. We were very thin but strong despite being tired. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything."

In the middle of the book, Blackmore described lying in the desert, looking at the full moon, and thinking of his family. How did he feel about what they must have gone through? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do that. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I have done. But when I think of my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt good because we had a purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life."

**Simplified Text:**

Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful tools that make life easier. However, Susan feels that we are too dependent on technology. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her think that gadgets are often not worth it.

Little by little, Susan has stopped using some of her household gadgets. She wonders if technology really gives us more time. Does it just make us buy more gadgets? When her broken machine started making strange noises, she left it outside. Now, she enjoys taking her time to sew by hand instead of using a noisy machine. 

There are some gadgets she still likes, like her washing machine, but she found joy in giving up others. For example, they returned their rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped them spend more time walking their dog, reading, and talking with each other. 

Susan used to think she needed her sewing machine, but now she sews by hand. She enjoys listening to the radio or talking with family while she sews. She feels relaxed and happy doing this. She used to think that sewing by hand was hard work, but now she finds it satisfying and calming. 

Now, she takes her time with chores like washing dishes and thinks about what gadgets she really needs. She wonders if they could live without their freezer, microwave, or electric lights. 

**Questions:**

1. Why did Susan decide to unplug her gadgets?
2. What bad experience did Susan have with her word processor?
3. What did Susan do with her broken machine?
4. How did returning to a black-and-white TV change their family time?
5. What does Susan enjoy while she sews by hand?
6. What does Susan think about the gadgets in her home now?

**Simplified Text:**

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wooden boards in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a good reputation. He has many orders and does not need to advertise. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person.

It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is harder to find one who makes high-quality furniture. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of some modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced furniture and those who make low-quality pieces. Hurst wants to make perfect furniture, and this is part of his success.

Hurst is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work comes from private clients. Some clients come back to him many times. He enjoys making furniture for their whole house. However, he finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want.

Hurst is also kind and praises others when they deserve it. He says, "There are people far better than me." He is critical of those who take too long to make one piece of furniture and of students who try to make their work look fashionable. He believes furniture should be useful, not just a statement.

Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture." 

**Questions:**

1. What does Charles Hurst make?
2. How long has Hurst been a cabinet-maker?
3. Why does Hurst not need to advertise his work?
4. What does Hurst think about modern furniture?
5. How does Hurst feel about his own skills?
6. Who are most of Hurst's clients?
7. What does Hurst think about furniture that is just a fashion statement?

**Text: Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. But, scientists do not agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main ideas.

The first idea says that sleep helps our bodies stay healthy. When we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and get ready for the next day.

The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us understand and remember what we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things.

The third idea is about energy. This idea says that we need to sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day and have enough energy to do our activities.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of their society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, someone might love to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the editor about many topics. Being eccentric shows our individuality.

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two feelings. One feeling is to be ourselves, called individualism. The other feeling is to fit in with others, called conformity. Most people want to be accepted and liked, so they often choose to fit in rather than stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to talk about what they enjoy or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think their interests are strange. Being in a group can make us feel safe.

Many of us feel a push and pull between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. Even when we follow the crowd, we might not like it if someone points it out. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. 

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Some people become very successful by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and go after it, you will surprise many people." But being different on purpose, like a pop star wearing strange clothes for attention, is not true eccentricity. 

True eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes eccentrics different from other people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, without worrying about what others think.

**Simplified Text: Natural Books**

We asked four naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. One of the most important is Barbara Ward. She is a small, frail woman, but her ideas about the environment are very strong. She has combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own important ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand many things. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think her most important book is "The Home of Man." This book talks about the fast growth of cities in the world and important themes she cared about. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the guano in the sun. This book explains very well, with words and pictures, how animals communicate. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaos turns into a smart social structure. You can see which birds are partners and where their boundaries are. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion to create this book, which is interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and how another shows peace. This is the art of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to a great career in conservation. It made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. I had been there for two years and was feeling discouraged, but when I opened the book, everything became brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all together—a small world worth saving. Some people say humans are bad because of the harm we have done to other species. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family that is connected. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially to the 48 colorful bird pictures by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" had so much more. It included beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative feelings about nature are just as important as scientific ones. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**Text: DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in newspapers. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or word of mouth. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers feel bad when there are no reviews. However, publishers think that even bad reviews can help sell books because they make readers curious. Publishers like reviews that match their own feelings about a book since they are often the first readers.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, especially in a good way. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find out about books and authors. Good reviews from trusted sources can really help sell books.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we rely on reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because they show that the review is honest. Publishers say they want big reviews, but the real effect of reviews on sales is hard to understand. Good reviews can help a book and its author become very popular, but they need help from other things like recommendations and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
The relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain is complicated. In the United States, a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to talk more about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they really help sell books? I once published a biography that got excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could learn everything from the reviews. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would listen. Now, sometimes it is the unexpected reviewer or a clever review that makes people want to buy the book.

**Text: WEATHERVANE MAKER**

Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith continues this craft in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. 

"A lot of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands," he says. "They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies." This is different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane Graham made was not a cockerel; it was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 

Graham decided to start a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed their roles. She went to work, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."

Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always asks for the customer's approval before cutting the design. He also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," Graham says. "They want something a little different."

Graham does not plan to grow his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love unique items, and I enjoy seeing a simple shape turn into something beautiful," he explains. "For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." 

Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want to add special touches to their homes. This has helped crafts like his. Graham is getting busier and sends weathervanes to customers all over the world, especially in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he says. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Text: 'Beginner Takes All'**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. He shares his story about his inspiration and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a hard time. A film project he had worked on for months fell apart suddenly. He was worried because he had not earned money for two years, and he needed to pay his bank. A smart person in his situation would have found a job. He could have gone back to working in television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and traveled for three months to research his first novel.

Nicholas had an idea for the story for a while. He got the idea from a farrier he met while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were very worried until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and change its behavior in a few hours. These special people were called "horse whisperers." Nicholas was inspired and started to learn more about this topic. He wanted to write a movie script because he was a filmmaker. But after his film project failed, he decided to write a book instead.

During the spring, he drove around the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He said, "It was a strange time. I was watching people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and worried about my family."

By the end of August, he returned home and had written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money and needed to know if he should continue. He showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for the book. Nicholas needed more money to pay off his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had two months of work left.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book and a summary to seven UK publishers. Soon, his agent called to say that he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Nicholas was shocked. His agent felt something good was going to happen. 

Within a week, the book was sold to two publishers for record amounts: £550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. Nicholas and his team could not believe it. They had not even sent the book to New York, and they did not know how it got there. Major film studios also wanted the book. Nicholas's agent in the UK worked with an agent in the US, and they offered $3 million for the movie rights. Nicholas was amazed.

One night in October, four famous filmmakers called him to ask for the chance to pay $3 million for his unfinished novel. Nicholas told me this story while we drank coffee on his porch at home. He said he turned down an offer to write the movie script for *The Horse Whisperer*. He felt it was like a fairy tale, and he did not want to ruin it. Writing for movies is hard work, and he did not want to become just an employee. He wanted to stay involved but keep some distance.

The success of his novel also brought new support for his old film project, but he was not sure if he wanted to make it anymore. He said, "I think I would be foolish not to write another novel."

**Text: 'Young Masters'**

Bobby Fischer is trying to come back to chess. He is not as young as he used to be. Chess is now a game for younger players. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, and it was a great game. But he is now 49 years old, not in good shape, and not used to playing. Boris Spassky is also older.

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Bobby Fischer helped make chess popular, and now there are many professional players. Today, the main goal for chess players is to win. In international chess, a player needs to be strong mentally and physically. The game is very intense. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time. If they do not, they lose the game. Now, games can last longer, and players often do not take breaks. This makes it harder for older players.

In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Most of the top ten players in the world are under 30 years old. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare before their matches. Computers help players study many chess games and find weaknesses in their opponents. In one recent match, players had teams of helpers to find mistakes in each other's games. 

Today, there are more great chess players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock adds to the pressure. At the end of a game, players often rush to make their moves. They have only a few seconds to finish, which can be very stressful.

Winning a game feels great, but one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess tournaments usually last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even harder. For example, a match in 1984 between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov had to stop after several months because both players were too tired. Karpov lost a lot of weight during the match.

Can Bobby Fischer still be the best? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long break from chess surprising. If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot. No matter what happens in his match with Spassky, they will both make millions of dollars. But if Bobby wants to prove he is still the best player, the result could be very sad for him.

**Text: Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.

A. Nick Grosso is a playwright in his early 30s. He has written three plays that many people liked. Now, he is turning his first play, Peaches, into a movie script. He says, "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before he wrote Peaches, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It is set in a car. I probably wouldn’t do that now because I know it is hard to do." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors because he wanted people to hear his writing. He says, "I was finally with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."

B. Simon Pegg is a 28-year-old comedian. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a comedy series for TV and just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he practiced his comedy in clubs. Simon remembers, "University was very theoretical. I realized I didn’t want to be a serious actor; I liked comedy more. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn’t. If you have courage and good material, it is great to make people laugh." He has worked with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best work has been with Steve Coogan. Simon says, "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his. He probably saw me copying him."

C. Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he danced in the show The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked his performance, and now he can choose what work he wants to do. He says, "It has been a great chance for me. I can pick what I want, which is what I always wanted." Ciaran started acting in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He laughs, "I used acting to avoid homework. But then I decided I wanted to do it seriously because I was good at it." Now, he waits for praise, but he thinks about fame. He says, "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you realize it is not why you act. It is about getting respect for good work."

D. Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They just signed a deal for three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their single, Chimera, comes out. Neil says, "The record company thinks good sales are very different from what I think. They want a big hit, but I just want two people to buy it." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for eight years. He says, "It is funny how things happen. I was tired of doing small gigs and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections in the music industry. It was a great time for me."

E. Stephen Richards is a 27-year-old poet and author. He has won many awards and is well-known in the poetry world. He has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. He says, "It is a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I could not write as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but later lost interest in education. He decided not to go to university but later realized he should after getting bored with a job. **Volunteer Tourism**

Four writers talk about international volunteer work.

A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps development a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money was given directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for gap years, where volunteers often do not need special skills or experience. Many studies ask if gap year volunteering is really about helping others or if young people want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help people learn to act kindly towards those who have less.

B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better, solve problems, and take part in global issues through community organizations. It can also help build international friendships. In this way, everyone can benefit, both the volunteers and the communities they help. C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to help themselves while pretending to help others. It can also be a way to provide real help for development. Most importantly, volunteering can help people understand and care about the unfair power differences and the deep causes of poverty and injustice.

**Text: Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?

A group of us, including the inventor Tom Granger and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios that are available now. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs two alarms? This model costs about the same as another one we tested, but it has a cassette player. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to music instead of news. We all thought the radio quality was very good, but the clock radio is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm does not go off."

This model was voted the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," but the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it easily with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I ended up pressing them too much, which made it hard to understand the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you do not have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But we found it hard to set up, even though it made us feel cool when we finally did it.

Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, looked cheap. He said, "You have to pull the light out to make it work, which makes me question the quality." He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The light was hard to position; it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges thought the lamp idea was funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is bright and colorful, which appealed to Tom Granger and me. Tom said, "I would choose this one because it stands out."

The traditional design of the controls made it the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be 20 minutes early or late. The manual says, "The alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this idea and said this model was "very difficult to use" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, "It's easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are never sure if you pressed everything correctly." He agreed that companies had to improve radio quality because of button tuning. I thought the tuning was not very good, and Paul Bridges agreed, but we both thought the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Text: Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger. This helps protect them because their spines point outwards. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They may try to run away from danger instead of rolling up. 

Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They often sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. Some hedgehogs stay awake all year if the conditions are good.

Despite this, they are overcoming challenges and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

"I love to ski and feel great when I jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or the weather is bad, but I keep going. "Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools offer it. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so it can be difficult for the women’s team. But I enjoy it and like being fit, plus I have a good social life."

The day I met Picasso

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 18 years old. He was a student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. One day, he ran out of money and found a job painting boats. He often drew pictures and had a sketchbook with him.

One day, Richard saw Picasso sitting at a table in a restaurant in Cannes. Picasso was famous and usually stayed away from people. Richard was surprised to see him there with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. He was nervous but asked Picasso for his signature. So, Richard took his sketchbook and returned to Picasso's table. He did not ask if he could draw Picasso's portrait because he was afraid of being refused. Instead, he just started to draw.

**Text: Shopping Tricks**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.

A. **Freshness First**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The color green is often used in stores because it makes people think of fresh food. Most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.

B. **Smart Displays**  
Where products are placed in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where shoppers look the most. They put the most expensive items in these places. Items at eye level are more likely to be bought. Special bins with discounts attract people who love a good deal. Sometimes, stores place items that go well together near each other, like ice cream and toppings.

C. **Hiding Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting items. Stores may also put popular products far away, hoping that loyal customers will look for them and see other items they might want to buy.

D. **Less is More**  
Some chain stores have changed how they show their products. For example, Next stores display fewer items to make them look special. Even though their clothes are made in large amounts, good store design helps them sell better.

E. **Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers often care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap items with more expensive ones. They sometimes sell basic items at a loss to attract customers. They can get lower prices by buying in large amounts or by giving products good display space.

F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up sales to give change.

G. **Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so shoppers can see colors well. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.

H. **Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the way through the store, and another shows sales areas. This helps shoppers move along paths called the "Yellow Brick Road." Some shoppers, however, do not want to leave these paths.

I. **In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. In some U.S. supermarkets, shopping carts have screens that show ads for products while you shop. These ads are meant to catch the attention of shoppers and can increase sales a lot.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, like *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He set a record by sailing from New York to the Lizard in just 10 days. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote a book about their trip called *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*, a study of adventure after the war. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris about sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. 

They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Chris was impressed by how steady Robin was. When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. Robin asked if he could go down the way he used ropes on his boat. Chris wanted him to use his legs, but Robin lowered himself down safely. 

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a big step from their Skye trip. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions first. Most of the time, people did not give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. 

Chris found sailing boring and hard. He liked the excitement of problems at sea, but he did not like being on the ocean for many days. Chris preferred land and was not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, loved sailing and enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin did not really need him. The crew was also very close together: six people on a small yacht meant for four. On a mountain, you can get away from each other.

When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing expedition. He felt nervous about Robin's safety. If Robin fell, he could pull Chris down too. Chris did not expect climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, to be so hard. Robin was not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin trusted Chris completely and just followed him. When it became too hard, Chris knew they had to turn back, and Robin accepted it. 

Robin was also worried about their boat and whether it would be okay in the ice. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They took turns watching the boat. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his turn, but Robin did not wake him. Robin thought he could do it alone. Chris felt that Robin did not trust him, and he told him so. Robin quickly reassured Chris that he was wrong to think that. 

While they enjoyed the trip to Skye, they did not really know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. Chris found that Robin was a kind and sensitive person, even if he seemed tough on the outside.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the different kinds of apples we have.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored wild apples for winter. These apples were small and different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Times (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. This knowledge included making cider. The Romans brought some apple types to Britain, but many did not grow well there. After the Normans came, they brought new apple types. British monks also worked to create new kinds of apples. Most apples we have today come from these old varieties.

**Medieval Times (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a main dessert apple until the 1700s. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad weather and diseases made it hard to grow apples, so more apples were brought in from other places. In the sixteenth century, King Henry VIII sent a man named Richard Harris to France to learn about growing apples. Harris returned with many new apple types, including the famous Pippins.

**Settlers and Apples (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A famous apple planter in North America was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed'. He planted many apple trees and was loved by the Native Americans.

**Modern Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree and named the apple 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and said it was 'Delicious'. This apple became very popular. Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She discovered a small tree growing from old fruit and grew the first green apples, which became famous.

**Uniformity in Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most come from just a few types. These apples are often chosen for their looks or how well they travel, not for their taste. Many old apple types are disappearing. In the UK, some gardeners keep old varieties alive, but in the US, many apples from 100 years ago are gone. People want more types of apples. We need to care about keeping different kinds of apples and other foods for everyone.

**Text: Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We create trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our focus is on visiting new and interesting places with unique travel plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. Our groups are friendly and led by experienced guides. This gives you a chance to learn more about the places we visit and meet local people. It is a fun experience for all travelers.

**Different Ways to Travel**

We use many types of transport on our trips. Sometimes we travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, or even on foot. Each trip is special and reflects the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who enjoy new experiences. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone who is healthy, fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, and the rest are solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip with Explore Worldwide is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories based on activities and interests. Each category highlights special parts of a tour, but many other factors make each trip enjoyable, like unique places and local customs.

**Cultural/Adventure Trips**

Many trips focus on culture. Some tours emphasize local cultures and historical sites. For example, you can visit Egypt, Jordan, India, and many other countries with rich histories. Short walks of 2-4 hours to see special sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Nature**

Our wildlife safaris take you to amazing game parks to see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you can sometimes leave your vehicle and explore the wild. You might track gorillas in Zaire or go canoeing in the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays.

**Meeting Local People**

A highlight of our trips is meeting local or tribal people. You might meet the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. Many of these cultures are at risk, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing impact on their way of life.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Some trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can hike from village to village and stay in local homes or simple huts. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand. Your main luggage is carried separately, so you only need a small bag for the day.

**Major Treks**

We offer some challenging treks for experienced hikers. These may involve walking at high altitudes in places like the Himalayas or the Andes. We often stay with local people or camp in beautiful mountain areas.

**Wilderness Experiences**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert, which offer unique experiences.

**Sail and River Journeys**

We also have relaxing holidays on boats. You can sail in Egypt or travel between islands in Greece and Thailand. Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days, and no experience is needed. You will learn safety skills quickly and enjoy the beautiful scenery.

This is a brief overview of what Explore Worldwide offers. Each trip is a chance for adventure and discovery!

**Simplified Text:**

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners in his country. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is ten miles south of the equator. There is a mountain path that starts from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path leads to Mount Kenya, the highest mountain in Kenya. This beautiful and quiet place is called Nanyuk. For three years, it has been my place for training in the winter. But I had never trained with Kenyan runners before. 

On my fourth trip to Kenya, I decided to change this. I ran in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This is where the best Kenyan runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race. It was a great chance for me. 

Training at high altitude helps runners make more red blood cells, which helps them carry oxygen better. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. My first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race in Africa. There were 41 runners who finished before me, and almost all of them were Kenyan. I felt I did okay in the race!

I think Kenyan runners are successful for more reasons than just the high altitude. They have a simple and relaxed way of running. They enjoy competing and have a simple diet. But how do they train? I learned about their training at the camp. 

The national team training camp is at St Mark's College, which is 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The camp is basic, and the athletes live with regular students in shared rooms. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six in the morning. We would meet with the coaches before the morning run. They told us to run easy because we had a hard day ahead. 

Each day, we ran about 40 kilometers, which is close to a marathon distance. On Sundays, we only ran 20 kilometers, which was a nice break. Life at the camp was simple. We washed our faces and brushed our teeth before breakfast. Breakfast was tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar: ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to a stream to wash off in the evening.

By the time I left the camp, I understood more about why Kenyan runners are successful. Their success is not just because of their genes or where they come from. I think the simple life in the mountains, their hard training, and their love for running are the real reasons why Kenya is so good at distance running.

**The Problems of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is not doing well. It is not just because of the recession. Advertising started to decline in 1989, before the recession really began. The problems with advertising are serious and happen all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers think about large groups of people, but as more brands and media appear, the target audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.

Think about your own shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You might buy a few well-known brands, but you will not buy many different brands in a year. For example, you may only buy about 400 different brands in a year, even though there are many more brands advertised.

According to Media Register, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. If we look at the 9,500 brands that Media Register lists, the average person only buys about 400 of them. This means that about 96% of advertising does not lead to sales. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that only about 6% of the ads are for brands they will buy.

Many people think they are different and that they do not pay attention to advertising. But the truth is, most people do not buy most of the brands they see in ads. There is always waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. It needs to reach many people to find the few who will respond. 

Even with smart targeting, advertisers cannot know exactly who will buy their products. This is different from selling face-to-face, where a salesperson can connect with every customer they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all.

For any advertising campaign, getting just 2% of the adult population to buy a product is considered very successful. The best way to reach people may still be through mass media, but advertising needs to be more focused than ever to be effective again.
