**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits a Green Home**

Charles Clover goes inside a very eco-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This place has some surprises. First, it has Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. Writers who care about the environment like it because of the 'green' men figures carved by craftsmen in the thirteenth century.

The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' which is the greenest home in Britain. It was designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. They use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their waste into compost for the garden, and heat their home with waste heat from their appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

You might not notice the house at first. It looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was built to match the orange brick of the town's old buildings and was approved by planners, even in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. 

When you enter and take off your shoes (as Robert asks), it feels very calm. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to let in fresh air. The house is designed to keep out drafts, and even the cats have their own small door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, cared about the environment long before it became popular. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They wanted to create a building that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They built special toilets, put rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean. They filter the water before using it. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not have a dishwasher because they think using strong detergents is wrong.

Robert says, "We wanted people to see that it is possible to design a house that is better for the environment, without living in the dark." The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has the fireplace and staircase going up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use.

Soon, they will add solar panels to generate more electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances, but it will make more electricity than it needs. One day, it might even charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they say they only use in very cold weather. 

Is the house warm in winter? One night in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than usual, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no drafts and everything was at the same temperature. 

Robert believes that people who live in old houses should go back to how people lived in the past. However, it is hard to imagine many people wanting to do this. The secret of the house is that it is simple and easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from a local store and installed by local workers. This made the house cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost rental housing. It is not surprising that big building companies do not like this idea.

**Text: The Camera and Fairies**

Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies in a garden and believed they were real. He published these photos with an article, saying that fairies were wonderful creatures. 

In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the trick was simple. This goes against a common idea that a camera always tells the truth. 

Today, we can use computer programs to change our digital photos. It is a myth that photography has ever been completely honest. From the beginning, when cameras started to take pictures, the reality was changed.

**Text: Blacksmiths**

For a long time, iron has been very important to people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The lovely metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths. 

However, by the late 1960s, there were very few blacksmiths left in Britain because heavy industry did not need them anymore, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and new interior design styles. Still, much of the work looks similar to old styles, with many manufacturers calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." 

You can find many trendy design stores selling rusty candlesticks with extra decorations. Luckily, there are new events to promote blacksmithing. The first event is an exhibition of ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now." 

Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal. They can now bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. Dawson says, "These artists can now express themselves with this material." About 250 pieces of work are in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but some will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork. 

Dawson has made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it is hot. It's like drawing with metal in space." Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron and steel are harder to work with when cold. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it is soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and strong again." 

Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles from mild steel. Her designs are inspired by scary castles from horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever." No other metal gives people as much joy or a feeling of safety. Iron will likely be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we do not have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was strange for me too. 

I stopped smoking two months and three weeks ago. I did not plan to stop, and I did not really want to. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. I also had good health and did not often get sick. 

On that Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit. I said, "I will not try to stop. I am here to write, not to quit." I thought this was a good reason. I enjoyed smoking and it made me happy. 

During the session, we could smoke as much as we wanted. The room was full of smoke, and we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. The idea of not being a smoker began to feel good. 

It was not hard to stop. The cravings for nicotine went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was not a problem. The hardest part was being at home on weekend mornings. I realized that smoking helped me feel less bored. 

I do miss smoking sometimes, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is different, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a break at the theater. These are moments when I would have smoked before.

**Simplified Text:**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For the last four years, I have been asking my friends if they know about her. If they do, they pass my test. 

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She also helped discover the structure of insulin. Hodgkin was a very important scientist, but she is not as famous as other Nobel Prize winners in literature.

Hodgkin died in 1994, and her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and the spread of science around the world. When I started my research, I wanted to read about other scientists. I looked for a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a friend of Hodgkin and also won Nobel Prizes. But I could not find any books about him in the bookshop. 

Some people think that the lives of scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that scientists' lives are often boring to read. This idea makes it hard for scientists to be seen as interesting people. Some scientists do not want to be in the media because they do not want to seem like they are promoting themselves. 

However, more scientists are now appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on TV. These activities help people see scientists as real people.

The way we write about scientists is also changing. In the past, biographies were often dull and focused only on their work. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show scientists as interesting people with lives outside of their work. 

Dorothy Hodgkin loved her scientific work. She had three children and a husband who was often away because of his job. Her personal life is not the main focus of her work, but it shows how she balanced her family and her career. 

Hodgkin's passion for science is important. It can be hard to explain scientific ideas to people who do not have a strong background in science. But understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just takes practice. 

It is sad that many educated people do not know about important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists. 

**Questions:**

1. Who is Dorothy Hodgkin?
2. What did Dorothy Hodgkin win a Nobel Prize for?
3. Why is it surprising that many people do not know about Hodgkin?
4. What did Peter Medawar say about the lives of scientists?
5. How are scientists becoming more visible to the public today?
6. What is one way Dorothy Hodgkin balanced her work and personal life?

**Text: Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her special ability to find water. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells run dry. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines like drilling rigs, but Margaret prefers her hazel stick for finding water. They have a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special skill, while others believe it is based on science. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water. 

In recent years, many farmers have needed Margaret's help because of droughts. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, "We see customers only once in a lifetime because wells last a long time." Other customers have holiday homes where it is too expensive to run water pipes. Some are building golf courses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She says, "You can't drill where there is a risk of waste getting into the water." The water she finds is usually clean, but she has to be careful because some areas have iron in the water.

To find water, Margaret first looks at a map and uses a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when she is above water. After that, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. 

Margaret holds the two forks of the stick and pulls them slightly apart. If the stick rises, it means water is below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick points. If she and her husband do not agree on the spot, they will keep looking until they do.

Margaret's ability to find water is interesting to many people. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding where water is. If she did not have this skill, it would be hard for her family to run their well-drilling business.

**Simplified Text:**

**We changed lives for a day!** Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something new! We did this for four people. Here is what happened.

**A. Amanda's story**  
I had never been in a place like this before. It was dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and I was not sure I could do it! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was harder! I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when I tried, the drinks fell off the tray and spilled everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first! 

By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers outside, and I felt very nervous. I was worried about remembering the orders, but it was easy because everything was done by machines. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I could not get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say, "Pardon?" which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. One waitress told me it was a "quiet" day! I never knew waitressing was so tiring. I thought it was an easy job, but you need to be friendly and calm, especially when there are many customers. I am shy, and I don’t think I could work on a busy Saturday night. I was not happy with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers did not tip me! I was very glad to go back to my children. Taking care of them seems easy after waitressing!

**B. Cindy's story**  
I was a bit nervous about being a "mum" for a day, but I was also excited. I knew the girls could be naughty, but I thought I could handle it. When Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. 

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly! I thought they would get tired, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they were too much for me! After a lot of talking, I got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun began! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew they just wanted to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was tiring to spend all evening talking with them. I never knew taking care of two small children could be so tiring. You don’t have time to think about yourself, and it feels like a big responsibility. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's story**  
On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was great! But I took a long time to decide how to dress. I could not wear my farm clothes to school! At assembly, I looked at about 400 students and hoped I did not stand out. Then it was time for a math class. The children worked in small groups, which was different from when I was in school. I helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There is so much to do before classes start again. I went to a meeting about reports and helped with sports trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which was nice, and then a French lesson. The children wanted to practice their French with me, which showed me how rusty I was! Finally, we had Physical Education. I was very tired, but the children had so much energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I will stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's story**  
I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, but Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep! She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which she sells. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers, making ice cream, and putting on labels. It was hard not to eat the treats! 

At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I drove to a field and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If a sheep is left for more than 12 hours, it could die, so they must be checked every day. It must be hard in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking. It took two and a half hours, and Rosemary does this twice a day, every day! I found it lonely. I missed the children because animals do not talk back! The worst part of the job is that you cannot take time off. The cows must be milked twice a day, so it is hard to plan a break. Rosemary will only have about three days off this year. Farming seems nice, but the reality is very different. The money is not steady, and I would not like to depend on the weather.

**Simplified Text:**

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is interesting how many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known around the world. He plays old music from composers and also new music. When you see him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of the trumpet.

Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. He also had a TV show about his work, filmed in London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo. When he was eight years old, he got a trumpet as a Christmas gift from his father. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music, so he bought a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time.

His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give Hakan lessons. This teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher. Bo was very passionate about the trumpet and always looked for new ways to play.

Hakan explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is hard to make a perfect one. Each trumpet is a little different. He learned to accept these differences and work with them. Even as a child, people could recognize Hakan's unique sound.

Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, who played in orchestras, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre, and bought all his records. Hakan's parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player.

When Hakan was 15, he needed to choose where to study. His teacher wanted him to go to America, but it was too far. Instead, he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not for him. Hakan knew he played better than many others his age. 

At 17, he entered his first competition in Paris. He only prepared for the first round but made it to the second round. He knew most of the pieces for that round too. In the final round, he faced a difficult piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and realized that people listened to him.

Hakan is honest about his music and career. He does not want to explain how he connects with people through music because he believes it might ruin the magic. He thinks music has the power to move people.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what they do every day.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I operate, but I sometimes worry about the next day. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it works, it is amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see patients to explain their operations. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they are upset, I try to comfort them, but I have to be quick. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my beeper. When I am on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first three days, and I dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train to work, and arrive at 9:15 am. At 10:30 am on Monday, we meet to talk about our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with some design work. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like them, we make budgets and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people. I have to communicate well with everyone. When their work is ready, I put everything together and send it to the printers. It can be very stressful to manage many projects at once. Deadlines are always close, and my day is not always the same. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to the pub. If the client likes my designs, it feels great, but it is disappointing if they don’t. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, but sometimes it is much later. I find it hard to relax when I am busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am most days, but two or three times a week, I wake up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Because driving is a sitting job, I have to eat well and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area. Many jobs are booked in advance, so I can check the routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. But most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear things in the car that I shouldn’t, so I focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I take care of gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At about 11 am, we go to a cafe for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I have an office at home, so when I get back, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look old. Sometimes, clients have strange ideas, but it is satisfying to see a garden we created. It is hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the phone ring. I sleep well because my job is very physical, and I am always tired at the end of the day."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I am an assistant engineer, and I help build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that the workers are doing their jobs correctly and safely. I help solve problems and coordinate the workers. The workers start at 6 am, so my first job is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn. I usually have paperwork to do or questions to answer. I have lunch for about half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. The workers have set meal times, so I check things when they are eating. Because I check their work, we need to have a good relationship. I see the main engineer once a day, but if something important happens, I act quickly. I usually leave the site at about 6 pm and I am always on call."

**Text: Careers - Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I work with customers who use our credit cards. I help to start and manage a rewards program for card users in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then I check my emails. I work with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising. I have many meetings during the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I am in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10:30 am with calls from producers and others. I have meetings to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that people are sharing their hard work, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening. Sometimes I don’t get home until 1:00 am.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for the day. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I work with restorers to fix the furniture we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while I drink coffee to stay updated on the business. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes me about an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work in shifts. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start work at 7:00 am and take over from the night shift. I control aircraft movements with my team. In winter, we manage about 1,000 movements a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new air traffic rules. This job is stressful, and I need to be alert. I want to become a watch manager or general manager of the airport in the future.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is at the cash register. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be hard when they expect me to find many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new books with them. I need to make sure new titles arrive on time. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work late and close the shop.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for companies working abroad and warn clients about possible problems. I provide three services: an online news preview, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. I have deadlines to meet, so I work quickly. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Text: Career Power**

**Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take control at work.**

A. **What makes a good leader?**  
A leader is someone who inspires others and helps them change for the better. Leadership is not about being tall or smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote the book *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, says that leadership is about "making things happen with people who are as excited and interested as you are." A good leader should be enthusiastic and able to speak clearly and confidently. It is important to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who teaches a Leadership in Management course, says, "Most people can be better leaders than they think." To become a leader, you need to find and develop your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst, Mahatma Gandhi, or Richard Branson, but it can be harder to see it in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and supported you. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first leader was very good; the second one was not good at all.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who wrote *Leadership Rules*, says, "A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a struggling organization, whether it is a company, a sports team, or a country."

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to do it. Find out what you care about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy and take action.  
- Start thinking of yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of you.  
- Working together is good, but sometimes you need to be a strong leader. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead yourself. See how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better and grow in your career.

F.  
- Leadership does not just happen. It grows when you take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, organize, and give praise.  
- Don’t think that everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and available to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Simplified Text: Films on Video**

**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**

Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense Cold War movie about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The funny and brave foreman Bud and his team remind us of tough heroes in movies by Howard Hawks. The special effects and set design are very good. **B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video version of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal is directed by Andrew Marton. It is different from Terrence Malick's new film. Malick's film is poetic and mystical, while Marton's is a more traditional war movie. He focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has some good moments. The soldier's flashback about his wife is done in a strong way, which some may prefer over Malick's softer images.

**C. On Guard**  
This fun swashbuckler is based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel. It is better than most musketeer movies. Fabrice Luchini plays a villain who causes trouble behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, even if he does not last long. Daniel Auteuil is a bit too serious for this type of film, but he has his moments as a swordsman. The filmmakers use classic costume drama ideas with so much humor that it works well.

**D. Character**  
This serious story is set in Rotterdam at the turn of the century. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel when evicting tenants. His bad relationship with his son is the main part of the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on the details and not enough on the dark story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released video shows off director Leone's skills. The sound editing is excellent; every sound is clear. The story is very harsh, and when it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement. Morally, there is not much difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act badly in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
The publicity says "Forty-eight International stars" for this three-hour war movie by Darryl Zanuck. With four directors and 23,000 extras, it is a big production. The early scenes, where the soldiers wait for news about the invasion, are slow for both the audience and the soldiers. It is impressive in size, but it is better to watch on a big screen. Watching it on video does not give the same experience.

I might be too old for this, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age want to travel. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent my flat and travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and I'm nervous. I have traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I came back, I wanted to travel again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning money. I realized I was giving up my happiness for my salary. When I gave my resignation letter, it felt like I was in control of my life again. I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children. They don’t want to change places with me, but they envy my freedom. I am not in a relationship, and I don’t have big career goals. I feel I should enjoy this freedom, even for my friends! 

Why am I so nervous? First, I need to make plans. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize renting it out? And I need to decide where to go. I often put things off and I am already behind my schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the football season?” It is hard to cut emotional ties. I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to live simply? Will I feel out of place with younger backpackers? Maybe not. Many people in their late twenties and thirties in Britain want to leave their lives and travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people are realizing they can have adventures: “People who always say ‘I wish I had that chance’ are now seeing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave and organized.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a last chance before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m ready to give up job security for this trip. I know I won’t move up in my career, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river to show I was serious!” For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling helped him change. “In the military, there is a set way to do things. I needed to change that to live well as a civilian.” 

There are many reasons to travel at my age. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today, many people work on short-term contracts. If your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Some big companies even allow career breaks. “If you train someone well, it’s good to know they will come back instead of going to a competitor.” Dan Hiscocks, from Travellerseye, says more thirty-somethings are thinking about their lives. “If you are not happy, it’s not just about staying in a job. Now people know there are opportunities and that a job is not forever. Travel lets you think about your life.”

Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation can’t handle adulthood? Jennifer Cox says no. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society. We care more about living a balanced life than just paying bills. We ask ourselves, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, does not think he is running away. “I am running towards something. I want to grab what I want for myself.” But he is also nervous. “I will miss my comfortable routine, going to the office every day, saying ‘hi’ to everyone, and having coffee.” 

I feel the same way about leaving my easy life. I might not be going on this trip if my boss wasn’t so hard to deal with. Jennifer Cox says, “This is common. A big change, like a breakup or losing a job, can push people to travel.” It took a little push for me to start, but now I feel excited about the next 12 months. No matter what happens, I will be happy that I took this chance. I think many of us older backpackers feel the same way!

**Text: 'Working from Home'**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt she did not know much about new technology. In this text, she shares how she changed her home into a good place to work.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 years old. I realized I needed to get back to my job in journalism. I looked at my resume and saw that I was stuck in the past, like in the 1980s, when typewriters were common. I thought no one would want to hire me because I did not know how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for experience in desktop publishing, which I did not have. I felt like I could not even use a computer.

I thought it would be hard to leave home to work, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer package! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We started to learn about the Internet and began chatting with people from around the world. The children loved using the computer, and I set up a small office in the kitchen. I had a phone, a fax machine, and everything I needed to work from home while taking the kids to school.

At first, I was scared to use the computer. I thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills I needed. It was easier than I thought. I started writing articles for a magazine, and now I feel proud that I can work from home.

The computer helped me become more organized. Before, my desk was always messy, and I lost important papers. Now, I can keep track of my money and save time with invoices and letters. I can also research stories online and talk to other journalists.

However, working from home has some downsides. I sometimes feel lonely because I do not see many people. There are also distractions at home, like chores and sharing the computer with my children. But many people are buying computers for work and fun, and they enjoy not having to travel to work every day.

A report about computer use in UK homes says that most home workers are educated and own a personal computer. I feel like I am doing well with my computer skills. One day, I might even send an article to a newspaper in Australia or start my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless!

**The Tartan Museum**

The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has modern buildings that look like cheese wedges. The outside of the museum is very big and easy to see. It has a tall yellow tower and a garden hanging from the roof. When it opened, people had different opinions about the building. Some thought it was beautiful, while others did not like it.

Now, the inside of the museum is almost ready. The exhibitions will tell many stories about Scotland's history. There are important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show these treasures without too much national pride. 

Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants visitors to enjoy their time at the museum. He says it is for everyone, even those who do not know much about history. He does not want to show things that are not real or that guess what the past was like. He believes people deserve the truth.

Visitors will see explanations and pictures to help them understand the objects. There are also computers in the museum to provide more information. The museum has many different rooms with pale walls and deep display cases. Light comes in from special windows, making it bright and pleasant to look at the items.

There is a special area for children called the Discovery Centre. A group of kids helped create this space. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a hands-on area for children to explore.

On the top floor, there is a gallery that changes every three years. It shows objects chosen by Scottish people that have been important in the 20th century. Some items include an electric guitar and favorite toys. This idea is fun, but it may not be serious enough for some visitors.

Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum's modern design is impressive from the inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

**The Future of Newspapers**  
Peter Preston

Change is a nice word. It can make us feel calm. But change can also scare some people. Transition means moving from one place to another. For newspapers, this change to the online world is not easy. Many people think it will happen, but it is not clear how.

Print newspaper sales are going down. More people are visiting newspaper websites. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year. But their websites are getting more visitors. This is true for many newspapers, but it depends on different factors like time and place.

A recent survey showed that worldwide newspaper sales actually went up by 1.1% last year. In the West, sales went down, but in Asia, they increased. Some magazines also did well, with a 5.4% rise in sales. 

E-books are becoming very popular, and sales are increasing a lot. However, when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books, they found that sales were only down by 0.4%. This means people are buying both e-books and physical books.

Many people think young people do not read newspapers anymore, but this is not true. The latest survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%. France has seen a smaller drop of 3.1%.

In the past, experts thought that online advertising would help newspapers succeed. But now, online ads are going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to get readers is to offer both print and online access together. Print newspapers help sell online subscriptions, and they make much more money from ads than online ads.

However, it is hard for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. It is expensive and complicated. But print newspapers still have a strong presence, and it is harder for them to be noticed online.

**Text: Photographing People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually more exciting than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can change how people act.

A. **Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of groups, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can have some people sitting or kneeling in front so you can see all their faces.

B. **Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

C. **The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is clear you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to guide them to look at the camera.

D. **Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the person is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.

E. **Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural, as if you are watching them without them knowing.

F. **Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for common expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up.

G. **Situation Interest**  
The background of a photo can add interest. Make sure the background does not distract from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look larger compared to the background.

H. **Interaction**  
Good photos often show people interacting, like talking or laughing together. Look for moments of connection, like eye contact or a handshake.

I. **People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken on trips. To show both the person and the place, step back to include the background. Ask people to stand close to the camera, but make sure the background is still visible.

J. **To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want a clear photo of someone you met on holiday, ask them to pose. For family photos, candid shots of events can be more lively and memorable than formal poses. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Text: Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye and look very real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, Sarah talks about her work.

Not many artists do not sign their work unless someone asks them to. Sarah Janson is one of these artists. She does not think the artist is important; she believes the work is what matters. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and almost makes you think her paintings paint themselves. This makes the interview a bit difficult at first. She says, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she looks scared when asked if she can be photographed.

After a while, Sarah feels more comfortable, and the interview becomes fun and interesting. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she studied drawing at art school for two years and worked in graphic illustration. She did not enjoy illustration, so she started working with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it. She decided to work on her own, not knowing exactly what would happen, but she felt it was the right choice.

Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you. Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation." She believes that you should always keep learning. She is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also admits she struggles with math, especially when she had to measure for a big project at Lulworth Castle.

Sarah often talks about herself in the third person. She says, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'" Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special and different from others. She has many important projects for businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by buildings. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes a hallway look like it leads to two more rooms.

However, trompe-l'oeil can be tricky. Once people understand the trick, they might lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and then engage your imagination." She believes that trompe-l'oeil should also be personal for the client. She enjoys working with clients because that is where the best ideas come from. Some clients know exactly what they want, while others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their ideas.

Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working. Sarah is thankful for her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy. Even though she does not like to talk about her talent, she says, "I really don't like to shout about myself." She believes that both her work and herself should be calm and not too loud. 

In conclusion, you could never really get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be more well-known, and I am happy to share it with others.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman talks about the 'people skills' that are important for success in our jobs.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or by our training, but also by how well we manage ourselves and work with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who will be a great worker and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future jobs. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well in tests is not as important anymore. Now, it is more about social skills and personal qualities, like being proactive, understanding others, being flexible, and convincing people. These skills are called emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important at work. For many years, people have talked about these qualities using different names, like 'character' and 'soft skills'. Now, we have a better understanding of these skills, which we call 'emotional intelligence'. This means being able to understand and manage our own feelings and the feelings of others. In our work, it includes being aware of ourselves, controlling our emotions, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means 'being nice', but it can also mean being honest, even when it is uncomfortable. It is not about showing all our feelings, but about managing them so we can work well together.

C. More businesses are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard to use their knowledge and skills. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job.

D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people get better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our jobs, especially now when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore the human side of work, nothing else will work as well.

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West?**  
Acupuncture is a treatment that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to help with many health problems, but doctors in the West mostly use it for pain relief. Some general doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it often to help with pain.

**A. What is it about?**  
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. They say that energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows in the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ, and many small meridians that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel weak or sick. When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check where the Qi is not balanced. They do this by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and asking about your health, feelings, and habits. An acupuncturist uses very thin needles that go into the skin. They may also use warmth from burning herbs or pressure on certain points to help the flow of Qi.

**B. Over three hundred points**  
The points used in acupuncture are connected to the meridians and may not be close to where you feel pain. People often feel a mild ache or tingling when the needle is moved gently. This can be done by hand or with a machine. Acupuncturists say this feeling means the needle has reached the Qi. There are over three hundred points on the main meridians, and many more that are used less often.

**C. Science explains it**  
Even though not all doctors believe in traditional Chinese medicine, many accept that acupuncture can help with pain. They have found scientific reasons for how it works. For example:  
- It may block pain signals from reaching the brain.  
- It might release natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.

**D. What type of pain can be treated?**  
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. Common pains treated with acupuncture include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say they can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern use for an ancient treatment**  
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China believe in acupuncture. In China today, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, from tonsil removal to heart surgery. Needles can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with medicine. Some people say it helps reduce pain, but it can be different for each person. Many people might not like the idea of being awake during surgery, but acupuncturists say it has fewer side effects than regular anesthesia, and recovery is faster.

**F. Always effective?**  
Like many alternative therapies, it is hard to test acupuncture in studies. But studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find acupuncture helps with chronic pain. Acupuncturists say they have a similar success rate. They know it does not work for everyone. For long-term pain, it usually takes six to seven visits to feel real relief, but some people may feel better after just two or three visits.

**G. A different approach to pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. An acupuncturist looks at the whole person, not just the pain. They spend time finding out what is wrong and what might be causing the pain. They ask questions about how the pain feels and if it gets worse in different weather. These details help them decide how to treat the pain. Most regular doctors do not consider these things.

**H. Traditional or not?**  
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general doctors, prefer scientific explanations. Many traditional acupuncturists believe that using traditional Chinese medicine is the best way to help people heal deeply. It can be hard to measure this in studies. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist, who should send you to a doctor if needed.

The pen is stronger than the psychoanalyst. The study of handwriting to show a person's character is becoming more popular. If you apply for a job in some countries, you will likely be asked to give a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help show some illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can show emotional problems.

More companies are using handwriting analysis to help with job interviews. Many big companies now hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. But many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure if graphology is useful. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if a person should focus on arts or sciences and if they are honest or tricky."

According to Ms. Marne, graphology can help find possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have bad handwriting. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional problems. This can show in childish handwriting and in writing letters many times." She believes she can tell if people are honest or not. 

Ms. Marne says handwriting can also show if someone is under a lot of stress or has violent thoughts. It can even help predict if someone might think about suicide. Heart and lung problems can also be seen in handwriting. She explains, "You cannot make a diagnosis from one sample unless the writing is very shaky. But if the handwriting changes over time, it could mean something serious is happening."

A big emotional problem can change a person's signature for a short time. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people who write with letters that connect are often clever and tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity. Original handwriting shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing shows a person who is a loner. Very small signatures can mean a person feels shy or inferior. Circles over the letter "i" show a need for attention, and crossing the "t" heavily can mean a person is intolerant.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study to analyze handwriting well, along with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She thinks this will happen soon. "It is more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can see a person's history and emotional problems without asking them questions," she says. 

However, there is not much strong evidence to support these ideas. Some psychiatrists are critical of them. They say handwriting is just a result of education and the way writing is taught, and it does not have any other meaning.

Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no mechanical ventilation. The windows open to the street. It is surprising that this office works well, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, just like at home. **Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular in America, where people chew 12 million sticks every day. It is a simple food with less than ten calories per stick. Chewing gum must follow rules from the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials. It has added ingredients to keep the flavor and make it soft. But this was not always true. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath.

American colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans in New England. They chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people sold spruce gum in the eastern United States. This was the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s when people discovered chicle. Chicle is a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to a big industry. However, it is hard to grow sapodilla trees, so many gum makers now use synthetic materials.

Today, the few people who collect chicle, called chicleros, have a tough life. They walk for miles in very humid conditions to find sapodilla trees. There are dangerous snakes and many insects, including a fly that lays eggs in their ears and noses. Chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and forms bricks.

Life at the camp is not easy. Chicleros eat a simple diet of maize and drink local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to save money. Gum makers are also finding new ways to sell their products. They say that chewing gum can help you relax, give you energy, and reduce stress. During the world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the biggest claims is that chewing gum helps reduce tooth decay.

When we eat, plaque acid forms, which can harm our teeth. Our saliva helps protect our teeth by neutralizing the acid and providing minerals. Gum makers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow. Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Today, glycerine and other vegetable oils are used to make gum. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests to their home. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this makes it special.

The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in the south-west of Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along the coast, past empty beaches. The Hotel Splendido has welcomed many famous guests, like movie stars. It used to be a monastery and is now a beautiful hotel. The food is simple and delicious, and the hotel has lovely rugs and homemade pasta.

**Text: Five-Star Hotel with Modern Technology**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.

Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He likes how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.

Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature in any room between 14°C and 25°C.

The hotel has many features for business guests. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the guests will be business travelers. To help them, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.

Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel benefits from having a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Text: 'An Eye for Detail'**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. It is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower beds along the path in the garden have many colors and shapes. This is because the previous owners loved gardening and left plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. 

"In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some things I wanted to add. But when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant." 

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together. Usually, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she says. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in how flowers change as they wilt. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water. After a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they change all the time."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't like garden flowers then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic flowers. I liked wildflowers because they grew in tough places, like cracks in rocks."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude about the garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they don’t break anything. 

With two art shows coming up and many flowers to paint, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**

Many trees in the Brackham area fell down in the strong storms that March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed how the town center looked, and this upset some of the older residents. 

One of these residents was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, he was too sick to notice. Pelham was a big and healthy man, but he was very ill with bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor. He thought the police needed him too much, so he ignored her and tried to keep working. This made him forget things and made him angry. 

Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, he got his medicine and went home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night. Pelham could not believe it. On Thursday evening, he asked if the house was damaged. He was happy to hear it was not and pulled the sheets over his head.

On Saturday, when the medicine started to work and he felt better, he realized that the loss of the walnut tree changed how the living room looked. The Pelhams' big house had a large garden. Pelham was happy he bought it because the garden felt private. But now, the storm changed everything. 

Before, the living room had the beautiful walnut tree outside. The tree let in light but also hid the old furniture that the family brought from their last house. Now, without the tree, the room was too bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded happy. “That’s what I’ve been saying since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Text: Living in the Valley**

We had lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, before winter started. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. 

In the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some strong gusts of wind; the trees moved, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. The river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, was what worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day by day, we saw dark clouds gather over the hills. These clouds looked dangerous and warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing.

Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water rushed down. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen, moving quickly and dangerously.

For three days, we hoped the river would stay below its banks. Luckily, the dam held, and the water began to go down. In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, everything is fine. The water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes.

Thanks to this dam, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home.

It turned out that people liked to have one reviewer for each subject, so Mark chose to focus on films. Without Tom's help, they would not have the current way of working, where Mark writes a long piece each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He did not want to do the usual film critic job, which means watching every new film. That would make him bored quickly. **Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy writes about collecting things and why many people enjoy this hobby. Many adults like to collect items. It is a world of passion and excitement. But if you want to collect something, remember: if you do not love it, do not collect it.

People have always liked to collect. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. This was the first way people gathered objects for fun and meaning. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.

I have been collecting all my life. I collect many things, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a cold, windy place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people in the past. I loved looking at these objects.

Many adults also enjoy collecting. Some people collect because it is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, I just enjoy it. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful items. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had more than 4,000 paintings.

You do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected many different things, like tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I convinced another collector to give me a special tulip. I planted it and took care of it, but one year it disappeared - stolen by another collector.

I once collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost when my house caught fire. The next morning, I saw the remains of my collection and my furniture. I was very sad.

I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet is valuable. As small objects become popular, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I threw away the boxes and the toys!)

**Text: My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I put together temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I read about the subject of the exhibition and talk to important people to find out the main ideas and goals. I decide what objects and pictures should be shown. I make sure the public can understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep the display safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to tell people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning how to make the journeys. They find the best routes, using the right one-way streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like whether to turn right at a junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route. I tell them they must use a different route if the road is closed. This helps them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I work with schools and study centres and run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life under the water. This often changes their views because it is very different from using a computer. I am lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. The downside is that I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money and cannot do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My work is varied. I make sure our publishing program meets market needs and keep about 300 books in stock. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I must respond carefully. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is that there is too much administration, which leaves less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: A Holiday in Ireland**

Every June, we go to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we have spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds, an English couple, bought the house and made some changes, but they did it carefully.

Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still looking for guests. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. Last summer, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible.
