The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. My name is Dorothy Milson, but they call me Milly. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were classmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We think it is a funny coincidence.

"How nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are coming because she is usually waiting in the big hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She named our rooms after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of small details like that; her husband takes care of repairs.

"Welcome!" Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. He smiled widely, making us feel special, not just like any other guests. Everyone smiled, and I could feel that our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year!" she said, making everyone laugh.

Arthur took us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we did not play long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the cliff path to the beach. 

In the morning, we would walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this would happen because we had done the same things every year. Since we first came here, we have all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. "I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can sleep up to 18 guests. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "I hate coming to a messy kitchen in the morning," she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great," she says.

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas and might go to G Jay's or Dick's T-Bar later. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready," she says. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. At around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at about 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after dinner, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Simplified Text:**

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research about the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions on the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class. Years ago, Marie's father had shown those children how he made gloves. He showed them the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie thought the hot hands looked strange and called them "pancake hands."

Seymour heard Rita ask, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, "They go to the tannery first. The tannery makes the leather for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I worked there for six months when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," Rita said. 

"Well, you should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can help you set that up. It's a tough job, but the technology has improved. What you will see is not very different from what people saw hundreds of years ago. Tanning is one of the oldest industries. They found 6,000-year-old tools for tanning in Turkey. The first clothes were just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s an interesting subject. My father knows a lot about leather. If you talk to him about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemen love their work. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?"

"I can't say I have," she replied.

"Never seen anything made?" he asked.

"I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child," she said.

He laughed. She made him laugh. She was eager to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but Rita reminded him of Marie. She had the same good-natured intelligence that filled their home with joy when Marie came back from school. Marie remembered everything and wrote it down neatly in her notebook.

"I have an idea," he said. "We will show you the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Simplified Text:**

**Is it a tough job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there is one small problem - she does not like flying. "On a long trip to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings, and making travel plans. She did not apply for this job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance and got the job. She also took a secretarial course at night classes. Five years later, she became a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because he loves golf. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee and a part of the winnings. Most caddies earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but they spend a lot on travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he says. His skills in accounting were noticed, and now he works as a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the games, which are important for TV commentators and golfers.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food in fancy restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "If people can pay, it is their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." He got a food column from a friend who was an editor. At that time, he worked in advertising and it helped him earn extra money. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant I would earn less money," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay healthy by cycling to the nearest subway station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's story." Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually write in the mornings. I do not wake up very early. After lunch, I spend a few hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old typewriter instead of a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and that is the best part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help."

Text: 'In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building with two floors. Outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains and covered the yard down to the blue lake. One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored. They followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. 

Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." He jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards." He encouraged his friends to jump. They looked scared at first, but one by one, they jumped down and smiled with relief. 

In the warm sunlight, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes. Then one friend said, "Let’s go up to the roof again and jump down." They were not very excited, but they went up and started jumping off. Soon, only Michael was left on the roof. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What’s wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to jump down, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and then jump, but he couldn’t. His friends began to laugh at him because he was taking too long. They shouted, "Come on, you’re a coward! Do you think we will sit here all night?" When he didn’t move, they started to walk away, still shouting. 

Michael felt sad and alone. He stared at the ground for a long time. The sun was setting, getting bigger and bigger. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped off the roof into the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 

As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn’t jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, "You should be able to get home on time. If you won’t come home, you can stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair. She looked serious, but Michael didn’t really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.'

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. First, you will write a short history of yourself. Then, you will take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will get a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers. 

I tried Career Analysts, a big organization that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard to understand. They included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He used my test results to make a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was surprised to learn that I did not do well in the scientific and technical tests. I was glad to hear that I made the right choice in wanting to be a journalist.

Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a good chance for me to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I didn’t know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of retraining in design and my money situation," she said. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her current skills and move to a job that suited her better. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she really wanted to do. She has sent many friends there, and they are all happy with the service.

Some people feel they would not have made changes without help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services and made important decisions. "After working at a bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I didn’t know what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences," she said. "I had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped me remember what I said. After the fourth meeting, I decided I wanted to study geology and start a degree later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. I am much happier now."

However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. I got many new ideas, but I didn’t like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself. You have to share a lot of personal information, and I felt that a friend would have given me the same advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's**

If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make the office a place where people feel safe. That is why he does not wear a white coat. He believes that dental visits should be relaxing and enjoyable.

Many people think dental visits are painful or very serious. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ideas is to use virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular." Patients wear the headsets during their check-up. They sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while Jerome checks their teeth. The headset also shows a special camera that lets patients see inside their mouths.

Most patients like this part of their visit. The office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. He knows that the smell of a dentist can make people nervous. I thought the nice smell in the office was very pleasant.

Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, but he takes his work seriously. The relaxation ideas are important, but good treatment is the most important thing. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a little strange at first, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental techniques. He says, "When you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too." He believes that his way of treating patients is changing the serious style of British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers him a cup of tea, and asks what video he would like to watch. He gently leads the patient to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it feels more like a nice beauty salon than a regular dental office.

**Text: Bitter Water Becomes Popular**

Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is about eight percent of all chocolate sales in a year. People eat more chocolate at Christmas than at any other time.

The cacao plant, which is used to make chocolate, was first grown by the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South America, Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. The fruit of the cacao tree is big and has 20-40 seeds inside. When these seeds are dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, these are often called cocoa beans. This name is a mistake from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language. They added spices to the drink for special occasions and to welcome guests. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took a long time for this recipe to reach the rest of Europe.

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in big cities in Europe where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, people made chocolate drinks from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. 

The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate and sugar to make a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk to make milk chocolate. At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies were very popular in the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract customers with a French name. 

Cadbury then created the Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside, making it popular against French brands. Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. This has made chocolate companies look for new ways to attract customers. One new idea is to turn chocolate bars into ice cream, drinks, or desserts for people who want something different.

However, cacao farmers are still struggling because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small cacao farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old and is a master at making art from shells. He has many ideas for new projects, like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he focuses on creating beautiful objects from shells. 

As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring at all; he is very enthusiastic and charming. He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them." Peter never planned to sell his work, but five years ago, some friends told him he should have an exhibition. They helped him talk to an art gallery owner.

His first exhibition was in London, and 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices for his art are high, around £2,000 for some pieces. There are 86 items in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices, but he knows his work is unique. The gallery owner told him that one day, people will want his pieces even more because he will stop making them.

Peter wishes he had started making art from shells earlier in his life. He believes he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels he cannot work as easily as he could when he was younger. His work is very different from the common shell crafts found in seaside shops. He has a "miniature mind," which helps him create boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.

Peter has his own way of working and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His attention to detail and color makes his work look very special.

Peter travels to many places to find beautiful shells, including France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He lies on the beach to look for shells to take home. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures inside. He explains that many people walk on the beach and break shells, and the sea also breaks them. He believes it is okay to collect shells that are no longer homes for sea creatures. His argument is strong, especially when you see how beautiful his work is.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is 15 years old. When she is not traveling to exciting places and being on magazine covers, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

The receptionist at the agency said, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I replied, "Oh, fine, no problem." I was trying to think that all the bad things I had read about models were not true, but I kept thinking of words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent. I wondered how late she would be. Would it be one hour? Three hours? Maybe she would not come at all. What if she thought going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, walked in, she was smiling and relaxed. She was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive clothes; she had on a simple black dress and trainers. She was very friendly, very tall, and very pretty. All models under 16 must bring an adult with them when they work. Kira's mother looked proud of her daughter.

Kira seemed a little confused by her new fame, which is normal because it was not planned. Her older sister suggested that she enter the model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent some photos anyway. When Kira learned she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she did very well. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it hard to manage her two lives. Her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. Kira says, "They're really proud of me." However, some unkind people at her school say rude things about her success. They say she thinks too highly of herself. This must be hard for Kira because she is not a selfish person. She says, "They think that because I am a model now, I cannot stay the same. But the only thing that has changed is that I am more confident. I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call her at any time and ask her to work the next day. Kira says, "If my friends are going out, I can't say I will come because I don't know what I will do the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes change. But my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you are always going off to model now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career. Not many people can say that before they finish their school exams. At the end of the interview, I asked her what she would like to do if she did not have her beauty. She paused and replied, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to hot Africa to find gold. The father and son team - one is an explorer and the other is a mineral expert - think their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they believe they are very close to a five million dollar gold vein.

"As we dig, we are finding a lot of gold; now we just need to dig a bit more to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool. They have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold worth millions of pounds hidden in the 'Dolgellau gold belt', an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to study.

Since they first cleared the land and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent ten years getting permission to work from the landowners, taking samples of the earth, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-metre shaft. Now they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a bit deeper to where the gold is.

Chris Madden says, "Right now, this looks doubtful, but we have some people we can contact." As news spread about their dig, many people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. "It would bring more people here if they are right," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope many people do not come and dig up the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined a lot since the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. Now, individual gold-diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's exciting to uncover hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and does research about marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. 

When she is not teaching, Rachel goes into a small steel vehicle to dive three kilometres down into the ocean. This vehicle is the size of a small car. Inside, there is very little space. Rachel can touch the two pilots who are with her. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. 

A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, which goes quickly to the surface. Rachel says, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very nice trip."

Rachel remembers her first dive. She got into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that were blowing out black smoke. 

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" Black smokers are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. This water comes out at a speed of one metre per second and is 350 degrees hot.

Rachel felt scared during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was incredible!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she finally saw them, it was an amazing feeling.

Text: "I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by different train times, money, and languages. 'Never again,' I said as I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Sleeping in a train corridor is very different from sleeping in a bed. The train moves you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply. You might waste things, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away books you have read. But this is part of the fun of Inter-Rail. You can forget about rules and just enjoy the trip. All you need is that ticket in your hand. 

This ticket lets young people travel to many countries in one day. On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to travel more. There was always one more country to visit, and it did not cost us anything extra. 

We were not only interested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw the most interesting sights. We wanted to do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like many other Inter-Railers who shared the train with us. 

The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only knew by name. When the train arrives at the station, you see the city for the first time. You can only understand Europe by seeing it, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different lifestyles. Everyone knows about Europe, but it is not real until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. 

While the train trip may not show you new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to see it, even if it did not happen for us right away."

Text: 

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage is missing is very disappointing. You may have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a different place with a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather.

Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes, and they cannot always promise that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for bags to be checked and loaded onto the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change from one flight to another. This time is often longer to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights. These issues can cause bags to be lost. Human mistakes can also happen, like if a bag's label gets torn off. 

Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because they handle many bags. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with many moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4.

Even busy airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The chance of losing luggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers quickly connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, and include your flight numbers.

If your luggage is still missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before you leave the airport.

**Text: The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees grow over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The sounds of water in the breeze are gentle. The kingfisher moves quickly and straight, like a flash of light. It is gone in a second, but you can still remember it because it is so special. 

Charlie James loved kingfishers when he was young. He feels very strongly about this little bird, but he cannot say exactly why. The kingfisher is part of many stories. In Greek mythology, the kingfisher is a moon goddess that became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, while its bottom was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this story. Kingfishers do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the way their feathers are made scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich green depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. They are shy birds, but you can watch them easily from a hiding place. Charlie James's first hiding place was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in a few minutes and sat very close to him. But it took him four more years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became very important in his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream where kingfishers lived. However, school took away some of his time with the birds. He missed classes and called himself an "academic failure." But people noticed his interest in the kingfisher, which is the most common kingfisher in the world and the only one that breeds in Europe. 

At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and later became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the best kingfisher film. "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has loved for many years. His photographs show some of his feelings, but Charlie knows there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.

A. **ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up helping as an assistant. Later, she had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. "I wasn't nervous. I always felt good about standing in front of an orchestra," she said. Manson is from America and works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has helped Abbado on many projects.

B. **ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. He is thankful for the timing: "If I had won earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he finds it hard to shake off the "competition" label. "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried," he said. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting him back, which is good for his career.

C. **WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice time needed for opera. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," she said. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was important for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from bigger people, which makes a big difference." She likes the complex nature of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to think about the singers' personalities."

D. **ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says conducting surprised him, but he finds it fascinating. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and tried my best to get the performance I wanted. People respect my skills as a musician. I learn from every experience I have had, both in music style and performing. Now, I will do whatever people ask me to find out what I enjoy."

E. **WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and told his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London at short notice, which was a tough start. He had to deal with some relaxed musicians reading newspapers during the show. "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and did my best," he said. Many musicians do not seem to need advice from a conductor, but he is not afraid to say what he wants. "I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, which was very popular. For older children, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I wanted to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could be more exciting, and the scenery was not great. But the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and were happy there were places to rest. The park looked nice, and the staff were friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is very fun. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that waiting for rides is not boring. It is very clean, and the staff are nice. One time, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit scared of rides, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but if you are brave, it looked fun. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it too easy, but they loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very big, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was worse! There are many main rides, and the older children went on them several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were nice sometimes, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have told the kids we were going home early.

**Text: Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside.

A. "My customers are friends," says CHRISTINE HOGAN. She runs a computer design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted to work from home. I had worked with computers before I got married, so my husband suggested I start a computer design business. It needed a lot of money, and it was hard at first. But I was careful and told the bank manager if I might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is still a small business. We hardly ever deliver work; people from the area come to pick it up."

B. "I enjoy being independent," says MAGGY SASANOW. She works from home as a designer of greeting cards. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there were no jobs like that. So, I started my own business and make 50 different greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working from home is that there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I don’t advertise; my business comes from word of mouth. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I don’t share ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad."

C. "It has been hard at times," says DELIA TURNER. She makes curtains and has had good and bad times. "I started my business eight years ago. At that time, this type of business was growing, and in two years, my income went from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to have six full-time curtain makers, but I had to let them go because the economy got worse. It was hard because it is not easy to find other jobs here. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I have to lower my prices when needed and look for new opportunities."

D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, it was cheaper than London, and second, I love the countryside. I like being able to work when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at strange times. The bad thing is that I need to be disciplined to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I had all my work experience in London, so I felt very alone at first."

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business that sends cakes by post and has a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I care about health, so I began making fruit cakes with good quality flour and eggs. Then friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building, and now everything is made there. We have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don’t bake anymore; I manage the business. My biggest problem has been the money side of the business, which has been hard because we didn’t have a lot of money to start."

**Text: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is very special. The sons are musicians and composers, and their dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins are schoolteachers in South Wales. They wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but it was too expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He found a school nearby that teaches how to make instruments. He took evening classes for about three years. 

After making some violins, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. He made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching and makes violins full-time. He sells about twelve violins a year. One of his violins was sold to a famous American player, Jaime Laredo.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers, "I played the piano as soon as I could reach the keys." He tried the violin but did not like it. Instead, he liked the cello player in his dad's music group. When he was six or seven, he started taking cello lessons.

Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive. I wanted to be like Paul, but I did not feel pushed." Huw is now a pianist and composer.

Paul used his dad's cello to win a music competition. At just 20 years old, he became the main cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his dad's cello until last year. Now, he has a different cello that is very old, made by Francesco Rugeri. 

Paul will soon play this cello on television in a concert. He says, "I will play it my way." However, he cannot watch himself on TV because he is performing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also perform his String Quartet in London at the same time. John and Hetty will have to be very busy to keep up with all their sons' music events!

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust.

Gareth says that a National Trust Warden needs common sense. "You also need to be good with people," he explains. "You work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies." Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he did not have formal training.

Gareth says, "It helps that I still farm with my parents. I can talk to farmers and understand their problems." His farming background also helps him with the physical work, like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since he started working for the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers when he was young, he picked flowers, collected butterfly eggs, and found birds' nests. Now, he wonders where he can find those things. He believes farming has changed the countryside, but it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government rules.

At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. Gareth says, "We are close to bringing them together." 

Gareth's job includes conservation, allowing people to visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to make sure work gets done well and without too much trouble," he says. He enjoys seeing projects finished, but he spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to people, but some visitors can be difficult. "Some people come in, ask for everything, and then leave as if they own the place. It can be annoying!" he admits. But Gareth believes that common sense is important.

If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to apply to be a warden like Gareth. But be ready; it may take a long time to find a job on the Lleyn Peninsula!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. 

"Don't you get strange looks?" I asked her. She replied, "I am too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that’s all."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She is following a strict schedule to be very fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They are very skilled," Kendra said. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But Kendra knows the Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But in the Championships, you have only one chance."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You train hard to win," Kendra said. "But after the game, we are all friends."

Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "It is important that we think and train like world-class players," Kendra said. "As captain, I need to have a strong mind and lead by example. I want to support and encourage my team."

Kendra said, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned carefully. I decided that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents may not see their child's talent until they become frustrated and act out. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special support that regular schools may not provide. 

Children who are musically talented can benefit from going to a specialist music school. There are five of these schools in Britain. They help children aged seven to eighteen develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. 

At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, and practice singing and music theory. They also practice in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. Some students can study more subjects if they want.

All five specialist music schools in Britain are independent. This means they are not part of the government school system. The classes are small, so teachers can give more attention to each student. Most children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be around other children who love music too.

However, there are some problems. One big issue is the cost; it can be very expensive (around £12,000 to £17,000 a year for students who live at the school). The schools try to help with scholarships and financial aid for families with talented children. Also, not all parents want to send their young children to live at school. Many school directors worry about admitting children as young as seven because it can be a tough environment. They want to help children grow up to be well-rounded individuals.

It is important to know that being in a special music school can be stressful. Some children may lose their musical talent as they grow older. The pressure to succeed can also make them feel like they are failing. However, the schools watch each student closely and offer help when needed.

Many former students say they learned a lot from the music schools, but some think it is not good to focus too much on music and not enough on other subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school. Because of this, it might be better to wait until a child is older to decide if they should go to a specialist school. 

Children who are good at both music and academics can do well in regular schools that have good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges. However, this option may not be possible for families who live far from big cities like London.

**Text: 'An Eye for Detail'**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. It is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower beds along the path in the garden have many colors and shapes. This is because the previous owners loved gardening and left plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. 

"In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some things I wanted to add. But when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant." 

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together. Usually, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she says. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in how flowers change as they wilt. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water. After a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change all the time."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't like garden flowers then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic flowers. I liked wildflowers because they grew in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they don’t break anything. 

With two art shows coming up and many flowers to paint, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. "I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can sleep up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than a messy kitchen in the morning," she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great," she says.

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas and might go to G Jay's or Dick's T-Bar later. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, Sarah starts work early. Breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. "We clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready," she says. If she has not done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it now. 

At around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at about 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the guests are confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she says. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis and then gets a lift back to the chalet.

Soon, it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she chats with friends, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but here I was rushing around. Some people on the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like seeing how magazines work, but I enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. When I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was very dirty, but I had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes do not see daylight at work. It was hard work, but it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I did not think gardening would be so hard, so I will not quit my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on the TV show Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would faint during some jobs, but I was okay. The nurses are friendly, and it felt very different from my usual job with men. I feel my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but it made me feel good."

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different. People looked at me. Before the flight, our supervisor told us about safety, which I knew from my training. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who would not sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I do not exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I saw that some trainers did not eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I would not change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails**

Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys with Andrew Morgan.

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to go back as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes along the coast that goes to Italy. It takes you past beautiful sea views. It does not matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; it is always lovely. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and houses in France. You feel like you are looking into the homes of rich people. The travelers are always lively because there are many tourists and locals, all enjoying the beautiful journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was too young and was sent to my aunt's house. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still had not traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I ever saw, and its big glass roof amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am thankful for one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely as we traveled through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding plans.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would wait for days if people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream, like traveling on the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but I do not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It was not until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that had a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old train line that volunteers had taken care of. That is where my love for steam trains began. When we were not filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I went back last year, it felt like time had not changed. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Text: 'Want to Get Published?**

If you want to publish your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some advice for you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" 

First, you need to research where to send your work. You should learn about publishers and practice your writing skills. Writing well takes time and knowledge. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. 

One of the best ways to learn is by reading. Go to your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading many different things will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers want. 

This knowledge should be updated often because new magazines and books come out all the time. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to give them what they want. 

If you are not sure what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories. Get recent copies of these magazines and read them. Learn about the kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. 

These readers expect different things, and the editor wants to meet their needs. Sometimes, new writers send me their stories and ask, "This has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I never want to discourage anyone, but it is likely that their work is not ready to be published. 

Many new writers are too eager to send their work out too soon. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been writing for years before they got published. 

When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. Your skills and confidence will grow. 

Don’t throw away any of your stories; instead, try to improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others in the beginning. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 

Do everything you can to improve as a writer. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you can’t find one, try joining a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence from other writers. 

Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**Text:**

On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting at the Baltimore train station for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station did not feel clean and bright like usual. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and many college students had their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around and talking to different people. He looked rich: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft coat. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but to New York. Then he asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to Wilmington. 

I was going to Philadelphia, too. I thought he could have asked me, but he looked at me quickly and walked away. He looked stressed. He asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She was about thirty-five years old and looked like a teacher. She said yes. The man then asked her for a favor. I stood a little away and pretended to look at my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. 

The man said, “My daughter is flying out this afternoon from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and then went home. My wife was upset because my daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station and didn’t know what to do.” The woman listened and seemed sympathetic. I thought it was better to stay quiet and see what he would say next. 

The man continued, “I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport.” I thought it was strange he didn’t go himself if it was so important. The woman asked, “Why don’t you go yourself?” He replied, “I can’t leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair.” I thought this was not a good excuse. 

I looked at the man. He was holding a padded envelope, not a plain one. It was the size of a small book and looked stapled shut. I thought to myself, “Be careful, lady.”

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary got his chance to cook, and John got his chance to run a restaurant. When John heard about a restaurant for sale, he went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was perfect for him.

Running the restaurant made John think of his childhood. He remembers his mother working in a factory and how sad he felt when he was left alone. He wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money while he ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. They talked to the customers from a young age, which was good for them.

Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a corner bath and hurt himself. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend. He was disciplined and woke up early. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.

Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adult cooks and sometimes was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and has his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary’s cooking if the music becomes successful. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time. John told him that if he wanted to succeed, he needed to do it by age 30. If not, it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he finished his work quickly and even helped other students. Everyone is surprised by how successful Gary’s TV cooking show has become. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that to get what you want, you must work hard because no one gives you anything. Gary has seen his chance and worked hard for it. John believes that even if children only remember a little of what you say, it is still good. He thinks Gary must have listened sometimes.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is through friends. If you know someone who knows someone who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have any friends to help you. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown place. She felt nervous when she got on the train to go there for work. She didn’t think about why she was going. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to go to new places and have exciting lives. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel forever. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to the post office where she worked, and it seemed perfect. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people would like her. 

There was no line for this flat because it was not just a flat for rent; it was looking for a third girl to share. The mention of "own television" made Jo worry it might be too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf was coming down the stairs. "It’s a bad place," she told Jo. "Both girls are awful." 

"Oh," said Jo and kept climbing the stairs. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand her." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around and made a face, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh voice. We don’t want her here, do we, Pauline?" 

Pauline had a very colorful shirt and bright hair. Jo thought she looked like a punk. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one before. 

"I’m Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat." 

Nessa said they were about to have tea. She got three mugs; one said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the last one said "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We go to see them in seaside places, movies, and TV shows. But according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the decline of dolphins.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals, they can feel human emotions, and they make us dream of freedom in the ocean. This love for dolphins has grown because of TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. However, these happy images hide the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas.

The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals are protected by law and cared for in special marine areas. But this is not true, and the lack of protection may lead to a big wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We see them only in small groups, and we know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress.

It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are going down. Overfishing is taking away many fish from the sea, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken from one area, they may not have enough time to find food in another area. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. In modern fishing, large nets are often left in the water or pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have been found on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins can pass these poisons to their babies through their milk. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another big problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise pollution from ships and oil wells may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet know.

**Getting Fit**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels busy and stressful. Many articles talk about fitness because it is really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.

Exercise helps your muscles and can change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also help prevent injuries. Exercise can improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood flow.

You may have heard these reasons before, but here is something new: exercise can help with feelings of sadness and tiredness. It can also help you sleep better and reduce stress. Exercise can even help with some health problems. 

If you are not convinced yet, remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. Be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is important. It affects how you look and feel. If you slouch, try to imagine a balloon pulling you up. This can help you stand taller and breathe better. Good posture also makes your body look slimmer.
