Stretching is also important. It helps you move better and keeps your muscles from getting hurt. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. Stretching should be done slowly and carefully.

A good exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, working out, and cooling down.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is not easy to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost non-stop rain. This has caused some problems. Newman said they had to buy a special piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has made some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, looking for another shy animal, the jackal.

Traveling film-makers have been moving around the world to film wild animals since television started. I talked to Newman about his work with Amanda while he was at a safari lodge, having a rare break with other people. "We do have some arguments, but we get over them quickly," he said about his partner. They do not see one another as the leader. Newman believes they work well together because they both understand the animals in a similar way. "When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a more fixed camp. We leave at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask." Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a bit stressful," Newman said. 

It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would often go off alone, but when she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even their car. 

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one place to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I have worked well together from the beginning," Newman said, "because we have the same ideas and vision. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t see much else. I might notice cars slowing down, but that’s all."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part. "We will have home support, which is special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They are very skilled." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. Kendra explained that the Championships will be tough. "You must push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you have only one chance."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose." But after the game, everyone is friendly. 

Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is important that we think and train like world-class players." As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mind and lead by example. "I support and encourage my team," she said.

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and does research about marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle to dive three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very small. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up to the surface.

If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, and it goes quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice journey.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor who explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was leaving some equipment to study a project that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where hot water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water comes out very quickly and is very hot, at 350 degrees.

The only time Rachel felt scared was when she dived with an American team. They were using a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a loud bang, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt a huge relief.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She knows that no one else has seen them before. Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she finally saw them in real life, it was an incredible feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and our words.

Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree. When she graduated, she felt very confident. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she knew it would make her late. She believes it is important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think what is inside is important, but in an interview, you should try to look your best."

Many people do not understand how important a professional image is. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. She was shocked because she does a very good job, and she thought how she dresses should not matter.

Movement and gestures also affect how an interviewer sees a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how excited she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have gotten more if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report will tell you about what the company does. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the city, I found it was no longer fun to work there. I wanted to stay for five or ten more years, but then I lost my job suddenly. I did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start my farm. I met the head chef of a local hotel, which is one of the best in the country. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I am happy to be out of the office, but I still work long hours, about 80 to 90 a week, and I am still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He says, "I started painting as a hobby, but I enjoyed it much more than my job. It made sense to leave my job and become an artist. A career counselor helped me a lot. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I got married young, and our children are grown, so we could take this chance. We moved to the north of England, where we did not know anyone. We left our friends, but we are lucky that they still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but I worked too many hours. I did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but I never did. I have deadlines to keep me busy. In fashion, there are always new collections and designs to work on, so I have a lot to do. I feel happier now and less stressed. I do miss talking to colleagues. I love that I am responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When I worked for a company, I cared, but now I care even more because my name is on everything."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I worked in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I did not find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited many gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change my career, so I took courses in massage. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control now, and I have peace of mind. That is the best part."

**Text: 'Dedicated to their sports'**

**Four young sports stars talk about their lives.**

**A Darius (runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My best moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, not many people noticed, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there because the athletics facilities are great and the nightlife is exciting. But I have to be very disciplined. If my friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but being dedicated helps me in this sport. My main goal is to get to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

**B Gabriel (surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are in the morning, so I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. But it is worth it because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning that championship helped me get a chance to present a surfing show on TV. Now, I guess I am a bit of a celebrity.

**C Dieter (yacht racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes, reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so it is nice to come back and hang out with my friends who do different things. You cannot always focus on the sport; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but I am not recognized much in the street. I would not like to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from fans who want signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.

**D Tomas (tennis player)**  
It feels great to walk on the court and feel the crowd cheering for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But it has some problems. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you need to be serious and professional. It does not bother me too much. I want to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, because that happens early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and if I give in to their requests, I feel bad about buying unhealthy food. I don’t like saying no all the time, and I get worried before we go shopping. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I also think they need to learn how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big place for this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see fun ads on TV.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with ads and often disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks about food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their requests: "My son listens to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels. I have talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have less conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him the sweets he wants because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am in a good mood, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands might attract more customers.

**Text: Five-Star Hotel with Modern Technology**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.

Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He likes how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.

Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature from 14°C to 25°C.

Business guests will find many useful technologies in their rooms. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from these guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. They have added extra cables for new technology. They rent televisions so they can replace them with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.

Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved it. The hotel has better parking than before. This helps the hotel offer a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy in life.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I like to do things that are challenging. When I learn something new, I feel very energetic. I also get energy from rhythm. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dance is fun and gives me energy. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something useful, even a little, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love my job, so it does not feel hard. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need a good amount of sleep. When I sleep six hours a night, I feel a bit tired. I know exercise gives me energy, but I need to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthily for energy. I think my energy comes from being positive and enthusiastic. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life. Enjoyment is important. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many lively young people, which gives me energy. I like taking photos, but I’m not sure if I’m good at it. I also write words for fun, like imaginary songs, when I travel."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do, both at work and at home. Being positive helps me. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural feeling that comes from talking to others. Smiling at people makes me feel good. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a special exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "I love making a garden from nothing. I once turned a concrete area into a garden by breaking the concrete and adding soil. This gives me more energy than exercise. I also feel energized when I know someone wants to read my writing. I enjoy sneaking into a farmer's land or a forest. If someone sees me, I say, 'Oh, what a lovely place! I didn’t know it was private.' I like this because it feels playful."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I think it is important to care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like the time they took. You have a limited amount of energy, so use it for what is most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has a history of thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around the year 200 AD. In Scandinavia, skating was an important skill for the upper classes. 

In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish, but in 1924, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie changed this. She made skating more athletic and popular. Today, skating combines art and sports. It is both beautiful and physically challenging. 

For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can only go faster when you get better. The way you position your body helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed. Your body should lean a little forward. 

Relaxation is very important for skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. When you push with your back foot, make a small movement with the other foot. If you practice this, you can slowly make bigger movements as you get better. 

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater needs. Even professional skaters fall. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. 

Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn freestyle. 

With good instruction at ice rinks, you can quickly learn the basic moves. You will see that good skaters are relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate when your body is stiff, so warm-up exercises are important. Focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness. 

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also helps your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Bills**

If you want to see something that makes people cry happy tears, it is a talented child winning a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars and their mothers to talk about their lives.

A. Annika Reeder, 15, won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time. When I feel very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes you stiff."

B. Annika's mother said, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I have seen some parents push their children, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy. You have to want to do it yourself. People say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has friends from all over the world and is very confident."

C. Sarah Stokes started show-jumping at ten years old. Since then, she has won the British National Championship. "It’s good that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love show-jumping. Even if my parents were not there, I would still do it because I am very determined. I am happy when they are proud of me, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. Sarah's mother said, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she loved it. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we have to travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is always happy on a horse and knows what to do. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."

E. Jane McShane, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are very friendly. I know everyone, and it is fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I am not scared of being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."

F. Jane's mother said, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. When she wins, I am happy, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is special. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

**Simplified Text:**

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain.

Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are now getting better food than before, which is helping us grow taller. Professor Chris Stringer says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Now, most of the world's land is used for farming, and three main plants—wheat, rice, and maize—give us more than half of our food. This limited diet has hurt our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Even though corn was not good for health, farming spread because it could feed many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are still not getting enough good food, but in Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are getting better. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good change, but there are still problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less room for legs on planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often.

The question is: how tall can we get? Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, while some people are getting taller because of better food, as a whole, humans are actually getting smaller. 

10,000 years ago, during the last ice age, people were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even with good food. As the planet gets hotter, we might get even smaller. So, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming. 

**Questions:**

1. How tall is Chris Greener?
2. What did Chris want to be when he grew up?
3. What are the three main plants that provide most of our food today?
4. What happened to people's health when they started farming corn?
5. In which countries are diets getting better?

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"

Some people think that studio audiences are not important. They say that even people who work in television do not respect them. I thought that studio audiences were just made up of silly people who wanted to be on TV. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds and jobs. Television wants to attract different people for different shows.

Many people who watch TV at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for a long time in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came because it was a chance to be on television."

Another idea is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket." Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when you see them. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live television. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Text: Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which I later became known for.

**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive than regular tickets. The view is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closely for something new.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open moorland, perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was excited because she found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals that come to visit us for a short time. 

I got home late. I quickly put a pot on the stove to boil. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino the cat and Bianca the white mouse, which was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room. He was trying to find a way out while avoiding the kids' arms.

I jumped into the room and tripped over something. I fell on the floor. I saw the snake escaping from the table and slithering all over the floor. The snake was moving fast, and the kids were jumping around, screaming. The dog was barking loudly. The pot on the stove boiled over, and I ran to turn it off. 

I caught Domino by the tail and saved the small, wet mouse from his mouth. The same mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life. After saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and had no weak points. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, moving back and forth. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body. 

I carefully lifted the snake and stood up. I walked to the end of the garden and pointed the snake towards a tree, hoping it would be happy there. When I let go of the snake's head, it surprised me by sliding over my shoulders like a colorful shawl. 

We stood together in the evening light: four young children, Mum, and the snake. My oldest child, DJ, said, "Mum, you are nice and warm, and the shed is not." I asked the children to help me encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake's tail went away, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Text: 'Write to Me!'**

In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming rare. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who sent it, and happiness in reading it. Writing letters has been part of my life for a long time. It started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for gifts, no matter how short or messy they were.

When I left home at 18 to study in London, I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too, and I loved his funny letters. Most letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than by talking. I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it’s even better to get news from a whole year! I love getting letters in airmail envelopes with pretty stamps.

I get letters from friends in different countries. One friend is in Sri Lanka, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There is also a lady in France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant while on holiday. If I hadn’t asked for her address, I would not have been able to write to her. Luckily, she replied, and now we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her, and we have visited each other.

My best letter-writing moment was this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that we kept in touch for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us!

I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, set up by my penfriend. I encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks in France are being damaged. There are about 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps. Scientists are worried that these drawings will not last for future generations. The mountain has drawings that are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. 

More and more tourists visit the site, but some of them are ruining the pictures by writing on them. Jean Clottes, who is the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think these pictures will always be here. But if the damage continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and damaging them. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. 

When tourists cannot take a good photo, they rub the drawings to make them clearer. The weather makes the drawings smooth, but when the sun shines, some visitors rub them to see them better. Some people even bring sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts have different ideas about how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, who is the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way to save the site is to make it a "no-go" area. This means only guided tours would be allowed. He believes that if we do not protect the site, it will be destroyed, and important research will stop. 

Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says it is too strict and will upset local people. The site was made a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we should do our best to save it. 

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He thinks that it is hard to stop visitors from damaging it because the area is very big. He would like everyone to see it, but there is not enough money to hire guards. They might have to charge a fee to visit. 

Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that it will be damaged more as it becomes easier for tourists to visit. She believes the best solution is to block off the area and have guides. She says, "We need to find money because this area is a historic site. If we do not act, we will lose the drawings for future generations." 

**Questions:**

1. How many drawings are there in Mont Bego?
2. What do the drawings show?
3. What does Jean Clottes say about the future of the drawings?
4. What does Henry de Lumley suggest to protect the site?
5. Why is Annie Echassoux worried about the site?

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and if I say yes, I feel guilty about giving them unhealthy food. I don’t like saying no all the time, and I get worried before we go shopping. I try to avoid taking them, but then I feel bad because they need to learn how to make choices. I can’t win."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big place for this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents’ reasons, like how bad sugar is for teeth, are not convincing when children see fun ads on TV.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel they are competing with ads and often disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks about food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their requests: "My son listens to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and read labels together. I’ve talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have less conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am in a good mood, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could bring in more customers.

**Text: Climbing Walls**

Climbers used to go to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is excited. High above them on a climbing wall is the French climber, Francois Lombard. He is in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall.

In the past, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good places to climb. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls using special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had problems. These walls were only straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material that looked like the shapes on cliffs. This material could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to use steel frames to build climbing walls. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could make overhanging walls without a lot of construction. This system allowed climbers to have many different holds to use.

**Text: 'So you want to be an actor'**

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is a risky job. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are many actors, but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy, but others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. It is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own dreams. 

There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no tests to pass, and finishing your training does not guarantee you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.

Many people want to know what talent is. Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person's courage and belief in what they do. 

Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. 

If you ask successful actors how they did it, they might not know. They understand some things about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they must keep working hard because their fame can change quickly. 

Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without a job, doing other work. Then, you may get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job very much, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often do not talk about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected. 

From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.

**Food for All**

We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available.

A. When you think of a famous TV cook and writer, you might think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world. She loves exciting food and knows what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a must-have for modern cooks. It gives simple and expert advice on cooking, with many great recipes that are not boring. The book has been updated and is the best choice if you could only have one cookbook.

B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of a well-known French restaurant in Britain. Now, he has a book to go with his first TV show called "Blanc Mange." Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and teaches some basic food science. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that means the best in French cooking. For 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students to be great cooks. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which has 100 of the school's best recipes. The recipes are classic but still fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed to make dishes healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then has sections for Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have shared their famous recipes and secrets in this book.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes you can make tasty food in the same time it takes to get a pizza. He has already written two successful books about this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and friendly way, sharing over 200 recipes from around the world. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t love good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are delicious!

**Simplified Text:**

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is 228 cm tall, making him the tallest man in Britain.

Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe gets a little taller. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are starting to lose the effects of bad diets from the past. Professor Chris Stringer says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again," who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Now, most of the world's land is used for farming, and three main plants—wheat, rice, and maize—give more than half of the food we eat today. This limited diet has hurt our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be good, it caused health problems. Farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are still not well-nourished, but some countries like those in Europe, the US, and Japan are starting to eat better again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good change, but it also brings problems. 

Even though people are getting taller, beds have not changed in size since 1860. Also, there seems to be less space for legs on planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often. 

The question is: how tall can we get? Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, they also say that while some people are getting taller because of better food, as a group, we might actually be getting shorter. 

10,000 years ago, during the last ice age, people were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. If the planet keeps getting warmer, we might get even shorter. So, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming. 

**Questions:**

1. How tall is Chris Greener today?
2. What did Chris want to be when he left school?
3. What are the three main plants that provide most of our food today?
4. What happened to hunter-gatherers when they started farming corn?
5. What is the average height of men in the US?

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the city, I found it was no longer fun to work there. I wanted to stay for five or ten more years, but then I lost my job suddenly. I did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start my farm. I met the head chef of a local hotel, which is one of the best in the country. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I am happy to be out of the office, but I still work long hours, about 80 to 90 a week, and I am still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He says, "I started painting as a hobby, but I enjoyed it much more than my job. It made sense to leave my job and become an artist. A career counselor helped me a lot. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I got married young, and our children are grown, so we could take this chance. We moved to the north of England, where we did not know anyone. We left our friends, but we are lucky that they still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but I worked too many hours. I did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but I never did. I have deadlines to keep me busy. In fashion, there are always new collections and designs to work on, so I have a lot to do. I feel happier now and less stressed. I do miss talking to colleagues. I love that I am responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When I worked for a company, I cared, but now I care even more because my name is on everything."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I worked in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I did not find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited many gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change my career, so I took courses in massage. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control now, and I have peace of mind. That is the best part."

**Text: A Winning Game**

Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties, are sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and playing a game. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, a game they say is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. Soon, the family was playing the game every weekend and holiday, and they had a great time.

The family moved to New Mexico, but they did not forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden crates. They continued to play regularly. When visitors came, they were often curious because the game was unknown in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave saw that the old pichenotte board was damaged, so he decided to make a new one. It looked great! A relative saw it and wanted one. Then a friend wanted one too. 

One night, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People watched and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But then they sat down, and soon they could not leave the table!" When people asked about the game’s origins, Dave did some research. He found that the game probably started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version of the game that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks'. They flick the pucks across a round board using their fingers. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game has eight small posts that are obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

When the brothers saw how popular the game was at the bar, they made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and the game became more popular. Soon, championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was made. As more people learned about the game, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made more than 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. Norm says, "They are very strong and last a long time."

The boards are sold for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope that one day they will be very successful. For now, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of empty land, covered with weeds. For many years, people thought this land was useless. One man, with the help of his wife, worked hard to change this land into the beautiful place you see today. 

Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the lovely landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was also done by hand. After the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 

In the Model Village, hundreds of trees and bushes were planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand. 

The village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, wood, and plastic to last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about the materials, but soon he became an expert himself. 

You will see that all the models are made to the same scale and have many small details. This was done with patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality and care. The methods used here have been used in other model villages in England and even in some college courses about modeling. 

All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House. This is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, based on manor houses found in the West Country. 

As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition. Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; if you accidentally break something, it will take us a long time to fix it. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations. We are always replacing and updating the models, and we need your help to know which ones need attention.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

**Simplified Text:**

Every week, British tabloid newspapers print pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. While some pop stars do take pictures with paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. Usually, it hurts people in the public eye when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-distance photos before. Since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. 

The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other bad stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report this, and it would be on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected and might not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore. 

If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? If the person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities and royals might expect the PCC to take action when stories are about them, and they might be upset if it does not. The job is too big. How could the PCC watch all of the British press: national, local, and magazines? There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to be public. In this case, the PCC might seem like the enemy.

One British comedian had problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he did not complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family on vacation. He was afraid that the newspaper would use the pictures again and say he was angry, thinking it was just a joke. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

**Questions:**

1. What do British tabloid newspapers often print?
2. What is the Press Complaints Commission (PCC)?
3. Why did the actress have a good reason to complain?
4. What might happen if the PCC takes action against newspapers?
5. Why did the comedian not complain about the pictures taken of him?

**Simplified Text:**

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when you want to find a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one. We also do not talk about those who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. Instead, we will help those of you who are ready to take a real step in your career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do.

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to focus on a specific area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, you should be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibilities.

If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after college working for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were very supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance to move up in the job. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really changed. From the start, my boss wanted to help me grow. My job title is the same, but my tasks have changed. I now do most of the letters and budgets. I also answer questions from important people and those who want to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and gives me special projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'Confident People: What's Their Secret?'**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but most say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very scared, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.

**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too much, I don’t feel guilty if I leave some tasks for the next day. When I face something hard, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm down.

**C. Lisa**  
People think I am confident, but I often feel scared. I learned to look confident because it is important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. My mother gave me good advice when I was a teenager: “Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves.” I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt braver.

**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, but I built this confidence over time. If you keep trying and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident. I work hard and am liked at my restaurant, but not everyone likes me. That’s okay. You must like yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which help me feel better about myself. It is good to set small goals and see your progress.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary. I often sat in meetings and did not speak up because I was scared. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my ideas. When I started working in politics, I was very nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day.” I also wrote down some notes to help me. I think everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional. If the line breaks, finders are keepers. I have many more." He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and looked at Malaysia's biggest kite festival.

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs. The kites were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they flew. 

"Flying kites isn't so difficult," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how to make them." I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers in a big room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I could not. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with thick rainforest.

I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, it would have been good to know that most of the path was uphill and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with tea. He took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 

At night, it was very dark, and I heard many sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving and making noise. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got wet quickly. Sliding down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill.

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of the people.

**Simplified Text:**

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I love shopping! I can't spend enough money! When I have money, I go shopping and feel happy. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we go shopping together a lot. We are a shopping couple!"

B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my son and daughter shopping, but we all like different things. I don’t buy things for myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and don’t tell my husband how much I spent."

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for what I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. When I go, I know what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather do something else."

D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want. I don’t waste time and I shop quickly. I do have some clothes in my wardrobe that I don’t wear, so maybe I make some mistakes when I shop."

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really don’t like shopping. I hate shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want. The shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."

F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I think I am a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don’t usually go with a plan, but if I see something I like, I buy it."

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I am a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and I don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse because I spent too much money."

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it is too busy. I am a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want, and I look in different shops to find a better price. It takes me a long time!"

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I don’t like shopping. I work in the city, so shopping is not fun for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try things on because it is too much work. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t care too much. I would rather make mistakes than spend a lot of time in shops."

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE 

The Open University is a place where you can get a degree, just like other universities. You can study without stopping your job. This can help you learn new things and find new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning and gaining knowledge. You will also meet many new friends. Your degree can help you find new job opportunities. 

At the Open University, you do not go to classes like in other universities. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, just like in any university.
