**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, children can join a quiz about surprises. You can get free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will find 14 surprising paintings and answer different questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together."

Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. At first, I was happy at home and didn't want to come. But now, I am really glad I decided to join."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen is not always clean when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun hobby that can last a long time. Starting your collection is easy because you can find stamps everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends.

When you start collecting stamps seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways:

2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps for you to put in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too! A two-year membership costs just £5. If you join with a group, you can get a discount. This is a great deal!

Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and searching for new ones. **MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are types of money. They are like grams or kilometers, but you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or some cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.

A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people who wanted what the other had. Over time, many societies created their own types of money, called currencies, so people could trade more easily. Now, most countries use a national currency.

**Text: Write a Winning Story!**

You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people will win £100. We need people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important for every writer. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and problems with friends. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read more.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: If you describe a place or explain something, make sure you are correct. Don’t write about things you are not sure about.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A bad ending can ruin a good story.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using good words to describe them.

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and on one side of the paper only. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. 

You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have been printed or recorded anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. 

The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He made sure his daughter got a good education. This was special because most women did not have many chances to study. 

After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important works in mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created some scientific tools to help her work. 

At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people connected to it were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is twelve kilometers long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park, starting in Peterborough and ending at Wansford, which is next to the A1 main road. There is a two-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the western end of the line.  
**Fares:** Adult £10.00, Child £5.00, Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices may be available on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It is a great place for a family day out. There are many hectares of parkland with lakes for boating, picnic areas, and a nature reserve. There is also a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a special collection of historic trains from Europe. This includes famous trains like the De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these trains all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with film makers because it can look like a railway in any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed!

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can plan projects for students to do at the railway or in the classroom. There is an educational pack available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. You need to book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a great place for family events or company visits. It can provide a fun afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include food, drinks, and entertainment. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 types of grass, and they grow in every part of the earth. Grass can live in very cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to survive.

Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food available.

Text: 'Kal Kaur Rai is the Young Achiever of the Year. She loves fashion and just won an award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and make designs. She did not tell her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to work in fashion. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She went to events but could not buy the designer clothes she wanted. So, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her clothes, they asked her to make some for them too. She found a small shop in London that sold her designs. They were very popular, and nothing came back. This made her feel good, so she left her advertising job, took a loan of £20,000, and started her own women's clothing brand. Her parents were not angry about her choice and said they would help her, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, she designs for pop stars, and she just won an award. She feels very lucky. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

**SUNNINGDALE HOTEL**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given good service to people from all over the world. Many guests of all ages and nationalities have stayed here. In the last 80 years, over 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have visited Sunningdale.

The hotel is on a main road that goes to the town center. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the center of town. Buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should not take buses with a blue sign that says "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 comfortable single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking for cars in the hotel area. Daily newspapers are free, and guests can buy stamps at the office.

Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their rooms every week in advance. They need to tell the hotel one week before they leave. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.

Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. If guests are studying or working late, they can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing their name on a list or by calling before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires are allowed in the hotel. Guests should be quiet and respect others, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If guests arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main train station.

**Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is a very successful actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked to be in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, making millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a big adventure! The driver found her after a long trip of over 500 kilometres. He was very tired and hungry. He gave Bo some milk and tried to find her owner. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was looking for her too. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that came to his neighbour. He called the company, and soon Bo was back home safely.'

**Text: The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway took a train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cooler south. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late. 

In the 1920s, there was a plan to connect Darwin and Adelaide by train. A train line was built from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but it often had problems with flooding. A new train line was finished a few months before my trip. The train can go up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan is not as luxurious as other famous trains, but the food on board is very good. 

The train was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia by train would save time and money. It is special to have a train that goes from north to south, and the Ghan is the first one in the world to do this.

When I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited for the trip. Most of the other passengers were older Australians. Our first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so we just walked around it and watched the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But on the third day, early in the morning, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and even though the train did not meet all the promises, it took me to some amazing places in Australia.

**Text: Climbing Ben Nevis**

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is the highest mountain in Britain, and it can be very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first climb on Ben Nevis.

"It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is six hundred metres high, which is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are big bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be very hard, like ice. 

Even though some people in my group were very experienced, we took a lot of safety equipment. This included lights to get help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but I still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always hard.

The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest person in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I did, they started climbing again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. But we were not lucky; a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn can lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I enjoyed the climb when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top."

**Text: Anna's New School**

This week is very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a great place. The builders used wood to build it, just like our old school. But this school is one of the first in my country that is good for the environment. 

The school took a long time to build. We watched the builders clear the land where the school would be. It was exciting, but it also meant that some nice land was gone. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because it rained a lot. We thought the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the ones in our old school, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! The heat comes from the people inside - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside. It also keeps the sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that we can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are using the school now, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now!

**Text: No Title**

A month ago, I did not know that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place was not great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.

Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing. Then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. In my handbag were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man asked me what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the telephone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they had my handbag and would bring it back to me. 

I got my handbag back, and everything was inside and untouched. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Text: Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most scary animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food underwater because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. 

Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they do not sleep much. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting animals.
