Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could understand each other.

Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home one night to talk to her because I felt lonely.

The classes in Russia are much harder than my ballet school in England. I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This helps me perform well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends.

Now that I feel settled, I really like it here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was warm for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, and they enjoyed the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. 

In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, on the frozen Torne River. This building was called Arctic Hall, and it attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel began.

Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous around the world. When winter starts, a team of builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As they finish one part, it opens for visitors and guests, while they continue to build other parts. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is finished. 

The ICEHOTEL is built outside, using natural materials from winter, so the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and many woollen socks. They should wear shoes that are a bit bigger than normal to fit the thick socks.

If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange a bus to take you from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday but had to close very quickly. Up to 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop will normally be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but it said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer said, "We knew a large crowd would come, but people were not patient. The shop was full, and the managers decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in. They did not want to wait quietly in line. There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road."

One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. They had to close for safety. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Text: Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is one of the most active arts groups in Britain.

**Society Magazines**

We make great magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine has short stories by famous British writers and gives new writers a chance to print their work. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can see articles from recent issues on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run the National Short Story Competition, the biggest competition for short stories. Anyone aged 18 and over can enter. You can write about any topic. Short stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay to enter (non-members pay £5). The competition is open from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.

**Education**

For almost thirty years, the Society has worked with schools, giving children and teachers new ideas and helping them feel confident in their writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998. It is for writers aged 11-18. All winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is a social place for the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm from Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter has four world records in free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya made history by diving 120 meters deep while holding her breath. She came back up without help. A year before, she had dived deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She became the only woman to break a world record held by a man.

A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive from different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya believes safety is very important, along with training. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya has a regular training schedule. She spends two-thirds of her time training at the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart stronger. She does not run because she wants to protect her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit.

When Tanya practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She tries to do fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important for her not to get tired, as this could affect her preparation. When she is not training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products. She also helps environmental groups by doing research or making films.

Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. She says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. Because she is famous in some countries, people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. In the future, Tanya, who is now in her thirties, wants to keep breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and plans to continue for many more years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons exciting for people of all ages. In the late 1970s, many people thought cartoons were only for children. But soon, some directors had new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

**Text: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role**

"I never thought I would spend my first year at university making a TV show called The Finnegans. I had only acted in school, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother said I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her.

I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She told me there were plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part.

Filming started a week after university began, so I asked for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to write the essays I missed. I didn’t tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel so lucky.

After university, I want to make acting my job. I am not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I have not received any offers yet. I don’t know how I did it all because I also had a busy social life. When filming finished, I didn’t know what to do. I have since acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I am going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, I just wanted to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a big company that is growing fast all over the world. Since we started, I have learned a lot. Many of these lessons are in this book. I believe we have important ideas about how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. 

This is not a normal business book, and it is not just about my life. The main idea is that to be successful in business, you need to be different. Business can be fun, and it can be run with love. It can also help people. In business, like in life, I want to enjoy myself, feel like I am part of a family, and be excited by new things. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. 

Now, this book shares my ideas with everyone. I hope there are no limits to our 'family' and to what we can do. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

**A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER**

Jules Verne runs a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can hold 160 guests in double cabins. All cabins have outside views and a private shower and toilet. On the ship, there is air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and fly to Oporto. A guide will meet you when you arrive and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After seeing the sights in Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will keep traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. At dinner, you can try the delicious food and drink from this area.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will go by bus to the old town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. If the river is deep enough, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach and see many interesting things along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro river valley train for a beautiful ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel a long way, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. 

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey a lot and used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve sports performance. Honey is not just food; it can also help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. It has been a place to live for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. In 1066, when the Normans came, it became one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and celebrated its 900th anniversary recently. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it became a city and could govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It grew for 300 years and became rich, known for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a modern commercial center, especially for insurance services.

Norwich has many entertainment options, like theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, and good restaurants. There is also a football team with green and yellow colors, called 'The Canaries', but no one knows why.

One of the new attractions is a shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, there was a big hole in the city while builders worked on it. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and many trees. The people of Norwich are happy that the old open market is still there, next to the new shopping center. Both places are busy, showing that Norwich has a good mix of old and new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, becomes very colorful. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, which happens every year for nine days. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a parking lot in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries are expected to come.

**What to See**

The pilots talk to each other using radios. They light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great time to take beautiful photos. You should arrive just after night falls or before 5:30 am to see these "glows" as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are in many sizes and colors, some look like animals or cartoon characters, and some are shaped like popular drinks and fast food. Kids will enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies that offer this. Another option is to take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere, and you can see the festival from above.

There are many other fun things for visitors of all ages, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a special wind pattern that helps balloon pilots. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This means that skilled pilots can control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid a long wait. Wear several layers of thin clothes because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and don’t forget your camera. If you use film, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night photos.

**Text: The Eden Project**

The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is one of the most popular places for tourists in the UK. The big 'biospheres' look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone. This shows visitors how important plants are for people. 

Many products we use every day come from plants. For example, we get wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate from plants. There are over 135,000 different types of plants grown here. 

Even if it is cold outside, electric heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone looks like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. There are plans to build a desert zone soon.

**Text: No Title**

Some people have said they do not like this year's book, New Writing 3. I do not understand why. It has 500 pages of good writing for £6.99, which is great! Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are some nice pieces by well-known writers, like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. 

Interestingly, many less famous writers have written about food. I suggest you do not read Jane Harris's story, Those Nails, right after eating. It has some very unpleasant scenes that might make you feel sick! 

There are also poems from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can find parts of novels that are not finished by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a little non-fiction, which has a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers, and a surprising piece by Ursula Owen about herself. 

This is a great collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will be like!

**Text:**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's a time when you learn about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds who really want to learn.

When she started teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts one hour, every two weeks. Also, each student has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons.

From the first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for a few years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to make great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and learn the violin in a more traditional way.

**Text: Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. The CD is called "Here Again" and is a follow-up to their last CD, "The Waves." There have been some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined the band as the new drummer.

The first song on the CD is a dance tune. This shows that the band is not going to focus only on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder. Most of the other songs are in the band’s usual slow style. These two dance songs will surprise many fans. They could easily become popular hits because they are very good.

The singer, Rob Letchford, shows how talented he is by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be happy that he recorded these songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets does not need to worry; all the concerts will be rescheduled as soon as Rob gets better.)

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from the slow songs we know to the dance songs that make you want to move. However, I think they put their best songs at the beginning, and the last few songs are not as good. Still, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and will bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbour, it was found by land, not by sea.

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people were those who owned banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill.

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some even take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

**Text: SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It talks about everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events, like sickness, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his mistakes - he often slept in church or looked at pretty girls. He shares stories about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and his worry about her being sick. He enjoyed books, music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not think much about shoes being comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins. People tied these around their ankles when it was cold. Today, we still use leather for shoes, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton, depending on what is popular.

About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started to wear different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. 

Long ago, all shoes were made by hand. Now, many shoes are made by machines in big factories. The use of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many shoes quickly and at lower prices for more people.

**Text: No Title**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women enjoy running and feel good about it. So, I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers say there are not enough women in running, but they do not make separate changing rooms for them.

I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. Many of them wanted to lose weight, but I don’t think they thought much about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined it was hard and painful. They didn’t see that running can be fun, with chatting and smiling in nice places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes! They have also learned about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to help women with running, and I feel very happy to see how much they have improved. They are happy too!

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people came to Alaska to find gold and get rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod became the largest city in Alaska for a short time.

In the summer, boats could bring supplies to the towns. But in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, and it was hard to reach them. So, in 1910, a winter path was made for dog teams pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took a team of dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' to rest and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams for transport. However, in 1925, dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and no one knew if they could fly in the cold. The best pilot was away, so they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine.

The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to finish the journey. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian looking for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way in the snow, and Togo was a great guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, stopped the team from falling into icy water. The medicine arrived, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the famous route from 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Text: Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, the temperature can be very low, around -40°C. But every year, 6,000 visitors come to see a very special hotel. This hotel is made of ice. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even have a wedding there. The bar is made of ice too, so it is not good to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to keep warm. They can also get warm outdoor clothes if they need them. The hotel only lasts for six months because it melts in summer. Every winter, workers rebuild the hotel. It takes 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to make it.

**Text: Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl on a boys' team in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was in a local newspaper. Jose Craveirinha, who helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He realized she was very fast.

"He talked to me about athletics. I did not understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was hard work, and my legs hurt." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful and help their family. They agreed to let him take her to train.

In 1991, she accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she would miss her family. Her life was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but I worried about my parents having enough to eat. They worried about dresses and make-up. They did not know much about me or my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was made by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and see the view. The view is very beautiful, and it is even better because of the Skywalk. 

The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and a glass floor, so you can see the lovely rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. The Skywalk opened in 2007, and since then, many people have visited it. 

You must wear special covers over your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains are in North America. They start in the North-west and go down to the south. The Rockies are not as high as the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of Canada’s most beautiful cities. In Vancouver, you can enjoy the water and the mountains. You can ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. 

Before, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to travel across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still very exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will see the best views at night.

**Text: ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. A long time ago, the rulers of China opened a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. Now, this does not happen. Today, the purpose of zoos is for people to see animals acting naturally.

Most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people think zoos are good because they help us learn about nature and see wild animals up close. These things would not be possible without zoos. 

However, some people do not like zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and do not get good food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, while others wore bright T-shirts. We did not look like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions. The quality of our playing was amazing, especially because we are all so young. Players from each band even made new songs right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but it was even better when my band played!  

My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone who wants to join can. Only about half of the people who try out get in. However, anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not challenging enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can create your own music, but you also feel part of its history when you play on stage like great jazz performers did before you. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we would not get far with our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain from November to March. It does not rain often, but when it does, the water pipes in the city cannot handle it. This makes the streets very wet, like rivers. Many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the people are happy. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not depend on rain. They get water from underground channels that were made in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year. Places that are mostly dry and get water this way are called oases.

Further south of Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, people use every piece of land to grow food. The Atlas mountains, which are covered in snow in winter, look beautiful in the background.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan, who is an engineer, and Kath, who is a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. 

"People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three years old." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

"I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone at school, and I have a computer. I have never fallen behind my classmates."

And what about the future? "It was a hard decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we are enjoying it." And Gareth? "I am going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people. Our members are aged 8 to 18 years old. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers in the country where young people can meet and join projects. We plan to open more centers soon. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: "I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was amazed by what they could do. Age didn't matter; they could do stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19, and now I work on a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to help each other. 'Peer trainers' are members who are 12 years old and older. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they get better at training, some members present sessions to other young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. 

During the short summer in Antarctica, we take tourists on a big passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. The flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be changed if we need to change the date.

**Questions**

Here are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**  
The flight is about 12 hours long. After about four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will talk about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers get two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will move to the seat on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and a seat at the end of the row for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can see the sights. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting places so that everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain looks at the weather and chooses the best direction for clear views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica because of environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can wear Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together."

Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. At first, I was happy to stay at home, but now I am really glad I came."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen is not always clean when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, which can make you lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide across the road.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. If you move the car suddenly, it can be hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, press the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you do not spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what might happen. The more ice there is, the further down the road you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. 

In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. In art school, he found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He became interested in early Italian artists, and this can be seen in some of his paintings. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. 

To do this, he painted colors thinly, one on top of another, from light to dark. He said, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top." Aitchison makes painting sound easy. He said, "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what you put the colors next to."

Unlike some artists, he does not make drawings before he starts painting. He thinks that if he draws first, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes to paint people who do not ask to see their pictures while he is painting. He said, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since he moved to London, he has not felt part of the Scottish art scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but he just paints the way he can. Still, his work influences young British painters.

**Text: 'Rock Band'**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we did not like the idea because of the noise. Ben said, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, Ben's friends began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours a week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby is good for our health: when the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must say, even if their music sounds a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good musicians, but they play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they will not spend enough time on their school work because of their music, but this has not happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. One thing is sure: Ben was right. His music has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. It helps young people get important life experience outside the classroom and study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from many countries. In the morning, they study, and in the afternoon, they do useful activities. These activities include helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One good thing about Atlantic College is that students come from different backgrounds and countries. Many students cannot pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants available. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for trying to encourage understanding among young people. You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don’t like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn’t believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In summary, Atlantic College gives its students a great education with methods that really work.

**Text: Being an Older Student**

I am 32 years old and I just finished my first year at university. I go to lectures and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. 

Before, I worked as a secretary. I earned good money, but I was bored because my job was easy and I did not have to think much. I felt sad because I thought I was stuck in that job. I saw students at the local university who looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to feel that way too.

Now that I am a student, I find it hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. 

But I am happy to study because I know I need a qualification to get a good job, and that is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer to spend my weekends reading books instead of going to parties. I also enjoy the student benefits like long holidays and discounts for the theatre and cinema. 

Sometimes I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that going back to school now is a good choice.

**Text: Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen years old, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and built two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cars that were cheap for regular people to buy. 

In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant there were fewer choices. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 

'Dear Sir, 

I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I want to know more information. How much does a course cost? How long is each course? When does the next course start? 

Yours, 
Maria Gonzalez 

Dear Ms. Gonzalez, 

Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course is 6 weeks long and it costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that is 10 weeks long for £200. 

I hope this information helps you. 

Yours, 
David May'

**Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS'**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she was a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family and traveled to Asia with some other climbers. She found that life on Everest is hard. 

"You must carry everything on your back," she said. "You can only take what you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I am usually a clean person, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job too, on a science program on television. 

Rebecca is well known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you were sick and stayed in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party! Many of my friends were there and they gave me nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

**Text: 'CANADA GEESE'**

Canada Geese are big blue and white birds. When autumn comes, they fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know what to do in autumn." 

Bill had a small plane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. 

Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They did not arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks but could not find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon made £1,000.

At first, her parents did not want her to make jam. They thought she should study and become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen to them. She kept making jam. After a few months, she sold it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice and sold it to a school where her friend worked.

After two years, her business grew a lot, and her parents were very happy. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she needed to hire some people to help her.

Text: 

'Dear Jacqueline, 

Do you want to go to the cinema with me after school today? We can see Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? 

Love, Isabella 

Dear Isabella, 

I am very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I will cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go? I hope you like the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. 

Love, Jacqueline'

**Text: Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they do not get too warm.

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer, and the weather was hot, so people did not want to buy sweaters. Then, she made some socks. Everyone loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business started.

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had many customers. So, she had to send the wool to a factory, where all the socks are now made by machines. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. 

Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

Text: 

'28 Long Road  
Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,  

I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students are from many different countries, and I have made new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like my teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me when I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.  

Best wishes,  
Maria'

**Text: 'BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of house burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people go out and forget to close a door or a window. 

He said that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. But winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark and they cannot be seen easily. Many houses are empty at that time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This will help keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch the other houses in the street when people are not home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 

"We will also tell you how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This help costs nothing."

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, 

Thank you for the two nights I stayed in your nice home. It was good to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are nice photos, right? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I will visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time. Thanks again. 

Love, Roy'

**Text: The History of Farming**

Before people started farming, they looked for plants and fruit in the forest to eat. This meant they had to move all the time to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. 

Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. 

However, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it can travel a long way to reach our homes.

**Text: WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet left school when she was eighteen. She went to college and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Later, she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she became a manager.

This is what she said about her job: "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer. Then, I talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. 

Travelling can be hard. When I come back from a long trip, I just eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways. I want to stay there and keep travelling."

Text: 'Dear Maria, I am happy to be back home in my country, but I still think about my friends from our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study harder. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 

"Dear Sir, 

I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a big blue bag, and my name is on it. Have you found this bag? 

Yours faithfully, 
Mary Johnson 

Dear Ms. Johnson, 

I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6:30 p.m. every day. 

Yours sincerely, 
J Wilson"

Text: 'The Weather People care about the weather for many reasons. The weather is important for many jobs. For example, it is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to learn about the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us understand the weather. People can also get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people think that if cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have always been friends and go to the same school. Like their other friends, they like to go fishing or swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room using his laptop. They are not doing a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who has trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better when he sees pictures and hears sounds than when he reads. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make this game, and now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there is a picture of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be sold around the world. Many schools want to buy it.'

Text: 'HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? 

Sleeping well is very important. When I go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my head is full of music. 

Sport is also important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don’t drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don’t always drink that much. 

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also like to do other things. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. I don’t feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

**Text: 'Bollywood'**

'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since it made its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians like to watch films more than any other free-time activity, and ten million people go to the cinema every day. 

Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every film. People outside India also enjoy Indian films. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs at least $5 million to make. 

Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who some people say is India's greatest actor, is different. He has been the star of more than 140 films in his acting career of almost 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. Now, we have lived in the United States for the last three years. Our children are learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happier because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so I cannot go back for four more years.

I just went to England for six weeks to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about my new book. Most writers do not like to travel around the country to sell their books, but I do not mind it. I enjoy visiting new places and meeting many people. It is very different from my life in the United States when I am writing. In England, people drove me in big cars, and I stayed in nice hotels. It was good because I did not have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is newer here. The Giant Schnauzer is very big. It is 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, and they need to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany. Farmers use these dogs to help with sheep. The police also use Schnauzers because they are very smart. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and great with young children.

**Text: The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help make a road through a forest between two big towns.

"It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food," said Mary. "It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world."

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

Text: 

'Dear Keira, 

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers are friendly, but I am a little scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework. 

Hester'

**New Books This Month**

**The Long Night**  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for many years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take her to the nearest big city. They have many problems on the way.

**Hard Work**  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. One day, a man in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

**Hospital or Cinema?**  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story this year. Tina is a young woman from Brazil. Her dream is to become a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. One day, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina do?

Text: 'The History of Horse Racing

Horse racing is an important sport. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago. People in ancient Greece and Rome also loved horse racing. Modern horse racing began in the 12th century when Arab horses came to Europe. 

At first, races were long and only two horses ran against each other. But in the 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and had many horses running together. 

Today, more people watch horse racing than any other sport in the USA, except for baseball. Horse racing is also very popular in other parts of the world.'

Text: 'Nick Barlow is a world traveller. He is a British actor and he travels to many countries to make TV shows. "People are nice to me everywhere I go. When I come home, I remember all the great things that happened in each country," he says. Nick has been to many places, but he still wants to visit some more. "I would love to go to South America and visit Australia again one day," he says. Nick travels with a team of people. They bring cameras and other equipment to make the show. Nick does not take many things for himself, just a few shirts and pants, but he always brings some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him travelling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he comes back, she likes to hear his travel stories. But sometimes there are problems. When he was in the Malaysian rain forest, Nick heard that his wife was sick in the hospital. "I felt very bad because I could not help, but she did not want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

You may have seen parrots. They are beautiful birds with bright colors and long tails. Parrots live in places like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in big groups. Parrots like to eat fruit, so they can sometimes be a problem for farmers.

There are many types of parrots. All parrots have strong beaks and feet. They use their beaks and feet to climb and hold food. Some parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds. You can teach them to talk. Some zoos have shows with parrots, where you can see them do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER

Bray is a beautiful village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old.

When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He liked this so much that he decided not to buy many clothes and CDs. Instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty!

So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it is expensive to start your own restaurant and it is much harder to cook for fifty people than to cook for your family, but he is sure he has done the right thing.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, he was in Tokyo, and many Japanese people watched him on television because he is a famous singer in Japan. John is thirty-five years old.

A few months ago, John went to Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young people called the radio to ask for his songs again. In Japan, John uses the name Jon Otis when he sings.

John will continue to work in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from his music. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing.

John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, "This will not change how we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"
