**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have a new hobby: line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are young and old people. The boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people think it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is very hard, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run fast, up to 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live for 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police officers at all. A few old men tried to protect the city streets at night, but they did not get paid much. About 300 years ago, London was getting bigger. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people stayed at home as much as they could.

In 1750, Henry Fielding started to pay some people to stop the thieves. They were like police officers and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown very big and needed more police officers. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid well, and the few who still ride horses get paid even better.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Do you want to go on a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. There are hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles. The trip costs £25. It is very cold at night, so please take warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, tell me today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, for the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from all over the world. They come to Edinburgh for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students do comedy shows in small places like cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to see new films, plays, and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, you can see over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are not very expensive, and it is usually easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. 

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he says. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Text: 

'From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I am not having a good week! Yesterday, my team had a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team played better than us. Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called me with bad news. He cannot come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We cannot go camping together now. This morning, my sister got up late and rode my bike to school! She did not tell me she needed it. I am really angry with her.  

I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg'

**Text: Madame Tussaud's**

One famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Here, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, made wax figures. He opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with his work. 

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie went to prison. There, she had to make copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she came to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum, and her figures can still be seen today.

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive, and only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from today’s bicycles. Later, when bicycles became cheaper, many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and for fun. 

Today, many people use cars more than bicycles because cars are faster and keep you dry in the rain. But some people still like to ride bicycles to work. They say there are too many cars in town centers, and it is hard to find a place to park!

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we wanted to see the elephant show. We went to a big square with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of a large white card. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. The trainers gave each elephant a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, the elephants followed their trainers' instructions and drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the last one a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we brought for lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special places where visitors can watch them.'

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many kinds of cats. They are different in size and look. Tigers are the biggest cats. They can be 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Most cats do not like water, but tigers often lie in water when it is hot. 

Lions are the only cats that live in big family groups. Many lions work together to find food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and follow other animals easily. All cats need good eyes to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Text: 

'Dear Mrs. Brian, 

I am sorry, but I cannot come to your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will make a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sad to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you. 

Best wishes, 
Soraya'

Text: 

14 Sheffield Road  
Rotherham  
20th May 2002  

Dear Mary,  

I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then.  

Yours,  
Joan  

20 Didsbury Drive  
London NW1  
22 May 2002  

Dear Joan,  

Thank you for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant near there. Do you like Italian food? I have to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don’t be late!  

Yours,  
Mary

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I am happy because last month I got a new job in the city. I work in a Tourist Information Office and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up early! I love this job because I meet people from different countries. I like telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, from 65 to 90 kilometres an hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow up. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson is a snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now she is 23 and has won many competitions. We talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland last week. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I have always liked sports, especially skiing. It was natural for me to start snowboarding. It is easy to learn, and you can get good in a few months." 

We asked her if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains. It is so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best for me." 

We also asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It is also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet because you will fall down a lot at first!"'

Text: 

'23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,  

I want a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I would like a single room with a shower. I also need a telephone in my room. Can I have a quiet room on the ground floor? I will drive to the hotel. Is there a car park? I will arrive at about 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close? If possible, I would like a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your help.  

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones'

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the highest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and many tourists use this path. 

Only half of the climbers who try to reach the top succeed. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. Otters live near rivers and make their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, so it can stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, and many fish and insects died. The otters could not find food. But today, there is a lot of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

Text: 

'Dear Deshini, 

I am happy that you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would like to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you can send me? I am sending you some photos of my family. I will send more next time I write. I hope you will write to me soon. 

Tom'

Text: 

'17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,  

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I liked my time in Cambridge. Now I am at my brother's flat. He is studying to be a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go home to Greece. I like London a lot. We went to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was sunny and we had fun. Tonight, I will see a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write again from Greece.  

Best wishes,

Text: 

'Dear David, 

I will visit your country next month. I am traveling with two friends. We do not know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the center. Can you help us? 

Carlos 

Dear Carlos, 

Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you. She says you can stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? 

David'

**Text: Buildings**

People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We also have buildings like museums to keep beautiful things.

Many people work together to build a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures of their ideas. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully build it.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous building with a beautiful roof. It looks nice from every side, not just the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich is also famous. It has a roof that looks like a tent made of glass.

Text: "Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don’t have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my pants are too short for me now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe some boots. I don’t have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika"

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. No one knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on the first of May when the sun comes up, you will see many people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for coming second in big races. She always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for this.

In 2004, everything changed when she ran her first half-marathon, which is a long race. She won and had the fastest time of the year for any British woman runner. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also ran when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him.

Gail trains hard. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It is usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything."

**Text: Piano Players - When They Were Young**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano, but she taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. When he was ten, he wanted to write music, and he began his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who liked to play the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg soon won prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. After that, he returned to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German, but he taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two years old. A year later, he started playing the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he gave fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he would like to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office and writes. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren do not live near me, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." Because of this, Bill has learned what young children want to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and on the farms nearby. His fifth book is his favorite: *The Sheepdog* is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used new technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people send postcards to their friends and family. These postcards often have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are cheap and the pictures are often nicer than their own photos. 

The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed news events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these postcards because there were no pictures in newspapers at that time.

**Text: Dinosaurs**

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago, a long time before people were on Earth. Nobody knows for sure why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds. Some were very small, but others were very big. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other animals that ever lived on land. 

For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long, and it ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat. It could also run fast because it had long back legs.

**Text: BEARS**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can hurt a person. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run fast. However, they cannot see well. Like most animals, they find food using their noses. 

There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which is almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. 

Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Not many pandas live in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles live in warm places in the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They spend most of their time in slow water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in big groups. They eat many things, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they can also eat big animals or even people. There are more than ten types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. They can live a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon to take people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first plane with an engine and flew it. This happened in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 

Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 

Today, millions of people travel by aeroplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof. People got cold and wet if it rained. The queen liked to go to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see plays by William Shakespeare. All the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! 

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place by the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life in the 1600s.

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I am having a good holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is very beautiful. We do not want to go home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
